      • MISRA-C:2004

      • TBrun Requires

      • VSOS
LDRA Standards for C / C++
1 S
Procedure name reused.

Names to be used in different contexts such as blocks and namespaces. This may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. This standard reports when a procedure name is reused in any another context within the same file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void foo(UINT_32 p_1)
{
   UINT_32 x = p_1;
}
 
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 1 S : Procedure name reused.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_1(void)
{
   UINT_32 foo = 1u;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.1  
CMSE : 1.1.1  
DERA : 21  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
GJB : 4.1.1.1  
HIS : 21  
LMTCP : 248  
MISRA-AC : 5.2, 5.7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 21  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2, 5.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
2 S
Label name reused.

Names to be used in different contexts such as blocks and namespaces. This may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 2 S : Label name reused.
 *  (Superceded by other penalties depending on implementation)
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_2 (void)
{
   UINT_32 y = 0u;
 
value_x:
   y = 1u;
   {  value_x: /* not compliant; label already used */
       y= 2u;
   }
   /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.2  
CMSE : 1.1.2  
DERA : 12  
GJB : 4.1.1.2  
LMTCP : 16  
MISRA-AC : 5.7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 12  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
3 S
More than *** executable reformatted lines in file.

This standard enables managers to control the amount of code in each file. The limit is user definable. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 2000. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Related standards model rules
CMSE : 2.2.1  
EADS-C : 4  
GJB : 4.2.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
4 S
Procedure exceeds *** reformatted lines.

This standard enables managers to control the size of the procedures. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 200. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 4 S : Procedure exceeds *** reformatted lines
 *
 * Note: To see the message in this example,
 *       set the parameter to 20 in the pen.dat file
 ********************************************************/ 
 
BOOL isHexDigit( CHAR Hex )
{
  BOOL bResult = FALSE;
 
  if ((Hex == '0') || (Hex == '1') || (Hex == '2') || (Hex == '3') ||
      (Hex == '4') || (Hex == '5') || (Hex == '6') || (Hex == '7') ||
      (Hex == '8') || (Hex == '9') || (Hex == 'A') || (Hex == 'a') ||
      (Hex == 'B') || (Hex == 'b') || (Hex == 'C') || (Hex == 'c') ||
      (Hex == 'D') || (Hex == 'd') || (Hex == 'E') || (Hex == 'e') ||
      (Hex == 'F') || (Hex == 'f'))
  {
    bResult = TRUE;
  }
  return bResult;
 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.7  
CMSE : 2.2.2  
FSB582-C : 2.4.1  
FSB582-C++ : 3.5  
GJB : 4.2.2.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
5 S
Empty then clause.

The use of empty then clauses can be due either to errors or deliberate avoidance of negative boolean expressions. The options flagged are: 

        if(...) else
	if(...) {} else
	if(...) {;} else

The inclusion of a comment within the empty then clause { /* */ } is deemed to indicate that the absence of executable code is deliberate, and hence no standard will report in this circumstance. 

	if(...) { /* ... */ } else
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 5 S : Empty then clause
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_5(void)
{
   UINT_32 value_x = 1u;
 
   if (value_x == 0u)
   {
#if FALSE
     value_x = value_x + 1u;
#endif
   } 
   /* not compliant */
 
   if (value_x == 0u) {;} /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.3.1  
CERT-C : MSC03-C  
CMSE : 3.1.1  
CWE : 480  
DERA : 141  
FSB582-C : 3.9.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 9.1  
GJB : 4.3.1.1  
SEC-C : M1.9.1  
6 S
Procedure pointer declared.

The use of procedure pointers is considered to be dangerous by some bodies and needs to be tightly controlled. For example, the pointer could be rogue, and also will obscure control flow.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void foo(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2)
{ /* ... */ }
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 6 S : Procedure pointer declared.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_6(void)
{
  void (*proc_pointer) (UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2) = foo; /* not compliant */
 
  proc_pointer(1u, 1);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.4.3  
CMSE : 4.1.3  
GJB : 4.4.1.3  
JPL : 9  
7 S
Jump out of procedure.

This is compiler dependent but most commonly is a use of longjmp. This is generally considered bad practice.

Example
#include <setjmp.h> 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 7 S : jump out of procedure
 ******************************************************************/ 
static void static_7(jmp_buf mark, SINT_32 val)
{
   longjmp(mark,val);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.5.1  
CMSE : 5.1.1  
GJB : 4.5.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
8 S
Empty else clause.

The use of empty else clauses can either be due to incomplete code or deliberate policy to show that the possibility has been considered. The options flagged are: 

	else ;
	else { }
	else {;}

The inclusion of a comment within the empty else clause { /* */ } is deemed to indicate that the absence of executable code is deliberate, and hence no standard will report in this circumstance: 

	else { /* ... */ }
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 8 S : Empty else clause
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_8 (void)
{
   UINT_32 name_x = 1u;
 
   if (name_x == 0u)
   { /* ... */ }
   else ;  /* not compliant */
 
   if (name_x == 0u)
   { /* ... */ }
   else   /* not compliant */
   {
#if FALSE
      name_x = name_x + 1u;
#endif
   }
 
   if (name_x == 0u)
   { /* ... */ }
   else
   { ; }  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.3.2  
CMSE : 3.1.3  
FSB582-C : 3.9.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 9.1  
GJB : 4.3.1.3  
SEC-C : M1.9.1  
9 S
Assignment operation in expression.

The assignment operator (=) sets an lvalue, whereas the equality operator (==) performs a comparison. It is possible that the assignment operator was typed in error. It can also cause unexpected side effects.

This standard can be relaxed to allow postfix increment and decrement operators on the RHS of an assignment or in a comparison to NULL by setting the modifiers 259 and 266 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 9 S : Assignment operator in expression.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
BOOL static_9(BOOL test)
{
   BOOL result,flag;
 
   result = ( flag = test ); /* not compliant */
 
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP30-C, EXP31-C, FIO41-C, PRE31-C  
CMSE : 6.1.1  
DERA : 33, 35, 40, 46  
EADS-C : 166, 167  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
GJB : 4.6.1.1  
HIC++ : 10.3, 10.5, 10.6  
HIS : 33, 35, 40, 46  
JSF++ AV : 160, 204   Modifiers : 259 = 1, 266 = 1
LMTCP : 362  
MISRA-AC : 12.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1, 6-2-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 33, 35, 40, 46  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.1, R.13.2, R.13.4

SEC-C : M3.2.2, R3.6.1, R3.6.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
11 S
No brackets to loop body (added by Testbed).

The use of curly brackets, {}, in controlled clauses is recommended for maintenance purposes. Upon detection of this standards violation LDRA Testbed inserts the required brackets into the reformatted code to permit instrumentation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 11 S : No brackets to loop body
 ********************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 static_11( void )
{
  SINT_32 j = 10;
  SINT_32 k = 0;
 
  for (k = 0; k < 10; k = k + 1) j--; /* not compliant */
 
  return j;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.1, 5.2.2  
CMSE : 2.1.2  
CWE : 483  
DERA : 59  
EADS-C : 145, 165, 166, 167  
FSB582-C++ : 9.1  
GJB : 4.2.1.1, 4.2.1.2  
HIC++ : 5.1  
HIS : 59  
JSF++ AV : 59  
LMTCP : 84  
MISRA-AC : 14.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-3-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 59  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.15.6  
NETRINO : 1.3.a  
SEC-C : M2.1.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
12 S
No brackets to then/else (added by Testbed).

The use of curly brackets, {}, in controlled clauses is recommended for maintenance purposes. Upon detection of this standards violation LDRA Testbed inserts the required brackets into the reformatted code to permit instrumentation.

This standard can be relaxed to allow else if ( rather than else { if } ) by setting the tbend modifier to F in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 12 S : No brackets to then/else
 ********************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 static_12(SINT_32 p_1, SINT_32 p_2)
{
   SINT_32 i = 1;
   SINT_32 j = 0;
 
   if (p_1 > 0)
   {
     i = i - 1;
   }
   else
      i = i + 1;          /* not compliant */
 
   if (p_2 > 0)
   {
      j = j + p_2;
   }
   else if (p_2 < 0)    /* not compliant but permitted with modifier */
   {
      j = j - p_2;
   }
   else
   {
      j = i;
   }
   return j;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.3  
CERT-C : MSC01-C  
CMSE : 2.1.3  
CWE : 483

FSB582-C : 3.9.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 9.1

Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
13 S
goto detected.

The use of goto is usually considered bad practice, as its use leads to code that can be difficult to read and maintain.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 13 S : goto detected.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_13(void)
{
   SINT_32 jump_flag = 0;
start:
   jump_flag++;
   if (jump_flag < 10)
   {
      goto start; /* not compliant */
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.5.2  
CMSE : 5.1.2  
DERA : 56  
EADS-C : 119  
FSB582-C++ : 9.10  
GJB : 4.5.1.2  
HIC++ : 5.8  
HIS : 56  
JPL : 1  
JSF++ AV : 189  
LMTCP : 340  
MISRA-AC : 14.4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 56  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.15.1  
NETRINO : 1.7.c, 8.5.a  
SEC-C : M3.1.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
14 S
Procedural parameter declared.

Passing procedures as parameters is an issue on which authorities are divided. They can be used to generalise software, but also to obscure control flow. This standard will report any instances encountered.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void test_14s(SINT_32 p_1)
{ /* ... */ }
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 14 S : Procedural parameter declared.
 ********************************************************/ 
void static_14(void (*p_proc_pointer)(SINT_32 parameter_1) )
{
   p_proc_pointer = test_14s;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 1.2.2  
DERA : 149  
GJB : 4.1.2.2  
16 S
Multiple labels declared.

With the exception of case labels, the use of multiple consecutive labels is considered redundant by some authorities; only one is required.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 16 C : Multiple labels declared
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_16(void)
{
start:begin: /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.3  
CMSE : 1.1.4  
GJB : 4.1.1.4  
17 S
Code insert found.

This standard reports the presence of any sections of assembler code, which are compiler dependent.

Example
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 17 S : Code insert found.
 *******************************************************/ 
static void static_17(void)
{
   _asm
   {
      mov eax,01h
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 3  
HIC++ : 13.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-4-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 3  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
18 S
More than *** parameters in procedure.

The trade-off between the use of global variables and parameters is a complex issue, but parameter passing is less efficient than using globals. Also parameters could be grouped into structures to reduce the complexity of the interface. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to six. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

This standard can be relaxed to allow constructors to exceed the specific number of parameters by setting the modifier 209 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 18 S : More than *** parameters in procedure.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_18(UINT_32 p_1,
               UINT_32 p_2,
               UINT_32 p_3,
               UINT_32 p_4,
               UINT_32 p_5,
               UINT_32 p_6,
               UINT_32 p_7,
               UINT_32 p_8) /* not compliant */
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.20  
CMSE : 1.2.3  
FSB582-C : 3.7.10  
GJB : 4.1.2.3  
HIC++ : 4.3  
JSF++ AV : 110   Modifiers : 209 = 1
LMTCP : 205   Modifiers : 209 = 1
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML
19 S
Procedural para used in an uncalled procedure.

This standard reports when an uncalled procedure receives a procedural parameter, which therefore is never called.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 19 S : Procedural parameter used in uncalled procedure.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_19( void ( * p_proc_pointer )(void) )  /* not compliant */
{
   p_proc_pointer();
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.8  
CMSE : 7.2.1  
GJB : 4.7.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
20 S
Parameter not declared explicitly.

As part of LDRA Testbed's strong type checking, this standard reports when a partial declaration or definition of a procedure is encountered. Some compilers allow default types for parameters, which introduces non-portability and relies on the underlying implementation, rather than the specific code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 20 S : Parameter not declared explicitly.
 ********************************************************/
 
UINT_32 static_20_135( p_1 ) /* not compliant */
{
   UINT_32 result;
   result = p_1 * 2;
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.4  
CERT-C : DCL31-C  
CMSE : 1.1.5  
CWE : 628  
DERA : 71  
GJB : 4.1.1.5  
HIS : 71  
MISRA-AC : 8.1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 71  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

21 S
Number of parameters does not match.

Some compilers will successfully link regardless of the numbers of actual and formal parameters. In particular, this may happen for functions without a prototype as such behaviour is undefined in C. This standard reports any mismatches in the number of parameters between the declaration and the call.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 test_21(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2)
{
   UINT_32 result = 0;
   result = p_1 + p_2;
   return result;
}
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 21 S : Number of parameters does not match.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_21(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2)
{
   test_21(1u, 2u ,2u); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.1  
CERT-C : DCL07-C, EXP37-C  
CMSE : 7.1.1  
CWE : 234, 235, 685  
DERA : 78  
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
GJB : 4.7.1.1  
HIS : 78  
MISRA-AC : 16.6  
MISRA-C:1998 : 78  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1, R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

22 S
Use of obsolete language feature ( use = - ).

Early versions of languages (non-ANSI) had a reverse ordering for [operator] assign syntax. Examples of the ambiguous operators are: 

			=-  =*  =+

where a careless initialisation of

			i = -1;
			val = *ptr;

is not the same as

			i =- 1;
			val =* ptr;
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 22 S : Use of obsolete language feature ( use = - ).
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_22(void)
{
   SINT_32 b = 1, a = 0;
 
   a =- b;  /* not compliant */
   a =+ b;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 1, 137  
GJB : 4.8.2.1  
HIS : 1  
JSF++ AV : 8  
MISRA-C:1998 : 1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
23 S
Procedure is not explicitly called in code analysed.

This standard reports procedures in a file containing a main procedure, that are not called by any procedures in that file. If the procedure is not used in the file then it could be removed or moved to another file where it is used.

Note that this standard detects explicit procedure calls and so will also give a warning if a procedure is only accessed via its address. In such cases the procedure may not be removed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************************
 * Standard 23 S : Procedure is not explicitly called in code analysed.
 *********************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_23(UINT_32 p)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
 
   x = x + p;
 
   return x;
} /* not compliant */
 
 
INT_32 main(void)
{
    /* ... */ 
    return (0);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.18  
CMSE : 1.2.10, 7.1.2  
CWE : 561  
GJB : 4.7.1.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
24 S
Use of Noanalysis annotation.

Warns that LDRA Testbed NO_ANALYSIS annotation has been utilised within the analysis scope. This means that the user has intentionally not analysed all of the code within the source file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 24 S : Use of Noanalysis annotation.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_24(void)
{
   UINT_32  x;
 
   x = 1u;
 
/*LDRA_NOANALYSIS*/ /* not compliant */
   x = x + 1u;
/*LDRA_ANALYSIS*/
 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 10.2.1  
GJB : 4.10.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
25 S
Null case in switch statement.

These correspond to cases which fall through to the following case or default. They should be inspected to see if a break statement is missing.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 25 S :  Null case in switch statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 static_25(SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 i = 0, j = 0;
 
  switch (p_1)
  {
     case 0:
        j = 0;
        break;
     case 1:
     case 2:  /* not compliant */
        j=i;
        break;
     default:
        i = j + 1;
  }
 
  return i + j;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.3.5  
CMSE : 3.1.8  
GJB : 4.3.1.8  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , RUNTIME , Standard
26 S
Loop control expression may not terminate loop.

An infinite loop may be present if the control expression is never zero. This may occur in cases such as:

   for ( ; ; )        empty control expression
   for ( ; i < 10; )  no incrementer
   while ( 1 )        non-zero constant
   do.. while(!0)     non-zero constant

This standard takes no account of other methods of changing the controlling expression nor of any breaks within the loop body. More precise forms of infinite loop detection are performed by 5 C and 28 D. Infinite loops may be used for legitimate purposes, for example in Real-Time systems, but the potential for dangerous behaviour is still reported.

This standard can be relaxed so that only checks for non-zero constants are performed by setting the modifier 425 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. An exception is made for for loops where all the clauses are empty.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 26 S : Loop control expression may not terminate loop.
 ******************************************************************/
 
void static_26 (void)
{
  UINT_32 a = 0U;
 
  while (1)  /* not compliant */
  {
     /* ... */ 
  }
 
  do
  {
     /* ... */ 
  } while (1);   /* not compliant */
 
  for (a = 0U; ; a++)  /* not compliant */ 
  {
     /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.11.3  
CMSE : 11.2.1  
DERA : 142  
EADS-C : 133  
GJB : 4.11.2.1  
HIC++ : 5.3  
JPL : 2  
SEC-C : M1.9.2   Modifiers : 425 = 1
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , TBrun Requires , VSOS
27 S
Void procedure with return statement.

If the procedure returns void, then any return statement should not return a value. 36 S reports on functions without a corresponding return value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 27 S : Void procedure with return statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_27( UINT_32 p_1, UINT_32 p_2)
{
   UINT_32 result;
   result = p_1 + p_2;
   return result; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.2  
CMSE : 9.1.2  
CWE : 398  
DERA : 84  
EADS-C : 112  
GJB : 4.9.1.2  
HIS : 84  
MISRA-C:1998 : 84  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
28 S
Duplicated Base Classes in a Derived class.

This standard reports when a derived class is based upon different classes which have a common base class. In such cases multiple base class objects are created and it can be ambiguous as to which member function is called. Virtual inheritance should be used instead.

Example
class Base
{
   public:
      void func ( void );
};
 
 
class Sub1: public Base { /* ... */ };
class Sub2: public Base { /* ... */ };
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 28 S : Duplicated Base Classes in a Derived class.
 ********************************************************/
 
class derived : public Sub1, public Sub2 { /* ... */ }; // not compliant
 
void static_028 ( void )
{
	derived d;
	d.func ();  // ambiguous whether Sub1::Base::func()
	            //                or Sub2::Base::func()
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.15  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

29 S
Use of += or -= operators found.

Some organisations believe that the use of these constructs is dangerous.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 29 S : Use of += or -= operators found.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_29(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
   UINT_32 y = 2u;
   UINT_32 z = 3u;
 
   x += 1u; /* not compliant */
   z -= y; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.1  
CMSE : 8.2.1  
GJB : 4.8.2.1  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
30 S
Deprecated usage of ++ or -- operators found.

The use of these operators in an expression is considered dangerous because of the side effect. This standard should also be considered in conjunction with 124 S which flags all prefix uses of ++ and --. Users are advised to select one or other of these standards.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the use of ++ and -- in stand-alone expressions and the 3rd expression of a for loop by setting the modifier 122 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. By default, the standard is configured to permit the relaxed use as described.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void foo( UINT_32 p_x)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 30 S : Deprecated usage of ++ or -- operators found.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_30(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
   UINT_32 y = 2u;
 
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   if (flag == FALSE)
   {
      x++;   /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 122 */
   }
 
   x = x + y++;  /* not compliant */
   foo( x++ );   /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP30-C, EXP31-C, FIO41-C  
CMSE : 8.2.2  
CWE : 737   Modifiers : 122 = 1
DERA : 33, 46  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2   Modifiers : 122 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
GJB : 4.8.2.2  
HIC++ : 10.3  
HIS : 33, 46  
LMTCP : 304  
MISRA-AC : 12.2, 12.13  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1, 5-2-10  
MISRA-C:1998 : 33, 46  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2, 12.13  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.1, R.13.2, R.13.3   Modifiers : 122 = 1
SEC-C : M3.2.2, R3.6.1, R3.6.2   Modifiers : 122 = 1
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
31 S
Use of break statement in loop.

Using a break statement in a loop is considered by some to violate the rules of structured programming, as it causes a loop to have more than one exit.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 31 S : Use of break statement in loop.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_31 (void)
{
  SINT_32 i=10 ;
 
  while (i > -1)
  {
     if (i == 0)
     {
         break; /* not compliant */
     }
     i = i - 1;
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 11.2.2  
DERA : 58  
EADS-C : 120  
FSB582-C++ : 9.9  
GJB : 4.11.2.2  
HIS : 58  
JSF++ AV : 191  
LMTCP : 342, 362  
MISRA-C:1998 : 58  
NETRINO : 1.7.e, 8.5.a  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
32 S
Use of continue statement.

The use of the continue statement is considered by some to violate the rules of structured programming.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 32 S : Use of continue statement
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_32 ( SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 i = p_1;
  SINT_32 x = 0;
 
  /* ... */ 
  while ( i != 0 )
  {
      i--;
      if ( x == 0 )
      {
          continue; /* not compliant */
      }
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.2  
CMSE : 8.2.3  
DERA : 57  
EADS-C : 119  
FSB582-C++ : 9.13  
GJB : 4.8.2.3  
HIS : 57  
JSF++ AV : 190  
LMTCP : 341  
MISRA-AC : 14.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-6-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 57  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.5  
NETRINO : 1.7.d, 8.5.a  
SEC-C : M3.1.3  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
33 S
Use of ternary operator found.

The use of these expressions can lead to highly complex code which can be unreadable. There are also often difficulties associated with the correct evaluation of the logical expression, and the termination of the final conditional expression. This standard will report any instances encountered. for example: 

		x = ( a ? b : c )  /* correct logical and condition terms*/

In this following sample, the logical term could be (a+b) or just b:

		x =  a + b ? b : c /* potential logical term error */

In this following sample, the final conditional term could be (c+6) or just c, with an addition of 6 to the result of the ternary expression:

		x = a ? b : c + 6 /* potential condition error */
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 33 S : Use of ternary expression found.
 *****************************************************/
 
void static_33( UINT_32 p_1 )
{
   UINT_32 val0 = 0u;
   UINT_32 val1 = 1u;
   UINT_32 result;
 
   result = ( p_1 == 0u ) ? val0 : val1 ; /* not compliant */
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.3  
CMSE : 8.2.4  
EADS-C : 134  
GJB : 4.8.2.4  
HIC++ : 10.20  
LMTCP : 366  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
34 S
No parameters declared in proc specification.

This standard reports when a function declaration has been specified with no parameters, but the function definition has been specified with parameters.

Standard 63 S reports on all declarations and definitions with no parameters.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 34 S : No parameters declared in proc specification.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_34();  /* not compliant */
 
UINT_32 static_34(UINT_32 p)
{
   return p;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.5  
CMSE : 1.1.6  
GJB : 4.1.1.6  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

35 S
Static procedure is not explicitly called in code analysed.

If a procedure is declared as static then it has file scope. If the procedure is not used in that file then it is not needed and could be removed.

Note that this standard detects explicit procedure calls and so will also give a warning if a procedure is only accessed via its address. In such cases the procedure may not be removed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************************
 * Standard 35 S : Static procedure is not explicitly called in code analysed.
 ****************************************************************************/ 
 
static BOOL static_35(UINT_32 p_1)  /* not compliant */
{
   BOOL ret = ( p_1 == 1U );
   return ret;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.2  
CMSE : 7.1.3  
CWE : 561  
GJB : 4.7.1.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.1  
SEC-C : M1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
36 S
Function has no return statement.

A function with a non-void return type and without a return statement will return an indeterminate value, often the top value of the stack.

Functions with a non-void return type should have a return statement or an if statement containing return statements on all branches at the end of the function. Placing the return at the end of the function improves readability and maintainability. This does not preclude additional return statements earlier in the function.

Missing return statements where there is more complicated control flow will be detected using 2 D rather than by this standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 36 S : Function has no return statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_36 ( UINT_32 p_1 )  /* not compliant */
{
   UINT_32 y = p_1;
 
   /* Not returning a value */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.1  
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CMSE : 9.1.1  
CWE : 758  
DERA : 75  
FSB582-C++ : 6.1  
GJB : 4.9.1.1  
HIC++ : 5.10  
HIS : 75  
JSF++ AV : 114  
LMTCP : 209  
MISRA-AC : 16.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-4-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 75  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.4  
SEC-C : X2.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
37 S
Procedure parameter has a type but no identifier.

It is a constraint error for function definitions to have a type and no parameter name. However, some compilers allow a parameter to have a type but no name. Such parameters cannot be used. Function declarations are permitted to have a type and no name.

This standard reports all function types where a parameter has type, but no identifier. This includes function declaration, definitions and typedefs. Guidelines vary in whether typedefs with function types should be checked, so the user will need to check their guideline documentation if they are following a specific set of guidelines.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 37 S : Procedure parameter has a type but no identifier.
 * Does not Compile with VC++
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_37 ( UINT_32 ); /* not compliant */
 
void static_37 ( UINT_32 )  /* not compliant - constraint error */
{
   ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.6  
CMSE : 1.1.7  
DERA : 73  
FSB582-C : 3.6.4  
FSB582-C++ : 6.5  
GJB : 4.1.1.7  
HIS : 73  
LMTCP : 233  
MISRA-AC : 16.3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 73  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.2  
NETRINO : 6.2.f  
SEC-C : M4.5.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
38 S
Use of static class member.

Some bodies consider the use of global variables to be bad practice. A class with a static data member is therefore also considered bad practice. Static member functions also introduce the prospect of runtime initialization errors, so their use is also considered unsafe.

This standard can be relaxed to allow non-public static members and constant static public members by setting the modifier 423 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 38 S : Use of static class member.
 ********************************************************/ 
class Counter
{
   public:
      Counter();
      ~Counter();
      static UINT_32 Count();  // not compliant
   private:
      static UINT_32 numItems; // not compliant
};
 
Counter::Counter(void)
{
   numItems++;
}
 
Counter::~Counter(void)
{
   numItems--;
}
 
UINT_32 Counter::Count(void)
{
   return numItems;
}
 
UINT_32 Counter::numItems = 0;
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 500   Modifiers : 423 = 1
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

39 S
Unsuitable type for loop variable.

The use of variables with floating-point types in the expressions of a for statement may lead to unexpected behaviour. This standard checks for the use of variables with floating-point types in the 1st and 2nd expressions of a for loop.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 39 S : Unsuitable type for loop variable
 ********************************************************/ 
void static_39( void )
{
  FLOAT_32 f = 0.0F;
 
  for (f = 0.0F; f < 10.0F; f = f + 1.0F) /* not compliant */
  {
     /* ... */ ;
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
40 S
Loop index is not declared locally.

Some authorities believe that loop indices should be declared in the smallest enclosing scope.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
INT_32 global_f = 0;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 40 S : Loop index not declared locally
 ********************************************************/
 
SINT_32 loop_standards (SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 j = 10;
 
  for (global_f = 0; global_f < 10; global_f = global_f + 1) /* not compliant */
  {
     j--;
  }
  return j;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.11.2  
CMSE : 11.1.2  
GJB : 4.11.1.2  
HIC++ : 5.12  
LMTCP : 353  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard
41 S
Ellipsis used in procedure parameter list.

An ellipsis () allows a procedure to receive a variable number of parameters, which prevents any checking activity. This is a construct which can be heavily abused.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdarg.h> 
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 41 S : Ellipsis used in procedure parameter list.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_41(UCHAR* p_1, ...) /* not compliant */
{
   va_list ap;
   UCHAR* t;
 
   va_start(ap, p_1);
   t = va_arg(ap, UCHAR*);
 
   va_end(ap);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

UML , VSOS
42 S
Use of bit field in structure declaration.

Bit fields are a source of difficulty in C because of ambiguities in the ANSI standard. The representation of the bit field is implementation defined, hence no assumptions can be made about such issues as alignment.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 42 S : Use of bit field in structure declaration.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct bitfield1 {UINT_32  x:1;};  /* not compliant */
 
void static_42(void)
{
    /* ... */
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

MISRA-C:2004 : 3.5  
SEC-C : P1.3.3  
Related standards filter models
UML
43 S
Use of setjmp/longjmp.

The use of these constructs can lead to many difficulties including lack of portability and structure.

Example
#include <setjmp.h> 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
jmp_buf env;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 43 S : Use of setjmp/longjmp.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_43 (SINT_32 val)
{
   longjmp(env,val); /* not compliant */
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates

Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
44 S
Use of banned function or variable.

In many installations there are reasons for banning the use of particular items:

procedures or functions from libraries ( malloc, calloc and realloc ),
library files,
specific names.

For example:

calloc, malloc, realloc, free, errno, offsetof, va_arg, va_start, va_end, atof, atoi, atol, getenv, system, bsearch, qsort, isalnum, qsort, isalnum, isalpha, iscntrl, islower, isprint, isupper, perror, strerror, and fmod are all banned for C by default.

setlocale is banned in C++.

To set up a ban, the c/cppvals.dat file will need specific entries for each procedure or function name, marked as type 240. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual. Users can add extra entries into this data file in the same format as the default entries:

240  11 banned_proc

abort and exit can be banned by using standard 122 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdarg.h> 
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 44 S : Use of banned function or variable.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_44( CHAR* p_1,...)
{
   va_list ap;
   CHAR* t;
 
   va_start(ap, p_1);       /* not compliant */
   t = va_arg(ap, CHAR*);   /* not compliant */
 
   va_end(ap);              /* not compliant */
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL03-C, ENV00-C, ERR01-C, ERR06-C, ERR30-C, ERR32-C, EXP38-C, FIO43-C, INT06-C, MSC30-C, POS33-C, STR03-C, STR35-C  
CMSE : 7.1.4  
CWE : 78, 187, 242, 338, 365, 475, 676  
DERA : 69, 118, 119, 120, 121, 125, 126  
EADS-C++ : 59  
FSB582-C++ : 2.3

MISRA-AC : 20.1, 20.4, 20.5, 20.6, 20.10, 20.11

MISRA-C:2004 : 20.1, 20.4, 20.5, 20.6, 20.10, 20.11  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.12, R.1.3, R.17.1, R.21.3, R.21.6, R.21.7, R.21.8, R.21.9, R.21.10, R.21.12  
SEC-C : M5.2.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
45 S
Use of C++ keyword.

This standard reports the use of C++ keywords in C files, as specified as type 241 in the cvals.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual. Users can add extra entries into this data file in the same format as the default entries:

241 9 namespace
241 5 throw
241 5 class
241 6 public
241 7 private
241 9 protected
241 8 operator
241 3 new
241 8 template
241 7 virtual
241 6 delete
241 6 friend
241 4 cout
241 3 cin
241 4 endl

Whilst these are permitted in C it precludes the code from being compiled by a C++ compiler.

For C code, the cvals.dat file must be altered.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 45 S : Use of C++ keyword.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_45(void)
{
   UINT_32 public    = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 private   = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 protected = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 operator  = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 new       = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 template  = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 virtual   = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 delete    = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 friend    = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 cout      = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 cin       = 0;  /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 endl      = 0;  /* not compliant */
   /* ... */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.8  
CMSE : 1.1.9  
GJB : 4.1.1.9  
NETRINO : 6.1.a, 7.1.a  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

46 S
extern not in nominated include file.

In some environments the use of extern is closely controlled, for instance only specified included files may contain such types. Files allowed to use the extern keyword are identified by including an entry in the data file c/cpptbend.dat. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Locate the line: 

  -1    1     Put File name for permitted extern keyword use before here

and insert any files ahead of the above, using the following structure:

   1   28 c:\mysource\extern_in_here.c
  -1    1     Put File name for permitted extern keyword use before here

where the line format is:

<3 spaces> 1 <spaces> <length of filename> <space> <filename including path>

The numbers must line up as shown in the above example.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 46 S : extern not in nominated include file.
 ********************************************************/
 
extern UINT_32 undef_global; /* not compliant */
 
void static_46(void)
{
     undef_global = 1u;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.15  
CMSE : 7.1.5  
GJB : 4.7.1.5  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
47 S
Array bound exceeded.

An index has been found which is not in the range specified for the array. This standard is enforced for local arrays that are explicitly declared or whose size can be determined from their initialisation. For example:

int a[4];
int b[] = {0, 0, 0, 0};
    .. a[5] ..
    .. b[5] ..

are detected.

The use of array manipulation via pointers, i.e. procedure parameters, are reported using 87 S. The use of global arrays or indexing via procedure calls are reported using 64 X, 68 X, 69 X and 72 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 *  Standard 47 S : Array bound exceeded.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_047(void)
{
  SINT_32 array[5] = {0,0,0,0};
 
  array[5] = 1; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.2  
CERT-C : ARR30-C, ARR35-C  
CMSE : 6.1.2  
CWE : 121, 122, 124, 126, 127, 129, 193, 466, 758, 823  
DERA : 4  
GJB : 4.6.1.2  
HIC++ : 10.2  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-16  
MISRA-C:1998 : 4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.1  
SEC-C : X3.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , VSOS
48 S
No default case in switch statement.

If a switch statement contains no default the processing continues at the next statement. Inserting a default clause implies that some thought has been given to the issue.

This standard can be relaxed to allow switch statements on enumerated types with no default statement by setting the modifier 252 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Alternatively, the standard can be relaxed to only allow no default statement if all the enumeration values are covered by setting the modifier 233 to 1. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 48 S :  No default case in switch statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_48(SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 i = 0, j = 0;
 
  switch (p_1) /* not compliant */
  {
     case 0:
        j = 0;
        break;
     case 1:
        j=i;
        break;
  }
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.3.3  
CERT-C : MSC01-C  
CMSE : 3.1.4  
CWE : 478  
DERA : 62  
EADS-C : 163  
FSB582-C : 3.9.2.3  
FSB582-C++ : 9.8, 10.2  
GJB : 4.3.1.4  
HIS : 62  
JSF++ AV : 194, 196   Modifiers : 252 = 1
LMTCP : 346  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-6  
MISRA-C:1998 : 62  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.4  
NETRINO : 8.3.b  
SEC-C : R3.5.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
49 S
Logical conjunctions need brackets.

The use of brackets to clarify the precedence order of logical conjunctions and (&&) and or (||) can help eliminate errors and improve maintainability.

This standard can be relaxed to allow function calls and array indexing without brackets by setting the modifier 206 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 49 S : Logical conjunctions need brackets.
 *****************************************************/
 
extern BOOL get_bool ( void );
 
void static_49(void)
{
   BOOL flag = TRUE;
   INT_32 y = 0, x = 0, z = 1;
 
   if (x < 0 || z + y != 0)  /* not compliant */
   {
      flag = FALSE;
   }
 
   if ( flag && get_bool() )  /* not compliant unless modifier 206 set */
   {
      flag = FALSE;
   }    
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.4  
CERT-C : EXP00-C   Modifiers : 206 = 1
CMSE : 2.1.4  
CWE : 783   Modifiers : 206 = 1
DERA : 34  
EADS-C : 98   Modifiers : 206 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 9.22   Modifiers : 206 = 1
GJB : 4.2.1.4  
HIC++ : 10.4   Modifiers : 206 = 1
HIS : 34  
JSF++ AV : 158, 213   Modifiers : 206 = 1
LMTCP : 287, 363  
MISRA-AC : 12.1, 12.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-2, 5-2-1   Modifiers : 206 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 34  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.1, 12.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.12.1   Modifiers : 206 = 1
NETRINO : 1.4.b  
SEC-C : M1.4.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
50 S
Use of shift operator on signed type.

The shifting of signed types can lead to surprising effects. The result of a shift on a negative value is implementation defined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 50 S : Use of shift operator on signed type.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_50(void)
{
   SINT_32 b = 1;
 
   b >>= 1; /* not compliant */
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.4  
CERT-C : INT13-C  
CMSE : 6.1.3  
CWE : 682  
DERA : 37  
GJB : 4.6.1.3  
HIC++ : 10.11, 10.12, 13.6  
HIS : 37  
LMTCP : 295  
MISRA-AC : 12.7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 37  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1  
NETRINO : 5.3.b  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
51 S
Shifting value too far.

Some compilers do not check that the shift operation cannot exceed the word length, effectively allowing the loss of all significance of the variable being shifted. The limits for the standard types need to be specified in the c/cpptbend.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 51 S : Shifting value too far.
 *****************************************************/
 
void static_51(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 0u;
   UINT_32 y = 2u;
 
   x = y << 34; /* not compliant */
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

LMTCP : 294  
MISRA-AC : 12.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-8-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 38  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.12.2  
SEC-C : R2.5.4  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
52 S
Unsigned expression negated.

There may be an implementation-specific implicit type conversion within the calculation, which can causing surprising results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 52 S : Unsigned expression negated.
 *****************************************************/ 
void static_52(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
   UINT_32 y = 2u;
 
   y = -x; /* not compliant */
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

SEC-C : R2.5.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
53 S
Use of comma operator.

Some authorities believe that the use of the comma operator outside of a for loop can make code more difficult to read. As this operator only returns the result of the rightmost expression, care should be taken with its use.

This standard can be further restricted to prohibit the use of the comma operator in for loops by setting the modifier 263 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 foo( UINT_32 v_1 )
{
	return (v_1+1);
}
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 53 S : Use of comma operator.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_53(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
 
   x++ , foo(x) ; /* not compliant */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.15  
CMSE : 6.2.1  
DERA : 42  
GJB : 4.6.2.1  
HIC++ : 10.19  
HIS : 42  
JSF++ AV : 168   Modifiers : 263 = 1
LMTCP : 303   Modifiers : 263 = 1
MISRA-AC : 12.10   Modifiers : 263 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-18-1   Modifiers : 263 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 42  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.10   Modifiers : 263 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.12.3   Modifiers : 263 = 1
SEC-C : M3.2.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
54 S
Sizeof operator with side effects.

The sizeof operator does not compute its operand and hence this can cause surprises if an expression is present.

For example:

in place of 

x = sizeof(y=z); /* WRONG - NO assignment takes place*/

use:

y = z;
x = sizeof(y); /* correct - returns sizeof type of y*/
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 54 S : Sizeof operator with side effects.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_54(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
   UINT_32 a = 1u;
 
   a = sizeof( x++ ); /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP06-C  
CMSE : 6.2.2  
CWE : 737  
DERA : 40  
GJB : 4.6.2.2  
HIC++ : 10.9  
HIS : 40  
JSF++ AV : 166  
LMTCP : 300  
MISRA-AC : 12.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-3-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 40  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.6  
SEC-C : X1.x  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
55 S
Expression with more than one function.

There is the possibility of side effects being different depending on the order of execution. Note that standard | 2 D reports functions which do have side effects.

Standard 1 Q is capable of more sophisticated reporting.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 55 S : Expression with more than one function.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 exp_1(UINT_32 *p_1)
{
  UINT_32 x = *p_1;
  (*p_1) = x*x;
  return (x);
}
 
UINT_32 exp_2(UINT_32 *p_1)
{
  UINT_32 x = *p_1;
  (*p_1) = (x % 2u);
  return (x);
}
 
 
void static_55(void)
{
  UINT_32 y = 3u, x = 0u;
  x = exp_1(&y) + exp_2(&y); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.3  
CMSE : 7.1.6  
DERA : 46  
GJB : 4.7.1.6  
HIS : 46  
MISRA-C:1998 : 46  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
56 S
Equality comparison of floating point.

This standard reports comparisons involving equality testing of floating point values. This includes ==, !=, >= and <=. Every float expression has an associated representational error, which cannot be resolved. It is safer to test that the difference between two float values fall below an agreed threshold value, rather than depend on some test featuring an equality comparison, where it is impossible to differentiate between numbers that are really equivalent, and those that are equivalent due to representational errors.

For example:

  	float x = 1.0f / 7.0f; 
	float y = 2.0f / 7.0f; 
	x = x * 2; 
	if ( x == y ) { ... } /* incorrect - representational errors*/ 
	if (( x -y ) < threshold ) { ... } /* correct - threshold testing*/

This standard can be relaxed to permit the use of >= and <= by setting the modifier 223 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. The user of the modifier adds extra checks for possible circumventions of this rule. This includes examples such as 

       ( ( f1 < f2 ) || ( f1 > f2 ) )
       ( ( f1 <= f2 ) && (f2 <= f1 ) )

Instructions for making alterations can be found in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 56 S : Equality comparison of floating point.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_56 ( void)
{
   FLOAT_32 fl, f2;
 
   fl = 1.01f;
   f2 = 2.01f;
 
   if (fl == f2)    /* not compliant */
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
   if (fl >= 0.0f) /* compliant when modifier 223 is set */
   {
      fl = fl + 0.01f;
   }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules

JSF++ AV : 202   Modifiers : 223 = 1
LMTCP : 358  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-2-2   Modifiers : 223 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 50  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.3   Modifiers : 223 = 1
NETRINO : 5.4.b  
SEC-C : R2.1.1   Modifiers : 223 = 1
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
57 S
Statement with no side effect.

This is a statement which changes no local or global variables and does not effect the control flow. It appears that it does not need to be present, and so is reported as a matter for investigation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 57 S : Statement with no side effect.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_57(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 0U;
 
   x;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.6  
CERT-C : MSC03-C, MSC12-C  
CMSE : 8.1.4  
CWE : 398, 482  
DERA : 53  
GJB : 4.8.2.5, 5.1.1  
HIC++ : 10.10  
HIS : 53  
JSF++ AV : 187  
LMTCP : 338  
MISRA-AC : 14.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 53  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.2  
SEC-C : M1.9.1, X1.x, X5.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
58 S
Null statement found.

The presence of a null statement may indicate that the coder has forgotten a line of code, and so the potential omission is reported as a matter for investigation. In particular null statements can be a problem if they follow a conditional test and the user believes that the following code is controlled by the test.

If a null statement is intended, the penalty may be suppressed by the addition of a comment /* . */

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 58 S : Null statement found.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_58(void)
{
   UINT_32 Timing_Loop = 100U;
 
   /* not compliant - decrement is not part of loop */
   while ( Timing_Loop > 0U ); 
        Timing_Loop--;
 
  ; 
  /* compliant as followed by comment */
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.4  
CERT-C : MSC03-C  
CMSE : 8.2.5  
CWE : 747  
DERA : 54  
GJB : 4.8.2.6  
HIS : 54  
LMTCP : 91  
MISRA-AC : 14.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-2-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 54  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.3  
SEC-C : M1.9.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
59 S
Else alternative missing in if.

This is the complement of 8 S where a dummy entry is deliberately inserted to show that the alternative has been considered.

This standard can be further restricted to check for a missing else in an if statement with no else if by setting the tbend modifier to T in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 59 S : Else alternative missing in if.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_59 (void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 2u;
 
   if ( x == 2u )
   {
      /* ... */ ;
   }
   else if ( x == 3u)
   {
      /* ... */ ;
   } 
   /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

60 S
Empty switch statement.

This is the case of a switch statement with no internal processing. It is reported as a matter for investigation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/********************************************************
 * Standard 60 S :  Empty switch statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_060(SINT_32 p_1)
{
  switch (p_1)
  {
  } /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 3.1.5  
DERA : 64  
GJB : 4.3.1.5  
HIS : 64  
JSF++ AV : 196  
MISRA-AC : 15.0  
MISRA-C:1998 : 64  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.0  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.6  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
61 S
Switch contains default only.

A switch statement which has only a default clause is redundant and may indicate a programming error.

This standard can be further restricted to check for switch statements that have only a single path containing null case labels and a default by setting the modifier 437 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/********************************************************
 * Standard 61 S :  Switch contains default only.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_061(SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 i = p_1;
 
  switch (p_1)
  {
    default:
        i++;
  } /* not compliant */
 
  switch (p_1)
  {
    case 1:
    default:
        i++;
  } /* not compliant if modifier is set to 1  */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 3.1.6  
DERA : 64  
GJB : 4.3.1.6  
HIS : 64  
JSF++ AV : 196  
LMTCP : 348  
MISRA-AC : 15.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-8  
MISRA-C:1998 : 64  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.6  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
62 S
Switch case not terminated with break.

One major source of errors in switch statements is the fall through from one case to another, which is only preventable with the break statement or other transfer of control. This standard ensures that only one case can ever be accessed within the switch.

In order to clarify the structure of the switch, this standard checks that the default statement appears as the last statement of each case and default clause. It may not appear within an if statement.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the default statement to have no break statement by setting the modifier 283 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. The standard can also be relaxed to allow a throw statement instead of a break statement at the end of a case clause by setting the modifier 384 to 1. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 62 S :  Switch case not terminated with break.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_62(SINT_32 p_1)
{
  SINT_32 i = 0, j = 0;
 
  switch (p_1)
  {
     case 0:
        j = 0;   /* not compliant*/
     case 1:
        j = i;
        break;
     default:
        i = j + 1; /* not compliant unless modifier 283 set to 1 */
  }
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.3.6  
CMSE : 3.1.7  
CWE : 484  
DERA : 61  
EADS-C : 164  
FSB582-C : 3.9.2.1  
FSB582-C++ : 9.7  
GJB : 4.3.1.7  
HIC++ : 5.4  
HIS : 61  
JSF++ AV : 193   Modifiers : 283 = 1
LMTCP : 345, 348  
MISRA-AC : 15.2, 15.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-5   Modifiers : 384 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 61  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.2, 15.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.3  
SEC-C : M3.1.4  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
63 S
Empty parameter list to procedure/function.

This standard advocates the use of func(void) rather than func(). This indicates that the lack of parameters is intentional, rather than accidental.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 63 S :  Empty Parameter List to procedure/function
 **************************************************************/ 
 
void static_63() /* not compliant */
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules

DERA : 76

FSB582-C++ : 6.2

MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.2

Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
64 S
Void procedure used in expression.

A procedure which yields a void value can be used in expressions and this is considered dangerous. This is compiler dependent, but is usually seen within a ternary expression.

This standard also applies to procedures that yield a void* value. This standard can be relaxed to allow void* by configuring the modifier 218 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
void foo(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 64 S : Void procedure used in expression.
 * Code Does Not Compile under VC++
 *****************************************************/ 
void static_64(void)
{
   CHAR x;
 
   x = (CHAR) foo();  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.4   Modifiers : 218 = 1
CERT-C : MSC15-C   Modifiers : 218 = 1
CMSE : 7.1.7   Modifiers : 218 = 1
CWE : 758   Modifiers : 218 = 1
DERA : 79   Modifiers : 218 = 1
GJB : 4.7.1.7   Modifiers : 218 = 1
HIS : 79   Modifiers : 218 = 1
MISRA-AC : 1.2   Modifiers : 218 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 79   Modifiers : 218 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2   Modifiers : 218 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3   Modifiers : 218 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , VSOS
65 S
Void variable passed as parameter.

Passing void as a parameter can lead to surprising effects and should therefore be avoided.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void void_para_func(void P1)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 65 S : Void variable passed as parameter.
 * Does not Compile with VC++
 ******************************************************************/
 
void static_65( void )
{
  void v_ptr;
  UINT_32 a;
 
  void_para_func(v_ptr);   /* not compliant */
 
  void_para_func((void)a); /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CMSE : 7.1.8  
CWE : 758  
DERA : 80  
GJB : 4.7.1.8  
HIS : 80  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 80  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , VSOS
66 S
Function with empty return expression.

There is a return in a function but no value is specified so the function will return an indeterminate value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 66 S : Function with empty return expression.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_66 ( void )
{
   /* ... */
   return;  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.3  
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CMSE : 9.1.3

JSF++ AV : 114

MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-4-3

MISRA-C:2004 : 16.8

SEC-C : X2.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
67 S
#define used in a block.

Macro definitions can obscure readability and in particular those defined in inner blocks are considered dangerous because the block scope is not relevant.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <string.h>
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 67 S : #define used in a block.
 *******************************************************/ 
void static_067(UINT_32 p_1)
{
  UINT_32 local_x = 0;
 
#define BLOCKDEF "test"
  local_x = strlen(BLOCKDEF);
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 1.2.5  
DERA : 91  
GJB : 4.1.2.5  
HIS : 91  
MISRA-AC : 19.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-0-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 91  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.5  
SEC-C : M4.7.5  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
68 S
#undef used.

Redefining macros leads to unreadability and is considered bad practice. This standard reports all instances encountered at file scope, and 426 S reports those at block level.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <string.h>
 
#define BLOCKDEF "test"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 68 S : #undef used.
 *******************************************************/ 
void static_68(void)
{
  UINT_32 local_x = 0U;
 
  local_x = strlen(BLOCKDEF);
 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/* not compliant */
#undef BLOCKDEF
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 1.2.6  
DERA : 92  
GJB : 4.1.2.6  
LMTCP : 32, 92  
MISRA-AC : 19.6, 20.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-0-3, 17-0-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 92  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.6, 20.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.2, M4.7.6  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
69 S
#pragma used.

Compiler pragmas can be used to cover up all sorts of problems; therefore their use needs to be controlled.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 69 S : #pragma used.
 *******************************************************/ 
#pragma
 
static void static_69(void)
{
  ; /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 1.2.7  
DERA : 99  
GJB : 4.1.2.7  
HIC++ : 13.4  
HIS : 99  
JSF++ AV : 26  
LMTCP : 247  
MISRA-AC : 3.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-6-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 99  
MISRA-C:2004 : 3.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.1.1  
NETRINO : 1.1.c  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
70 S
Logical comparison of pointers.

The only safe, portable comparison of pointers is to use equality comparisons ( == and != ). This standard reports any other comparisons.

For example:

	char * x;
	char * y;
	....
	if (x>y)		{ /*  Incorrect, Unsafe*/ }
	if (x!=y)		{ /*  Correct usage*/ }
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 70 S : Logical comparison of pointers.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_70(UINT_32 * p1_ptr, UINT_32 * p2_ptr )
{
   if ( p1_ptr > p2_ptr ) /* not compliant */
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.4.4  
CMSE : 4.2.1  
DERA : 103  
GJB : 4.4.2.1  
HIS : 103  
JSF++ AV : 171  
LMTCP : 315  
MISRA-C:1998 : 103  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
71 S
Pointer assignment to wider scope.

This standard checks whether the address of an object is assigned to a wider scope. Accessing an object outside its scope will lead to undefined behaviour.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the use of the address of a static object in a return statement by setting the modifier 222 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

In general, it is not possible to determine statically whether a pointer contains the address of an object that has lifetime greater than the current scope. Therefore, Testbed also highlights the assignment of all pointers to a wider scope. The user can configure the tool to allow functions that return such pointers. For example, for data that is created using malloc. These functions are identified by including an entry in the data file c/cpptbend.dat. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Locate the line in the .dat file: 

C list of allocator functions  RDALLC

and add the function names after it:

   15 malloc_function

where the line format is: ( <spaces>, <length of function name>, <space>, <name of function> ). The function name length should line up with the preceding lines.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 71 S : Pointer assignment to wider scope.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 *ptr;
 
UINT_32* static_71( void )
{
   static UINT_32 w = 10u;
   UINT_32 local = 3U;
   UINT_32 *local_ptr = &local;
 
   ptr = &local;     /* Not Compliant */
 
   ptr = local_ptr;  /* Not Compliant */
 
   return &w;       /* Not Compliant if modifier is set to 0 */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.4.1  
CERT-C : DCL30-C, MEM36-C   Modifiers : 222 = 1
CMSE : 4.1.1, 9.1.6

DERA : 106   Modifiers : 222 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 4.11   Modifiers : 222 = 1

MISRA-C:2004 : 17.6   Modifiers : 222 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.6   Modifiers : 222 = 1
SEC-C : X3.x   Modifiers : 222 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
72 S
Signed bit field less than 2 bits wide.

A signed bit field requires 1 bit for the sign, and at least 1 bit for the value.

This standard can be relaxed to allow anonymous bit fields by setting the modifier 416 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 72 S : Signed bit field less than 2 bits wide.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct s_72 {SINT_32 x:1; }; /* not compliant */
 
void static_72( void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

73 S
Bit field not signed or unsigned int.

The definition of bit fields make their use for other types dangerous.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 73 S : Bit field not signed or unsigned int.
 ********************************************************/ 
struct static_73 
{ UCHAR  x:1;  /* Not Compliant */
};
 
void dummy(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}

74 S
Union declared.

Unions can be dangerous when the extent of the overlay cannot be certain. Word boundaries are implementation specific.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 74 S : Union declared.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
union s_74{UCHAR fu; UINT_32 xu;}; /* not compliant */
 
void static_74(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}

75 S
Executable code before an included file.

In an attempt to enforce a clear design, some authorities believe that included files should only occur at the beginning of a file before any executable code. This standard reports any instances of include files after executable code.

Example
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 75 S : Executable code before an included file.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_75(void)  /* not compliant */
{
#include "c_standards.h"
 
   /* ... */ 
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

NETRINO : 4.3.b

VSOS
76 S
More than one of # or ## in a macro.

Due to poor definition in the language it is dangerous to use more than one of these operators or indeed both in the same macro.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard  76 S : More than one of # or ## in a macro.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void dummy(CHAR *p_1, CHAR *p_2)
{
   /* ... */
}
 
/* not compliant */
#define SetVariable( Variable, Value ) ( dummy(NewString##Variable, #Value ))
 
 
void static_76(void)
{
  CHAR NewString1[128];
  INT_32 value = 10;
 
  SetVariable(1, value );
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
