CONFORM , Legacy , UML , VSOS
77 S
Macro replacement list needs parentheses.

Some authorities believe that the body of a macro should be enclosed in brackets. This can help prevent problems with precedence order when the macro is expanded.

The following object-like macro definitions do not require parenthesis: Identifiers, struct selectors, casts and function calls.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define increment_NOK(a)    ( a ) + 1
 
#define increment_OK(b)   ( ( b ) + 1 )
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 77 S : Macro replacement list needs parentheses.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_77(void)
{
   INT_32 result = 1;
   result = increment_NOK(result) * 3; /* result = 4 */
 
   result = 1;
   result = increment_OK(result) * 3;  /* result = 6 */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.14  
CERT-C : PRE02-C  
CMSE : 1.1.12  
CWE : 735  
DERA : 96  
EADS-C : 92  
FSB582-C : 3.11.5  
GJB : 4.1.1.12  
HIC++ : 14.14  
HIS : 96  
JSF++ AV : 29  
LMTCP : 35  
MISRA-AC : 19.4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 96  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.4  
NETRINO : 6.3.b  
SEC-C : M4.7.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
78 S
Macro parameter not in brackets.

Some authorities believe that the use of parameters in the macro body should be enclosed in brackets.

For example:

	#define abs(x) (((x) >= 0) ? (x) : -(x)) /* Compliant */ 
	#define abs(x) x >= 0 ? x : -x           /* Not compliant */

In the incorrect second sample, the problem manifests itself when the following call is made

	z=abs(a-b)

which becomes:

	z= a - b >= 0 ? a - b : -a - b;

where the last expression -a - b is equivalent to (-a) - b and not - (a - b), as expected.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 78 S : Macro parameters not in brackets
 ********************************************************/ 
 
/* not compliant */
#define multiply(a1, a2) ((al)*a2)
 
static void static_78(void)
{
   SINT_32 test;
   SINT_32 p1 = 2;
   SINT_32 p2 = 5;
 
   test = ( multiply(100,p1) );
   test = ( multiply(100,p1-p2) );
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.5  
CERT-C : PRE01-C  
CMSE : 2.1.6  
CWE : 735  
DERA : 96  
EADS-C : 92  
FSB582-C : 3.11.5  
GJB : 4.2.1.6  
HIC++ : 14.14  
HIS : 96  
MISRA-AC : 19.10  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-0-6  
MISRA-C:1998 : 96  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.10  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.7  
NETRINO : 6.3.b  
SEC-C : M4.7.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
79 S
Macro contains unacceptable items.

Some authorities believe that macros should only be used for constant literals, function-like macros, type qualifiers and storage class specifiers. Statement keywords and type keywords are not permitted.

This standard permits the use of integer constant expressions including casts on constants. This standard can be further restricted to prohibit the use of >> and << in macro definitions by setting the modifier 298 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/* not compliant */
#define t void
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 79 S : Macro contains unacceptable items.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
t static_79(t)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

VSOS
80 S
Pointer indirection exceeds 2 levels.

The use of pointers is difficult to control, so levels of indirection greater than two are considered very dangerous. Pointers to pointers are acceptable.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 80 S : Pointer indirection exceeds 2 levels.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_80(void)
{
   UINT_32 array[10] = {0};
   UINT_32 * p1_ptr, **p2_ptr;
   UINT_32 *** p3_ptr;        /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 w;
 
   p1_ptr = array;
   p2_ptr = &p1_ptr;
   p3_ptr = &p2_ptr;
 
   w = ***p3_ptr;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.4.2  
CMSE : 4.1.2  
DERA : 102  
GJB : 4.4.1.2  
HIS : 102  
JPL : 9  
JSF++ AV : 169, 170  
LMTCP : 313, 314  
MISRA-AC : 17.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-19  
MISRA-C:1998 : 102  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.5  
SEC-C : M3.4.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
81 S
Use of trigraph.

C as a language was designed using the standard English character set and requires #[\]^{|}~ characters. Certain platforms or regions do not feature these required characters or symbols, and so trigraphs are allowed to represent these missing characters. Some authorities believe that the use of trigraphs is dangerous, so this standard reports any trigraph detected.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 81 S : Use of trigraph.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_81(void)
??<   /* not compliant */
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : PRE07-C  
CMSE : 8.1.2  
CWE : 735

MISRA-C:2012 : R.4.2  
SEC-C : M1.8.4  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
82 S
Use of wide string literal.

Some authorities believe that the use of wide string literals is dangerous.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 82 S : Use of wide string literal.
 *******************************************************/
 
void static_82(void)
{
   wchar_t WideChar = L'1'; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 8  
HIS : 8  
JSF++ AV : 13  
MISRA-C:1998 : 8  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
83 S
Octal number found.

Since octal numbers, which start with a leading zero, can be confused for decimal numbers with a leading zero they are considered to be dangerous.

For Example: 

	code[1] = 109   /* set to decimal 109 */ 
	code[2] = 100   /* set to decimal 100 */ 
	code[3] = 052   /* incorrect - set to decimal 42 */ 
	code[4] = 071   /* incorrect - set to decimal 57 */
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 83 S : Octal number found.
 *******************************************************/ 
void static_83(void)
{
   UINT_32 i;
 
   i = (UINT_32) 076;
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 * This penalty is reported as follows:
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.5  
CMSE : 8.1.3  
DERA : 19  
GJB : 4.8.1.3  
HIS : 19  
JSF++ AV : 149  
LMTCP : 270  
MISRA-AC : 7.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-13-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 19  
MISRA-C:2004 : 7.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.7.1  
SEC-C : M1.8.5  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
84 S
Register variable declared.

The register storage-class specifier is a request, not an imperative, to the compiler to allocate the fastest possible access mechanism for the object specified. Its use also places restrictions upon the use of the variable or object specified. It is not possible, for example, to compute the address of any register variable, regardless of what decisions the compiler made.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 84 S : Register variable declared.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_84(void)
{
   register SINT_32 ri = 0; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.8.7  
CMSE : 8.2.6  
DERA : 28  
GJB : 4.8.2.7  
HIC++ : 8.3.3  
JSF++ AV : 140  
LMTCP : 255  
MISRA-C:1998 : 28  
NETRINO : 1.7.b  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
85 S
Incomplete initialisation of enumerator.

Enumerator types can be explicitly initialised, but only two forms of initialisation are safe. One is to initialise all the entries and the other is to initialise only the first. An enum without initialisation is safe.

This standard can be further restricted to prohibit enums with no explicit initialisation by setting the modifier 377 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

For Example: 

   enum (x,y,z)	       /*GOOD (unless type 377 is set) - no explicit initialisation*/ 
   enum (x=1,y,z)      /*GOOD - first value only*/ 
   enum (x=2,y=3,z=4)  /*GOOD - all values set*/ 
   enum (x,y,z=1)      /*BAD*/
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 85 S : Incomplete initialisation of enumerator.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_85(void)
{
   enum E_type { num1, num2 = 2, num3};
 
   /* ... */ 
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.13.1  
CERT-C : INT09-C  
CMSE : 13.1.1  
DERA : 32  
EADS-C : 81  
EADS-C++ : 55  
GJB : 4.13.1.1  
HIS : 32  
JSF++ AV : 145  
LMTCP : 260  
MISRA-AC : 9.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-5-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 32  
MISRA-C:2004 : 9.3  
SEC-C : R1.2.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
86 S
Attempt to define reserved word.

The macro pre-processor can redefine reserved words which can lead to confusion. This includes redefining an object-like macro as:

  • the keywords of a language
  • the keyword extensions to a language
  • the types and macros in included standard library files

The list of language keywords can be found in section 10 Alphabetic keywords of the c/cppvals.dat file. The type and macros for the standard library files can be found in section 11 macro names of the same file.

Further checks on defining function-like macro as reserved words can be found as part of the standards 580 S and 626 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 86 S : Attempt to define reserved word.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#define FILE UINT_32  /* not compliant */
 
void static_86(void)
{
   /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.16  
CERT-C : ERR31-C  
CMSE : 1.1.14  
CWE : 746  
DERA : 114  
FSB582-C : 3.11.6  
GJB : 4.1.1.14  
HIS : 114  
LMTCP : 92  
MISRA-AC : 20.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 17-0-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 114  
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.4, R.21.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
87 S
Use of pointer arithmetic.

Performing arithmetic on pointers is considered to be an unsafe activity since there is no guarantee that the result is a valid address.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 87 S : Use of pointer arithmetic.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_87(void)
{
   UINT_32 w;
   UINT_32 array[5];
   UINT_32 * p1_ptr;
 
   p1_ptr = array;
   w = *(p1_ptr + 8);  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.4.5  
CMSE : 4.2.2  
DERA : 101, 104  
GJB : 4.4.2.2  
HIS : 101, 104  
JSF++ AV : 215  
LMTCP : 315, 400  
MISRA-C:1998 : 101, 104  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.4  
SEC-C : R1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML , VSOS
88 S
Procedure is not pure assembler.

This standard is designed to ensure that all code inserts are pure procedures with a defined interface.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 88 S : Procedure is not pure assembler.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_88(void)
{
   UINT_32 x;
   x=0;
 
   _asm
   {
      mov eax,x
   }
 
}  /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.2.6  
CMSE : 2.1.7  
DERA : 3  
GJB : 4.2.1.7  
HIC++ : 13.5  
LMTCP : 17  
MISRA-AC : 2.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-4-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 2.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.3  
NETRINO : 1.1.c  
SEC-C : P2.1.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
89 S
char type not signed or unsigned.

The plain char type can be implemented as either a signed or unsigned type. Some authorities ban the use of the plain char type.

This standard restricts the use of plain char. Plain char types may not be used in the declaration or definition of functions or objects. An exception is made where an object is initialised with a plain char literal or a typedef of a plain char is used.

Some authorities allow the declaration of plain char objects, but restrict their use to the storage and use of character values. If this behaviour is required, this standard may be switched off and replaced by 329 S, 432 S and 433 S.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 89 S : char type not signed or unsigned
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void use_char ( char notok ) /* not compliant */
{ ; }
 
void static_89 ( void ) 
{
   char num = 42;   /* not compliant */
   /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.10  
CMSE : 1.1.15  
DERA : 14  
GJB : 4.1.1.15  
HIS : 14  
MISRA-C:1998 : 14  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
90 S
Basic type declaration used.

This is designed to make code portable between compilers where the sizes of the basic types can vary dramatically. Therefore the use of the basic types is banned except in typedefs. An example of a number of definitions follow: 

	typedef char						CHAR;
	typedef unsigned char					UCHAR;
	typedef unsigned short					UINT_16;
	typedef unsigned int					UINT_32;
	typedef signed char					SCHAR;
	typedef signed short					SINT_16;
	typedef signed int					SINT_32;
	typedef float						FLOAT_32;
	typedef double						FLOAT_64;
	typedef enum { FALSE = 0, TRUE  = 1}			BOOL;

This standard can be relaxed to allow the plain char basic type to be used by setting the modifier 219 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 90 S : Basic type declaration used.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
unsigned int static_90 (void)
{
  char           ch;
  unsigned char  uc;
  unsigned int   ui_32;
  unsigned short ui_16;
  int            i_32;
  float          f_32;
  double         f_64;
  signed char    sc;
 
  /* ... */ 
  return ui_32;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.19  
DERA : 13  
EADS-C : 84  
FSB582-C : 3.8.2  
FSB582-C++ : 1.10  
GJB : 4.1.2.1  
HIC++ : 8.4.6, 13.6  
HIS : 13  
JSF++ AV : 209   Modifiers : 219 = 1
LMTCP : 393   Modifiers : 219 = 1
MISRA-AC : 6.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-9-2

MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.6   Modifiers : 219 = 1
NETRINO : 5.2.a  
SEC-C : P2.1.3  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
91 S
Name redeclared in another C name space (MR).

The C language allows the same names to be used in many different contexts (blocks and name spaces), which is unsafe, as it may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. This standard increases readability by enforcing unique names. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 91 S : Name redeclared in another C name space.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct s_91
{
  UINT_32 s_91;  /* not compliant */
  UINT_32 u_1;
};
 
 
UINT_32 static_91 (void)
{
   UINT_32 var_1;
 
static_91:      /* not compliant */
   var_1 = 1;
   return (var_1);
}
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.11  
CMSE : 1.1.16  
DERA : 12  
EADS-C : 53  
GJB : 4.1.1.16  
MISRA-AC : 5.2, 5.6, 5.7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 12  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2, 5.6, 5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
TBrun Requires , UML , VSOS
92 S
Duplicate use of a name in an enumeration.

Languages may permit the use of the same name in different contexts (e.g. blocks and namespaces). This is unsafe as it may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. This standard reports where a field in an enumeration is the same as another name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 duplicate = 0;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 92 S : Duplicate use of a name in an enumeration.
 ********************************************************/ 
void static_92 (void)
{
   enum Name_type { e1, duplicate } EnumVar;
 
   EnumVar = e1;
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.15.1  
CMSE : 15.1.1  
DERA : 12  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
GJB : 4.15.1.1  
LMTCP : 248  
MISRA-AC : 5.2, 5.7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 12  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2, 5.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.3  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
93 S
Value is not of appropriate type.

Testbed enforces strict type checking by the use of this standard combined with 96 S, 101 S, 104 S, 107 S, 330 S, 331 S, 411 S, 431 S, 432 S, 433 S, 435 S, 445 S, 446 S, 458 S and 488 S.

In addition, Testbed highlights the use of casts by the use of this standard combined with 332 S, 333 S, 441 S, 442 S, 443 S, 444 S, 451 S and 452 S.

This standard includes a check that array indexing is performed using unsigned integers. The array indexing check is switched off when using the MISRA-C:2004 model, but can be enabled by setting the modifier 372 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 93 S : Value is not of appropriate type.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void STATIC_93(void)
{
   FLOAT_32 fl;
 
   fl = 2.0; /* not compliant - Requires explicit assignment of 2.0F */ 
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.16  
CERT-C : INT01-C, INT02-C, INT07-C, INT31-C, STR04-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CMSE : 6.1.8  
CWE : 192, 197, 758   Modifiers : 191 = 1
DERA : 18, 48  
GJB : 4.6.1.8

MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1, R.10.3, R.10.4, R.10.5, R.11.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
NETRINO : 5.2.c, 5.3.c, 5.4.b   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : M1.2.2, P1.3.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , UML , VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

94 S
Casting operation on a pointer.

Casting pointers to other types can be dangerous. 439 S covers the casting of a pointer to an integral type 635 S covers the casting of a pointer to a float type. .

This standard can be relaxed to allow casts between pointers to the same object type by setting the modifier 396 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. The standard may also be relaxed to allow casts to void by setting the modifier 439 to 1 and to allow casts to char * by setting the modifier 440 to 1. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
extern UINT_32 * get_ptr( void );
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 94 S : Casting operation on a pointer.
 ********************************************************/
 
static void static_94(UINT_32 * p1_ptr)
{
   FLOAT_32 v_1;
   UINT_32 *ptr2;
   CHAR * ptr_ch;
 
   v_1 = (FLOAT_32) p1_ptr;    /* not compliant */
 
   ptr2 = (UINT_32 *) p1_ptr;  /* not compliant, but permitted with modifier 396 */
 
   (void) get_ptr();           /* not compliant, but permitted with modifier 439 */
 
   ptr_ch = (CHAR *) p1_ptr;   /* not compliant, but permitted with modifier 440 */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP11-C, EXP36-C   Modifiers : 439 = 1, 396 = 1
CMSE : 12.1.1  
CWE : 737   Modifiers : 439 = 1
DERA : 45  
EADS-C++ : 15, 16   Modifiers : 396 = 1
GJB : 4.12.1.1  
HIC++ : 7.5, 7.7, 13.7  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182  
LMTCP : 328  
MISRA-AC : 11.1, 11.2, 11.4   Modifiers : 396 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-7   Modifiers : 396 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.1, 11.2, 11.4   Modifiers : 396 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.1, R.11.2, R.11.3, R.11.7   Modifiers : 439 = 1, 396 = 1
SEC-C : R2.7.1   Modifiers : 396 = 1, 439 = 1
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML , VSOS
95 S
Casting operation to a pointer.

Generating a pointer other than by taking an address is considered dangerous. Note: 440 S covers casting from an integral type to a pointer and 636 S covers casting from a float type to a pointer.

This standard can be relaxed to allow casts from void* by setting the modifier 381 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file, and relaxed to allow casts between pointers to the same object type by setting the modifier 396 to 1. The standard may also be relaxed to allow casts to char * by setting the modifier 440 to 1. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/********************************************************
 * Standard 95 S : Casting operation to a pointer.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct Astruct { UINT_32 a; };
 
void static_95 (UINT_32 *intptr)
{
  struct Astruct *Astructptr;
  Astructptr = (struct Astruct *) intptr; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.12.1

CMSE : 12.2.1  
CWE : 737

EADS-C++ : 28  
GJB : 4.12.2.1  
HIC++ : 7.5  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182   Modifiers : 381 = 1
LMTCP : 328, 331  
MISRA-AC : 11.1, 11.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.1, 11.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.1, R.11.2, R.11.3, R.11.5, R.11.7   Modifiers : 440 = 1
SEC-C : R2.7.1   Modifiers : 381 = 1
Related standards filter models
Standard , TBrun Requires , UML , VSOS
96 S
Use of mixed mode arithmetic.

In general the programmer should show that they appreciate that they are using mixed mode arithmetic by using explicit casts. This is one of a range of standards that together detect mixed mode arithmetic.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 96 S : Use of mixed mode arithmetic.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_96(void)
{
  INT_32 i32 = 10;
  FLOAT_64 f64 = 20.5;
  FLOAT_32 f32 = 2.0F;
 
  f64 = i32 + f64;  /* not compliant */
  f64 = f64 * f32;  /* compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules

JSF++ AV : 162, 180, 184   Modifiers : 267 = 1
LMTCP : 292, 325, 398   Modifiers : 267 = 1
MISRA-AC : 6.2, 10.1, 10.2, 12.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 43, 48   Modifiers : 267 = 1

Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
97 S
Use of redundant cast.

Explicit casting between the same type is unnecessary and may make the code less readable. Types declared using the typedef specifier are considered to have the same type as their underlying basic type.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 97 S : Use of redundant cast.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_97(void)
{
   SINT_32 sx,sy = -10;
 
   sx = (SINT_32) sy + 1; /* not compliant */
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 12.2.2  
DERA : 44, 48  
GJB : 4.12.2.2  
HIS : 48  
JSF++ AV : 181  
LMTCP : 327  
MISRA-C:1998 : 44, 48  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML , VSOS
98 S
Actual and formal parameters inconsistent (MR).

The formal parameters are those derived from either the definition or the prototype, whereas the actual parameters are those that are present in the call to the procedure. This standard provides rigorous type checking across procedure boundaries.

The actual and formal parameters must be compatible, but not necessarily identical. The rules regarding compatibility are restrictive and do not extend to distinct types deemed safe for conversion, e.g. between pointer to void and some other pointer type. Examples of compatible type pairs are:

signed int, int
unsigned short int, unsigned short

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void fn( UINT_16 p_1, UINT_16 p_2 )
{
  ; /* ... */ 
}
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 98 S : Actual and formal parameters inconsistent.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_98(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2)
{
   fn(p_1, p_2); /* not compliant */ 
}
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.7.6  
CERT-C : EXP37-C  
CMSE : 7.1.9  
CWE : 685  
DERA : 105  
GJB : 4.7.1.9  
HIS : 105  
MISRA-C:1998 : 105  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

99 S
Function use is not a call.

It is possible to use a procedure identifier in expressions which do not lead either to a call or an assignment of the address of the function.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
BOOL test_99(void)
{
   BOOL retval= TRUE;
   /* ... */ 
   return retval;
}
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 99 S : Function use is not a call.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_99(void)
{
   if ( test_99 ) /* not compliant */
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

100 S
#include filename is non conformant.

This standard bans the use of the characters ' \ and the character combination /* in include file names. For users of the PC the \ is essential so the characters ' and \ are configurable using the modifier 120 in the c/cppvals.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 100 S : #include filename is non conformant.
 *****************************************************/ 
#include <\ctype.h> 
 
static void static_100(void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules

SEC-C : P1.4.1, P1.4.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , UML , VSOS
101 S
Function return type inconsistent.

LDRA Testbed enforces strong type checking. This standard reports when the type returned by a return statement is not consistent with the function declaration.

It is possible to switch off the check for the return statement of main by setting the modifier 374 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 101 S : Function return type inconsistent.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_101( UINT_32 par_1)
{
    switch (par_1)
    {
       case 0:
          return (-1);     /* not compliant */
          break;
       case 1:
          return (1U);
          break;
       case 2:
          return (1L);    /* not compliant */
          break;
       case 3:
          return (1.0f);  /* not compliant */
          break;
       default:
          break;
    }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.4  
CERT-C : INT02-C, INT07-C, STR04-C  
CMSE : 9.1.4  
CWE : 192, 197  
DERA : 83  
GJB : 4.9.1.4  
HIC++ : 5.10  
HIS : 83  
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-4, 5-0-5, 5-0-6  
MISRA-C:1998 : 83  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
NETRINO : 5.3.c, 5.4.b  
SEC-C : R2.5.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
102 S
Function and prototype return inconsistent (MR).

There is a difference between the function prototype and definition return types. This continues the theme of rigorous type checking across procedure boundaries. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 static_102(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2);
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 102 S : Function and prototype return inconsistent.
 **************************************************************/
 
SINT_32 static_102(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_16 p_2) /* not compliant */
{
   SINT_32 result = 0;
   /* ... */ 
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.5

103 S
Function and prototype param inconsistent (MR).

There is a difference between the function prototype and definition parameter types. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
BOOL static_103(FLOAT_32 up_1);
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 103 S : Function and prototype param inconsistent.
 ***************************************************************/ 
BOOL static_103(UINT_32 up_1)
{
   BOOL ret = FALSE;
   /* ... */ 
   return ret;
}

104 S
Struct field initialisation incorrect.

Consistent with strong typing there is an inconsistency between a structure definition and its initialisation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct s_type_a { SINT_32 xs; FLOAT_32 fs;};
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 104 S : Struct field initialisation incorrect.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_104(void)
{
   struct s_type_a sta = {3.14F, 0.0f}; /* not compliant */
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
105 S
Initialisation brace { } fault.

Brace faults are generated if the initialisation does not contain the same brace structure as the nesting of the definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct pixel{ UINT_32 colour; struct {UINT_32 x, y;} coords; };
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 105 S : Struct field initialisation brace fault.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void static_105(void)
{
   UINT_32 xs = 0;
   UINT_32 ys = 0;
 
   struct pixel spot = {1u, xs, ys }; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.13.3

LMTCP : 259

SEC-C : M2.1.1, R1.2.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
106 S
Volatile declaration.

The value of volatile variables can change outside of the control of the application. This standard allows all such declarations to be monitored. The cross reference report gives all the uses of variables identified by this standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 106 S : Volatile declaration.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_106(void)
{
   volatile UINT_32 v = 1U; /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 x = 0;
 
   x = v;
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 205  
LMTCP : 364  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
107 S
Type mismatch in ternary expression.

This standard performs strong type checking for the two alternatives of a ternary expression.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 107 S : Type Mismatch in ternary Expression.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_107( BOOL flag )
{
   UINT_32  x = 0U;
   FLOAT_32 f = 0.0F;
 
   x = (flag ? f : x);
 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C  
CMSE : 6.2.3, 12.2.3  
CWE : 192  
DERA : 144

HIS : 48  
JSF++ AV : 162, 180  
LMTCP : 82, 292, 325, 398  
MISRA-AC : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-4, 5-0-5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 48  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.4  
NETRINO : 5.3.c  
SEC-C : P1.3.1, R2.3.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard
109 S
Array subscript is not integral.

All array indices should be positive whole numbers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define ArraySize 3.0F
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 109 S : Array subscript is not integral.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_109(void)
{
   UINT_32 fl_arr[ (UINT_32) ArraySize ] = {0,1,2};  /* not compliant */
}

 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

DERA : 165  
GJB : 4.6.1.10  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
110 S
Use of single line comment //.

The single line comment is not available in all compilers and should not be used.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 110 S : Use of single line comment
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_110(void)
{
// This is a single line comment
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 10.2.2  
DERA : 1  
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
GJB : 4.10.2.2  
HIS : 1  
MISRA-AC : 2.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 2.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.2  
SEC-C : P1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

111 S
Label is not part of switch statement (MR).

The only use of labels which can be said to be safe is in a switch statement. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 111 S : Label is not part of switch statement.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_111(void)
{
   SINT_32 jump_flag = 0;
 
start:  /* not compliant */
 
   jump_flag++;
   if (jump_flag < 10)
   {
      goto start;
   }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 55  
HIS : 55  
JSF++ AV : 188  
LMTCP : 339  
MISRA-C:1998 : 55  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
112 S
Typedef name redeclared.

Changing the type of a user-defined type is at best confusing and at worse dangerous. This standard highlights the use of typedef names which are used else-where as a typedef or a tag name.

This standard can be relaxed to allow a typedef with the same tag name by setting the modifier 417 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef SINT_32 mytype;
 
typedef struct st1 { SINT_32 a; SINT_32 b; } st1; /* compliant when modifier 417 is set  */
 
/*******************************************
 * Standard 112 S : Typedef name redeclared.
 ********************************************/
 
void static_112(void)
{
   typedef FLOAT_32 mytype; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.12  
CMSE : 1.1.17  
DERA : 17  
GJB : 4.1.1.17  
HIS : 17  
LMTCP : 89  
MISRA-AC : 5.3, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 17  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6   Modifiers : 417 = 1
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
113 S
Non standard character in source.

This is reported whenever a character is found in the source file which is not defined in the character set section of the c/cppvals.dat file. It is primarily used to detect those characters not defined in a character set. 

	3***** The lines of permissible characters,(80A1),those NOT changed
	ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
	abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
	()[].!~+-*/%<>=& ^|?:;,0123456789_{}'"#\$@<space><tab>

Although the @ and $ characters are listed above, they are not members of all character sets and are not permitted by default. This standard can be relaxed to allow the @ and $ characters by setting the modifier 408 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 113 S : Non standard character in source.
 *******************************************************/
 
void static_113(void)
{
   CHAR non_std_char = '';  /* not compliant */
 
   CHAR poss_string = "$Id: 56$";  /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 408 */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC09-C   Modifiers : 408 = 1
CMSE : 15.2.1  
CWE : 747   Modifiers : 408 = 1
DERA : 5  
FSB582-C : 3.1.5   Modifiers : 408 = 1
GJB : 4.15.2.1  
HIS : 5  
JSF++ AV : 9  
LMTCP : 9, 16  
MISRA-AC : 1.2   Modifiers : 408 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2   Modifiers : 408 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3   Modifiers : 408 = 1
SEC-C : P1.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
114 S
Expression is not Boolean.

Confusion can arise when Boolean values are used as integers and integers are used as Booleans. A violation of this standard will occur if:

  • Both operands of an arithmetic operator are Boolean (other standards handle arithmetic operators with only one Boolean operand)
  • An operand of a logical operator is not a Boolean
  • An expression with a non-Boolean type is used where a Boolean is expected.

The C LDRA Testbed treats expressions with Boolean operators as Boolean expressions. If the compiler has Boolean types then strong typing is applied. When the compiler does not have a boolean type the use of bool or BOOL to declare variables will be treated by the C LDRA Testbed as a declaration of a Boolean type. The user will have to add typedef int BOOL; to their code. Users wishing to use another name will need to add that name to the c/cppvals.dat file. Users should copy the c/cppvals.dat settings for BOOLEAN for their replacement name. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

This standard can be modified to treat objects with integer types as booleans if their first use is in a boolean context by setting the modifier 386 to 0 in the c/cppreport.dat file. The default value is 1. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 114 S : Expression is not Boolean.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_114(BOOL bl, UINT_32 a)
{
   UINT_32 x;
   BOOL flag;
 
   flag = bl + bl; /* not compliant */
 
   if (a) /* not compliant */
   {
      ; /* ... */
   }
 
   x = ( a && bl ? 1U : 0U ); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.14.3  
CMSE : 6.1.23, 14.1.2  
DERA : 35, 36, 49  
FSB582-C : 3.9.1.3  
FSB582-C++ : 9.14  
GJB : 4.14.1.2, 5.1.12  
HIC++ : 5.2  
HIS : 35, 36  
LMTCP : 299, 307, 360  
MISRA-AC : 12.6, 13.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-13, 5-0-14, 5-3-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 35, 36, 49  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.6, 13.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1, R.14.4  
SEC-C : M1.5.2, X4.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
115 S
String incorrectly terminated.

Some non-ANSI compilers allow strings over line boundaries. This standard only permits strings over line boundaries if they are terminated by a backslash.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 115 S : String incorrectly terminated.
 *******************************************************/ 
void static_115(void)
{
   CHAR* str1 = "string\
                 literal";   /* compliant */
 
   CHAR* str2 = "string
                 literal";  /* not compliant */
 }
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : STR03-C  
CMSE : 2.1.9  
CWE : 741  
GJB : 4.2.1.9  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
116 S
Boolean comparison with 0 preferred.

C uses the value zero (0) for Boolean FALSE, and all non-zero values are equivalent to Boolean TRUE. It is safer to compare against the one known value, FALSE, than to perform a comparison against a single value of the entire set that represents TRUE. This standard reports instances in a Boolean context where a variable is compared for equality with unity (1).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 116 S : Boolean comparison with 0 preferred.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_116 (void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 2u;
 
   if ( x == 1u ) /* not compliant */
   {
      /* ... */ ;
   }
   if ( x != 0u )
   {
      /* ... */ ;
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 138  
SEC-C : R2.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
117 S
Logical negation of constant value.

This is to tighten up the use of Boolean expressions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 117 S : Logical negation of constant value.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_117(void)
{
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   if (flag == (BOOL)!1) /* not compliant */
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.10  
CMSE : 6.1.11  
GJB : 4.6.1.11  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
118 S
main must be int (void) or int (int,char*[]).

The C standard only defines two forms for the main function. All other forms are implementation dependent.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 118 S : main must be int (void) or int (int,char*[]).
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void main(void)   /* Not compliant */
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ENV31-C  
CMSE : 2.1.10  
CWE : 744  
DERA : 148  
GJB : 4.2.1.10  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
119 S
Nested comment found.

The /* */ style of comments do not nest, but certain compilers allow nested comments without giving a warning. This is dangerous, as the compiler will terminate the comment at the first termination sequence (*/) encountered, potentially regarding all remaining parts of the comment as legal code.

Lines containing both // and /* can be confusing to the reader and under some circumstances may lead to unexpected results.

This standard can be relaxed to allow // within /* */ comments by setting the modifier 413 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Alternatively the standard can be relaxed to allow // within /* */ comments under a more restricted set of situations by setting the modifier 434 to 1. This permits the // providing it is not preceded by /* ; }, space or new line.

Instructions for making alterations can be found in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 119 S : Nested comment found.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
/* http://myweb - not compliant, unless modifier 413 or 434 set */
 
/* x = 2u; // not compliant, unless modifier 413 set */
 
void static_119(void)
{
   UINT_32 x;
   x = 2U // /*  - not compliant
        + 5U
          // */
       ;  /* User might expect +5U to be commented out */
 
/*  This is the Outer Comment
 /* This is the Inner Comment - not compliant
  */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.10.1  
CERT-C : MSC04-C  
CMSE : 10.1.1  
CWE : 747  
DERA : 9   Modifiers : 413 = 1
GJB : 4.10.1.1   Modifiers : 413 = 1
HIS : 9   Modifiers : 413 = 1
LMTCP : 246  
MISRA-AC : 2.3   Modifiers : 413 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-7-1   Modifiers : 413 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 9   Modifiers : 413 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 2.3   Modifiers : 413 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.3.1  
NETRINO : 2.1.b  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
120 S
Use of bit operator on signed type.

The handling of signed types with bitwise operators is unsafe, for example, and (&) or or (|), as the results are implementation specific. The sign may be lost, or shifted into the numeric part of the value.

Shift operators are handled by standard 50 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 120 S : Use of bit operator on signed type.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_120(void)
{
   SINT_32 b = 1;
 
   b = b | 1; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.11  
CERT-C : INT13-C  
CMSE : 6.1.12  
CWE : 682

HIS : 37  
LMTCP : 297  
MISRA-AC : 12.7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-21  
MISRA-C:1998 : 37  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1  
NETRINO : 5.3.b  
SEC-C : R2.6.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
121 S
Use of boolean expression in switch.

This should be implemented as an if .. then .. else ... The default clause will never be executed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 121 S : Use of boolean expression in switch.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_121(void)
{
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   switch (flag)  /* not compliant */
   {
      case TRUE:
          break;
      case FALSE:
          break;
      default:
          break;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.14.1  
CMSE : 14.1.3  
DERA : 63  
GJB : 4.14.1.3

MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-7  
MISRA-C:1998 : 63  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.7  
SEC-C : M1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
122 S
Use of abort, exit, etc.

The use of functions which terminate execution is banned. Functions which terminate execution are identified in c/cppvals.dat as type 39 codes, and can be changed as needed. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 122 S : Use of abort, exit, etc.
 ********************************************************/ 
void static_122(BOOL flag)
{
   if (flag)
   {
      abort();
   }
   exit(0);
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 7.2.3  
DERA : 126  
GJB : 4.7.2.3  
HIC++ : 5.9

JSF++ AV : 24

MISRA-C++:2008 : 18-0-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 126  
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.11  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.21.8  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
123 S
Use of underlying enum representation value.

This standard enforces strong type checking. Enumerated types must be used only in comparisons with other enumerated types.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 123 S : Use of underlying enum representation value.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
void static_123(void)
{
   enum E_type { Enum1, Enum2 , Enum3};
 
   UINT_32 ui;
 
   ui = Enum1;  /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

MISRA-C++:2008 : 4-5-2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1, R.10.3, R.10.4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
124 S
Use of prefix ++ or --.

The ++ and -- operators are considered dangerous. This standard detects the prefix versions. Postfix versions can be detected with 30 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 124 S : Use of prefix ++ or --.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_124(void)
{
   SINT_32 x = 1;
 
   ++x;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 136  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
125 S
Use of ## or # in a macro.

These operators are poorly defined and can lead to undefined results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 125 S : Use of ## or # in a macro.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#define cat(x) (&string[##(x)])
 
void static_125( UCHAR string[50], UINT_32 n)
{
 
   UCHAR *token1;
 
   token1=cat(n);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : PRE05-C  
CMSE : 15.2.2  
DERA : 157

MISRA-AC : 19.13

MISRA-C:2004 : 19.13  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.10, R.20.12  
SEC-C : M5.1.2  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
126 S
A #if has no #endif in the same file.

Preprocessor statements should not be spread over more than one file.

This standard is not available if "SHORTEN" is set to TRUE, which is the default value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#define MISMATCHEDIF 1
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 126 S : A #if has no #endif in the same file.
 * Does not compile with VC++
 ********************************************************/ 
#if MISMATCHEDIF == 1
 
void static_126(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.13  
CMSE : 1.1.18  
DERA : 160  
GJB : 4.1.1.18  
LMTCP : 43  
MISRA-AC : 19.17  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-1-2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.17  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.14  
SEC-C : M4.7.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML
127 S
Array has no bounds specified.

The use of incomplete array declarations or definitions is not permitted.

This standard can be relaxed to allow initialised array declarations by setting the modifier 426 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. The use of incomplete array declarations in function declarations can be excluded from this check by setting the modifiers 285 or 286 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 127 S : Array has no bounds specified.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 garray[];                /* not compliant */
 
void static_127( INT_32 par[] ) /* not compliant, unless modifier 286 set */
{
   INT_32 array[] = {0,1,2};    /* not compliant, unless modifier 426 set */
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.18  
CERT-C : ARR02-C   Modifiers : 286 = 1
CMSE : 1.1.19  
CWE : 665   Modifiers : 286 = 1, 426 = 1
DERA : 162, 166   Modifiers : 285 = 1
GJB : 4.1.1.19   Modifiers : 286 = 1
MISRA-AC : 8.12   Modifiers : 286 = 1, 426 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-1-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.12   Modifiers : 286 = 1, 426 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.11, R.9.5   Modifiers : 286 = 1, 426 = 1
SEC-C : R3.1.1   Modifiers : 286 = 1, 426 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , VSOS
128 S
Parameter has same name as global variable.

Languages may permit the use of the same name in different contexts (e.g. blocks and namespaces). This is unsafe as it may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. In this instance, the parameter variable would be used within the procedure, but the coder may be confused over which value or instance of the variable is active.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*-- Global Declarations --*/ 
UINT_32 global_int = 0;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 128 S : Parameter has same name as global variable.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_128(UINT_32* global_int) /* not compliant */
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.15.3  
CMSE : 15.1.3  
DERA : 21, 128  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
GJB : 4.15.1.3  
HIS : 21  
LMTCP : 248  
MISRA-AC : 5.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 21  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.3  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
129 S
Parameter has same name as type or tag.

Languages may permit the use of the same name in different contexts (e.g. blocks and namespaces). This is unsafe as it may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. In this instance, the parameter variable name is already declared as a type or as a tag, which can be the name of a structure, a union or an enumeration.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct DUPLICATE
{
  UINT_32 field1;
  UINT_32 field2;
};
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 129 S : Parameter has same name as type or tag.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_129(UINT_32 DUPLICATE)  /* not compliant */
{
   /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.15.4  
CMSE : 15.1.4  
DERA : 12  
GJB : 4.15.1.4  
LMTCP : 248  
MISRA-AC : 5.7   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 12  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
VSOS
130 S
Included file is not permitted.

The use of certain libraries and functions is prohibited by some authorities. This standard prevents the use of nominated include files. The list of include file names that are not permitted are listed as type 260 in the c/cppvals.dat files. The name of the appropriate model must also be added. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

e.g.

QUAL 260 7 stdio.h "MISRA" "MISRA-C:2004"
Example
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 130 S : Included file is not permitted.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#include <stdio.h>  /* not compliant */
 
void static_130 (void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
DERA : 121, 123, 124, 127  
EADS-C++ : 43  
FSB582-C++ : 1.7, 1.8  
HIC++ : 17.1  
HIS : 121, 123, 124, 127  
JSF++ AV : 17, 19, 21, 22, 25  
LMTCP : 23, 25, 26, 29, 30  
MISRA-AC : 20.8, 20.9, 20.12  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 18-0-1, 18-0-4, 18-0-5, 18-7-1, 27-0-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 121, 123, 124, 127

MISRA-C:2012 : R.21.5, R.21.6, R.21.10, R.21.11  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
131 S
Name reused in inner scope.

Languages may permit the use of the same name in different contexts (e.g. blocks and namespaces). This is unsafe as it may lead to confusion as to which variant is active at the time. While block structure rules allow names to be reused in inner blocks, this standard will report any instances encountered.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 131 S : Name reused in inner scope.
 ********************************************************/ 
void STATIC_131(UINT_32 p_1)
{
   UINT_32 static_131;
   BOOL c_1 = FALSE;
 
   if (c_1)
   {
      UINT_32 static_131 = 1u;
      static_131 = static_131 + 1u;
   }
 
   static_131 = p_1;
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.15.2, 5.15.5  
CERT-C : DCL01-C  
CMSE : 15.1.2, 15.1.5  
CWE : 736  
DERA : 21, 128  
EADS-C++ : 30  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
GJB : 4.15.1.2, 4.15.1.5  
HIC++ : 8.2.1  
HIS : 21  
JPL : 6  
JSF++ AV : 135, 138  
LMTCP : 248  
MISRA-AC : 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 21  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.3  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
132 S
Assignment operator in boolean expression.

The assignment operator ( = ) set an lvalue, whereas the equality operator ( == ) performs a comparison. It is possible that the assignment operator was typed in error. This is highly likely, and the operator should be the equality operator.

For Example: 

if (flag=false)  /* Incorrect-assignment made */ 
if (flag==false) /* Correct  - comparison performed */
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 132 S : Assignment operator in boolean expression.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void static_132(void)
{
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   if (flag = FALSE) /* not compliant -  should be (flag == FALSE) */ 
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.1  
CERT-C : MSC02-C  
CMSE : 6.1.15  
CWE : 481  
DERA : 35  
GJB : 4.6.1.15  
HIC++ : 10.5, 10.6  
HIS : 35  
JSF++ AV : 160   Modifiers : 247 = 1
LMTCP : 291  
MISRA-AC : 13.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-2-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 35  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.1, R.13.4   Modifiers : 247 = 1
NETRINO : 8.2.c, 8.6.a  
SEC-C : M3.3.3, X5.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
133 S
Assignment operator in RHS of && or ||.

Any assignment on the right hand side of a logical and (&&) or or (||) operator is conditional on the result of the term to the left of the operator. This is considered to be bad practice.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 133 S : Assignment operator in RHS of && or ||.
 **********************************************************/ 
 
void static_133(void)
{
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
   INT_32 y = 0, x = 0;
 
   if ( flag &&
        ((x = y) == 0) /* not compliant */
      )
   {
      /* ... */
   }
}
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.13  
CERT-C : EXP02-C  
CMSE : 6.1.16  
CWE : 768  
DERA : 33  
GJB : 4.6.1.16  
HIC++ : 10.6, 10.9  
HIS : 33  
JSF++ AV : 157  
MISRA-C:1998 : 33  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
134 S
Volatile variable in complex expression.

The value of volatile variables can change outside of the control of the application. This standard reports any expression that uses the same volatile variable more than once in an expression. This is unsafe, as the value returned may be different at each stage of the expression evaluation. It is safer to use volatiles only in simple expressions which are unlikely to be optimised. If it is required that the same value be used in all parts of an expression, it is better to retain the current value in a local variable and use that in place of the volatile component of the expression.

For example: 

	volatile UINT_32 v = 1U;
	UINT_32 x, a;
	x = v*v; /* this is unsafe, v could change*/ 
	a = v;
	x = a*a; /* this is safe, the value of v was captured */
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 134 S : Volatile variable in complex expression.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_134(void)
{
   UINT_32 y = 2u, x = 0u, z = 1u;
   volatile UINT_32 v = 1U;
 
   x = (v + z) / (v * y);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP10-C, EXP30-C, FIO41-C  
CMSE : 15.1.6  
CWE : 758  
DERA : 46  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
GJB : 4.15.1.6  
HIC++ : 10.3  
HIS : 46  
LMTCP : 362  
MISRA-AC : 12.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 46  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.1, R.13.2  
SEC-C : R3.6.1, R3.6.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
135 S
Parameter list is KR.

The original standard for C was devised by Kernighan and Richie (often referred to as K&R ). This allowed parameter lists to be declared using the name ONLY, with the type optionally following the declaration. It is often preferred that programmers only use the newer (ANSI) form of parameter list, even though compilers will accept K&R style declarations. This standard reports any instances encountered.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 135 S : Parameter list is KR.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_135(  p_1,  p_2) /* not compliant */
UINT_32 p_1;
UINT_32 p_2;
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL07-C  
CMSE : 8.2.7  
CWE : 628  
FSB582-C : 3.6.4  
GJB : 4.8.2.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.1, R.8.2  
SEC-C : R2.8.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

136 S
Bit operator with boolean operand.

A bitwise operator, for example, and (&) or or (|), has been detected within an expression which uses a boolean operator. It is highly likely that the wrong operator is being used, e.g.& instead of &&.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 136 S : Bit operator with boolean operand.
 *****************************************************/ 
void static_136(void)
{
   UINT_32 x = 1u;
 
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   if ((flag | (x != 0u)) == FALSE)  /* not compliant */
   {
       /* ... */ 
   }
}
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.6.14  
CMSE : 6.1.17, 6.1.18  
CWE : 480  
DERA : 36  
GJB : 4.6.1.17, 4.6.1.18  
HIC++ : 10.11  
HIS : 36  
MISRA-AC : 12.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 4-5-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 36  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
138 S
Anonymous bit field used in structure.

All bit fields should have a name. The use of anonymous bit fields could be just packing, but also could be due to an error. For example: 

	struct  bad {UINT_32 x:1,          :1; UINT_32 z:1;}
	struct good {UINT_32 x:1; UINT_32 y:1; UINT_32 z:1;}

This standard can be relaxed to allow anonymous bit fields of length 0 by setting the modifier 248 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 138 S : Anonymous bit field used in structure.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct s_138 {UINT_32 x, :2;}; /* not compliant */
 
void static_138(void)
{
   /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.23  
CMSE : 1.1.3, 1.2.9  
DERA : 113  
GJB : 4.1.1.3, 4.1.2.9  
HIS : 113  
JSF++ AV : 156   Modifiers : 248 = 1
LMTCP : 285   Modifiers : 248 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 113  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
139 S
Construct leads to infeasible code.

It is possible that a branch condition evaluates to a constant value. This would cause some control flow structure to be infeasible and lead to the possibility of infeasible code. E.g.

	if (0) { /* NEVER EXECUTED */ } else {...};

When determining the condition of a branch, it is assumed that an object with an enumeration type will always have value represented by that type. For example:

        typedef enum { LANE_0 = 0, LANE_1 = 1, LANE_LAST = 3 } lane_t;
        if ( (lane > LANE_0) && ( lane <= LANE_LAST))

If lane is greater than 0, the second operand of && will always be true since lane is always less than or equal to 3. This means that there is no way of producing test data for the situation when the 1st operand is True and the 2nd operand is False.

Example
#define defval 0
 
typedef enum { LANE_0 = 0, LANE_1 = 1, LANE_LAST = 3 } lane_t;
extern lane_t get_lane ( void );
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 139 S : Construct leads to infeasible code.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_139( void )
{
   lane_t lane = get_lane();
   if ( (lane > LANE_0) && ( lane <= LANE_LAST))
      /* not compliant - False branch of 'lane <= LANE_LAST' never reached */
      { /* ... */ }
 
   if (defval)
      /* not compliant - True branch never reached*/
      { /* ... */ }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC07-C  
CMSE : 6.2.4  
CWE : 561, 570, 571  
DERA : 52  
GJB : 4.6.2.4  
HIC++ : 5.3  
HIS : 52  
LMTCP : 306  
MISRA-AC : 13.7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 52  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.3  
SEC-C : X2.x, X4.x  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , VSOS
140 S
Infeasible loop condition found.

Detects when a loop condition evaluates to a constant FALSE value

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define defval 0
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 140 S : Infeasible loop condition found.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_140(void)
{
   while (0)          /* not compliant */
      { /* ... */ }
 
   while( defval )   /* not compliant */
      { /* ... */ }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules

SEC-C : M1.9.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , VSOS
141 S
Incomplete structure or class declaration.

This identifies incomplete declarations of the form: 

	struct atagname;

A correct declaration requires a full declaration of all components of the structure. 

	struct atagname(UINT_32 A, UINT_32 B);
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 141 S : Incomplete structure or class declaration.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
struct static_141_s;  /* not compliant */
 
void static_141(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.17  
CMSE : 1.1.21  
DERA : 108  
GJB : 4.1.1.21  
HIS : 108  
MISRA-C:1998 : 108  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
142 S
Parameter list declarations are inconsistent.

This indicates that some parameters have a type and a name and others do not.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 142 S : Parameter list declarations are inconsistent.
 ****************************************************************/
 
void static_142(UINT_32 , UINT_16 p_2)  /* not compliant */
{
    /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 1.1.22  
DERA : 73  
GJB : 4.1.1.22  
HIS : 73  
MISRA-C:1998 : 73  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
143 S
Curly brackets used in expression.

Some compilers will permit the use of curly brackets {} in expressions. This can be very confusing to maintainers and is not portable.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 143 S : Curly brackets used in expression.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 static_143(UINT_32 p_1)
{
   UINT_32 result;
   result = p_1{};  /* not compliant */
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
MISRA-AC : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.2  
SEC-C : X6.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
144 S
Floating point not permitted.

Floating point numbers can introduce computational errors, loss of precision, and unexpected responses in comparison and loops. Floating point needs great care and hence its use is generally not permitted.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 144 S : Floating point not permitted.
 *************************************************/ 
 
FLOAT_32 static_144(FLOAT_32 p_1,FLOAT_32 p_2)  /* not compliant */
{
   FLOAT_32 result;      /* not compliant */
   result = p_1 + p_2;
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 129  
NETRINO : 5.4.a  
145 S
#if has invalid expression.

Some compilers fail to parse the expression following a #if, e.g. 

	#if MACRO_NAME JUNK_NAME

The term that follows a #if should also evaluate to a boolean result, and this type of expression is suspicious.

Example
/************************************************
 *  Standard 145 S : #if has invalid expression.
 ************************************************/ 
 
#define static_145 6
 
#if static_145 i  /* not compliant */
#endif
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 1.1  
MISRA-AC : 1.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 1-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1  
SEC-C : X6.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
146 S
#define with empty parameter list.

C permits macros without parameter lists hence 

	#define Macro() some_macro_body

is confusing and possibly due to an error.

	#define Macro some_macro_body

is more easily understood.

Example
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 146 S : #define with empty parameter list.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#define static_146() ("dummy()")  /* not compliant */
 
void dummy(void);
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
147 S
Spurious characters after preprocessor directive.

This detects coding errors of the type: 

	#endif ;

where the semi colon is a constraint error. However, not all compilers detect this problem.

Example
/*********************************************************************
 *  Standard 147 S : Spurious characters after preprocessor directive.
 *********************************************************************/ 
 
#ifdef STATIC_147
 
  typedef unsigned char UCHAR;
 
#endif ; /* not compliant */
 
void static_147(void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 19.16  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-0-8  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.16  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.13  
SEC-C : M1.12.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML
148 S
No return type for function/procedure.

In C, any declaration or definition that omits a return type will use the implementation-specific default return type. No reliance should be made on default types, so this standard reports any instances encountered

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 *  Standard 148 S : No return type for function/procedure.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
static_148(UINT_32 p1);  /* not compliant */
 
static_148(UINT_32 p1)   /* not compliant */
{
	 /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 628  
DERA : 75  
EADS-C : 108  
FSB582-C : 3.6.2  
HIS : 75  
MISRA-C:1998 : 75  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
149 S
Reference parameter to procedure is reassigned.

Call by reference parameters are declared as pointers and these pointers are initialised by the actual parameter. However these pointer parameters can at any time be reassigned to point to any other suitable object in scope. This is a highly undesirable construct leading to possibly serious errors and unmaintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
CHAR *static_149( CHAR *p1);
 
void test_149(void)
{
  CHAR *a = "Query";
  CHAR *b;
  b = static_149(a);
}
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 149 S : Reference parameter to procedure is reassigned.
 ********************************************************/ 
CHAR *static_149( CHAR *p1 )
{
  static CHAR *newA = "Response";
 
  p1++;        /* not compliant */
  p1 = p1+1;   /* not compliant */
  p1 = newA;   /* not compliant */
 
  return p1;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.8  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
150 S
Volatile or const used in function type.

volatile and const qualifiers are only meaningful for expressions that are lvalues. Therefore applying volatile or const to a function return type has no effect, but the user may be confused into thinking that its does have an effect.

Return types that are pointers to const or volatile are permitted.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
volatile UINT_32 STATIC_150(void);  /* not compliant */
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 150 S : Volatile or const used in function type.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
volatile UINT_32 STATIC_150(void)  /* not compliant */
{
  volatile UINT_32 r;
  /* ... */ 
  return r;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 147  
151 S
Use of global variable in macro definition.

Some authorities consider the use of globals in macro definitions to be dangerous. For example, the macro replacement could use a local definition with the same name instead of the required global variable. This standard reports any instances of a global variable within a macro definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 *  Standard 151 S : Use of global variable in macro definition.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 globvar;
 
#define STATIC_151 globvar  /* not compliant */
 
void  static_151 (void)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 159  
152 S
Use of a comment in a macro definition.

Macros can expand to unexpected code when combined with an incorrect form of comment, which can be very hard to diagnose.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 152 S : Use of a comment in a macro definition.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#define STATIC_152 3 /* not compliant comment */ 
 
void  static_152 (void)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 155  
HIC++ : 14.7  
153 S
Use of a comment in a pre-processor directive.

The mixture of C and preprocessor commands is potentially dangerous.

Example
#ifdef STATIC_153 /* A Comment  - not compliant */ 
  /* ... */ 
#endif /* Another Comment - not compliant */ 
 
/*****************************************************************
 *  Standard 153 S : Use of a comment in a pre-processor directive.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_153 (void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 155  
154 S
Nested header files found.

C allows header files to include further header files. Some bodies consider this unsafe, and require a flat file structure, where all include files contain only the information relevant to the file, and NO further includes. This standard will report any include files that have further includes.

Example

Static_154_1.h

#include "c_standards.h"

Static_154.h

#include "Static_154_1.h"

Static_154.c

#include "Static_154.h"  /* not compliant */
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 154 S : Nested Header Files Found
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_154(void)
{
  ; /* ... */  
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 168  
NETRINO : 4.2.d  
155 S
Comments between preprocessor directives.

This standard highlights when the #ifdef preprocessor directive with an undefined name acts like a comment. This could give problems if the name is later defined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 *  Standard 155 S : Comments between preprocessor directives
 **************************************************************/ 
 
 
#ifdef STATIC_155
  this acts as a comment, as STATIC_155 is undefined.
#endif
 
void static_155 (void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 161  
156 S
Use of 'defined' keyword in macro body.

The mixture of C and preprocessor commands is potentially dangerous. This standard reports any macros which feature the preprocessor directive defined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define STATIC_156(x) defined(x)
 
/****************************************************
 *  Standard 156 S : Use of 'defined' keyword in macro body
 ****************************************************/ 
 
#if STATIC_156(c)
UINT_32 var1;
#else
SINT_32 var1;
#endif
 
#define c 1
 
#if STATIC_156(c)
UINT_32 var2;
#else
SINT_32 var2;
#endif
 
void dummy( void )
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2000 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
DERA : 158  
LMTCP : 92  
MISRA-AC : 20.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 17-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.21.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
157 S
Modification of string literal.

The location of a string literal is determined at the time the program is compiled. For example, it may be placed in an area of memory marked as read-only, or physically stored within the binary executable. It is unsafe to attempt to change any such text, as the consequences are unpredictable.
