This standard also highlights modifications to the pointers returned from string library functions such as strchr. Though this is safe if the original string is not a constant, there will be undefined behaviour is the original string is a constant.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the modification of the contents of an array of chars accessed via a pointer by setting the modifier 438 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************
 *  Standard 157 S : Modification of string literal.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void static_157(void)
{
  CHAR *c = "1234567890";
 
  c[7] = '0';   /* not compliant */
  *(c+6) = '1'; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.13  
CERT-C : STR30-C   Modifiers : 438 = 1
CWE : 758   Modifiers : 438 = 1
DERA : 130   Modifiers : 438 = 1
GJB : 5.1.19  
JSF++ AV : 151.1  
LMTCP : 273  
MISRA-AC : 1.2   Modifiers : 438 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2   Modifiers : 438 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.7.4   Modifiers : 438 = 1
SEC-C : X3.x   Modifiers : 438 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
158 S
Expression with more than *** subconditions.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number, defaulting to 10 for this standard. The configuration is made in the c/cppreport.dat or c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************************
 *  Standard 158 S : Expression with more than *** subconditions.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_158(void)
{
  INT_32 a1,b1,c1,d1,e1;
  INT_32 a2,b2,c2,d2,e2;
  INT_32 a3,b3,c3,d3,e3;
 
  if  ((a1==0) && (b1==0) && (c1==0) && (d1==0) && (e1==0)
    && (a2==0) && (b2==0) && (c2==0) && (d2==0) && (e2==0)
    && (a3==0) && (b3==0) && (c3==0) && (d3==0) && (e3==0)) /* not compliant */
    {
      /* ... */ 
    }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 146  
159 S
Comparing pointer with zero or NULL.

Any comparison of a pointer to NULL or zero should be made to a NULL pointer of the correct type. e.g.

	char *message;
	if (message != (char *)(NULL) ) /* compliant */ 
	if (message != NULL )           /* not compliant */

This standard can be relaxed to allow comparisons with zero by setting the modifier 207 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/*********************************************************
 *  Standard 159 S : Comparing pointer with zero or NULL.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_159(void)
{
  CHAR *message = "TEST";
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  if  ( message != NULL )  /* not compliant */
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
  if  ( message != 0 ) /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 207 */
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 163  
160 S
Loop in macro expansion.
Example
/*********************************************************
 *  Standard 160 S : Loop in macro expansion..
 *********************************************************/ 
 
#define A B
#define B A
 
#define C D
#define D E
#define E C
 
main(){
int B;
int C;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
161 S
Declaration in for statement.

The scope of a variable declared in the first expression of a for loop is that of the for loop. It is not visible after the end of the for loop. However, some compilers permit such variables to be used after the for loop, which can lead to confusion. Therefore, don't define variables in the for statement initialiser.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
/*********************************************************
 *  Standard 161 S : Declaration in for statement.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void STATIC_161(void)
{
    UINT_32 y = 0U;
 
    for ( unsigned x(0); x < 3U; x++ ) /* not compliant */ 
    {
        y++;
    }
}
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

162 S
Method defined within class declaration.

Don't put member function definitions in the class declaration. Only member function declarations. An exception is for small member functions with an empty function body.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 162 S : Method defined within class declaration.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
 
public:
 
   long l;
   one(void);
   one(UINT_32 i){;}
    ~one(void){;}
    void bproc();
};
 
one::one(void)
{
    l=9;
}
 
void one::bproc(void)
{
    l=7;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 5.2, 7.3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

163 S
Function starts with upper case character.

Function names shall start with a lower-case letter (not including subsystem/package prefixes).

Class member functions are reported by 173 S.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 163 S : Function starts with upper case character.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void Static_163( void ) /* not compliant */
{
 
   /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 74  
164 S
Use of void * pointer.

The use of void declared pointers is not allowed. Exceptions can be made if no other solution is available and the reason is documented.

Example
#include <stdio.h>
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 164 S : Use of void * pointer.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void proc(void *ptr) { ; } /* not compliant */
 
void * a_proc ( void )            /* not compliant */
{
    return NULL;
}
 
 
void static_164 ( void )
{
   void * p = a_proc();          /* not compliant */
   proc(p);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
165 S
Nested class declaration.

Use nested classes and local classes in functions with caution. The added complexity of scope rules and restrictions may be confusing, especially since there are differences in the scope rules used in C and C++. It can be of use in some circumstances though.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 165 S : Nested class declaration.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
 
public:
    long along;
    class nested
    {
    public:
        short s;
        nested(){;}
    };
    one()
    {
        nested anest;
    }
};
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

166 S
Class declared in function body.
Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 166 S : Class declared in function body.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
 
public:
    long l;
    one(){;}
    void aproc()
    {
        class inproc1
        {
            public:
                short s;
                inproc1(){;}
        };
    }
 
};
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Standard , TBrun Requires
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

167 S
Class variable declared in class definition.

The declaration of structure/class variables shall be separate from the definition of the type. For clarity of compilation diagnostics, use typedef (rather than defines).

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 167 S : Class variable declared in class definition.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
 
public:
    long a;
    one(){;}
 
} aone, *paone;
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 141  
LMTCP : 256  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

168 S
Call by value parameter not const.

Non-pointer function parameters whose arguments are passed as call by value shall be declared constant. Pointer function parameters are covered by standard 603 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 168 S : Call by value parameter not const.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void aproc( SINT_32 iv_param) {;}        /* not compliant */
static void bproc(const SINT_32 ic_param) {;}
 
static SINT_32 static_168 (void)
{
  SINT_32 loc_var = 0;
 
  aproc(loc_var);
  bproc(loc_var);
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 34  
HIC++ : 8.4.11  
LMTCP : 279  
NETRINO : 1.8.b  
169 S
Use of forward reference of class member.
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 169 S : Use of forward reference of class member.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class ok 
{ public:
    INT_32 x;
    ok(void) { x = 1; }
};
 
class notok 
{ public:
     notok() { d = 91; /* not compliant */ }
     INT_32 d;
};
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

170 S
Procedure call has no prototype and no defn.

A call has been found that is not preceded by either a prototype, or the definition of the function. In this case the compiler may make assumptions about the types.

A violation may also occur for functions where the include file containing the prototype has not been included in the analysis.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
static void static_170( void );
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 170 S : Procedure call has no prototype and no defn.
 *******************************************************************/
 
static void static_170( void )
{  
  aproc() ;    /* not compliant */   
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL07-C, EXP37-C  
CWE : 628  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

172 S
Variable declared multiply.

Two declarations and\or definitions that occur with the same name at file scope in the same translation unit shall not both have the extern storage class or both have no storage class. The C/C++ rules on linkage are complicated and such code may lead to confusion.

It is recommended that the user declares an external identifier with the extern storage class in a header file and then provides a definition with no storage class in one source file.

This standard can be relaxed to allow duplicate names in C++ namespaces by setting the modifier 297 to 1 in the cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 172 S : Variable declared multiply.
 *******************************************************************/
 
UCHAR a;
UCHAR a;     /* not compliant */
 
UCHAR b;
UCHAR b = 3; /* not compliant */
 
extern UCHAR c;
extern UCHAR c;     /* not compliant */
 
extern UCHAR ok;  /* ideally in a header file */
UCHAR ok = 3U;    /* compliant */
 
static void static_172( void )
{
 ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIS : 25  
LMTCP : 252  
MISRA-AC : 8.9  
MISRA-C:1998 : 25  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.9  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.5  
SEC-C : M4.4.3, M4.4.4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
173 S
Class member starts with upper case character.

Class member function names shall start with a lower-case letter. (This standard does not apply to constructors, destructors or conversion functions.)

Non-member functions are reported by 163 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 173 S : Class member starts with upper case character.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
class one {public:
    void Upper2_out(); /* not compliant */
};
 
void one::Upper2_out(){INT_32 a = 13;}
 
 
int main(void){
  one x;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

174 S
Class member starts with lower case character.

Class member function names shall start with an upper-case letter. (This standard does not apply to constructors, destructors or conversion functions.)

Non-member functions are reported by 175 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 174 S : Class member starts with lower case character.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
class one {
  public:
  INT_32 x;
 
  void notokproc1 ()  /* not compliant */
  {
  }
};
 
INT_32 main(void)
{
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

175 S
Function starts with lower case character.

Function names shall start with an upper-case letter (not including subsystem/package prefixes).

This rule does not apply main or to overloading the operators new, new[], delete and delete[]. Class member functions are reported by 174 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 175 S : Function starts with lower case character.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void static_175 (void) /* not compliant */
 
{
}
 
int32_t main (void) /* compliant */
{
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
176 S
Non standard escape sequence in source.
Example
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 176 S : Non standard escape sequence in source.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_176 (void)
{
     char c = 'b';
 
     switch(c)
     {
     case '\m':  /* not compliant */
          break;
 
     default:
          break;
     }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC10-C  
CWE : 176, 758  
DERA : 5  
FSB582-C : 3.1.5  
HIC++ : 6.4  
HIS : 5  
LMTCP : 19, 270  
MISRA-AC : 4.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-13-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 4.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3, R.4.1  
SEC-C : P1.2.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , VSOS
177 S
Identifier not declared on new line.

Each declaration of a variable or constant shall have a source line to itself. This LDRA penalty is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 177 S : Identifier not declared on new line.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 okvar, notok2; /* not compliant */
 
void static_177(void)
{
  okvar = 0;
  notok2 = 2;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL04-C  
EADS-C : 83  
HIC++ : 8.4.2   Modifiers : 220 = 1
JPL : 4  
JSF++ AV : 152   Modifiers : 220 = 1
LMTCP : 83   Modifiers : 220 = 1
Related standards filter models
VSOS
178 S
Declaration statement not on new line.

Each declaration of a variable or constant shall have a source line to itself, except for the declarations of procedure parameters.

This LDRA penalty is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 178 S : Declaration does not start new line.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 * oka;
INT_32 b;  INT_32 *notoka; /* not compliant */
 
void proc( INT_32 * s, INT_32 *ok);  /* compliant */
 
struct tag0 { INT_32 * w; INT_32 *notokq;} astr; /* not compliant */
 
static void static_178(void)
{
 oka = 0;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 156  
FSB582-C : 3.3.6, 3.7.6  
FSB582-C++ : 10.7  
HIC++ : 8.4.2  
JPL : 4  
LMTCP : 276  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
179 S
Extern not at start of header file.

External variables shall be declared at the beginning of header files.

Example

Static_179.c

#include "c_standards.h"
#include "Static_179.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 179 S : Extern not at start of header file.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_179(void)
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */

Static_179.h

INT_32 var;
 
extern INT_32 ex; /* not compliant */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.15  
180 S
No space between * or & and name in declaration.

If '*' or '&' is used in a declaration, then a space should occur between the '*' or '&' and the name. It is important that only one variable/constant is declared on each line with this syntax style to avoid unintentional type declaration errors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 180 S : No space between * or & and name in declaration.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 *notoka;       /* not compliant */
 
typedef INT_32 *ptr;  /* not compliant */
 
void static_180(INT_32 *p1) /* not compliant */
{
  *notoka = *p1;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
NETRINO : 3.1.e  
181 S
No space between if, while, for and expresn.

Control structure keywords (if, switch, while, for) should be followed by one space. Spaces are optional between the parenthesis and the expression.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 181 S : No space between if, while, for and expresn.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 main(void)
{
   INT_32 i=3;
   if( 1==2 ) {2;}       /* not compliant */
   switch(i){            /* not compliant */
   }
   switch (i){
   }
   while(i==0){2;}      /* not compliant */  
   do{2;}while(i==0);   /* not compliant */
   for(i=0;i>2;i++){2;} /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 148  
FSB582-C++ : 10.12  
NETRINO : 3.1.a  
182 S
No space after semi colon in for expression.

In order to aid readability, semi colons in a for statement should be followed by a space or a new-line.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 182 S : No space after semi colon in for expression.
 **************************************************************/
 
void static_182(void)
{
  INT_32 i;
  for ( i = 0;i < 5;i++ ) /* not compliant */
  {
      i++;
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 151  
FSB582-C++ : 10.12  
NETRINO : 3.1.l  
183 S
No newline after semi colon.

Placing declarations and statements on separate lines improves readability. The use of semi colon as the declaration of a for loop is not included in this rule.

This standard is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 183 S : No newline after semi colon.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_183(void)
{
  INT_32 i; INT_32 j;   /* not compliant */
 
  for ( i = 0; i < 5; i++ )
  { i++;}  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.3.6  
FSB582-C++ : 10.7  
JSF++ AV : 42  
LMTCP : 65  
NETRINO : 3.3.a  
184 S
Spaces round -> or [] operators.

The -> operator should not be written with surrounding spaces. The left bracket of an array declaration or subscript ([]) should not be preceded by a space. The right bracket of an array subscript should not be followed by a space if it is followed by a (.

This standard can be relaxed to allow spaces around [] by setting the modifier 240 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 184 S : Spaces round -> or [] operators.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct tag { INT_32 f; };
 
void static_184(struct tag * astr, 
                INT_32 b []     /* not compliant */ )
{
  astr ->f = 2; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.3.9   Modifiers : 240 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 10.13   Modifiers : 240 = 1
JSF++ AV : 63   Modifiers : 240 = 1
LMTCP : 88  
NETRINO : 3.1.g  
185 S
Space between unary operator and operand.

There should be no space between a unary operator and its operand.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 185 S : Space between unary operator and operator.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void static_185(void)
{
   INT_32 i=9;
   INT_32 j=19;
   INT_32 * p;
 
   i = - j;           /* not compliant */
   p = & j;           /* not compliant */
   * p = 77;          /* not compliant */
   *p = * p + 77;     /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 153, 154  
FSB582-C : 3.3.9  
FSB582-C++ : 10.13  
JSF++ AV : 63  
LMTCP : 88  
NETRINO : 3.1.d, 3.1.e  
Related standards filter models
Standard
186 S
Space missing before or after binary operator.

Binary operators should always have spaces around them, since this aids readability. This standard also requires spaces around = in initialisations.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 *  Standard 186 S : Space missing before or after binary operator.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_186( void )
{
   INT_32 i = 9;
   INT_32 j =8;         /* not compliant */
   INT_32 k= 7;         /* not compliant */
   UINT_32 x = 3u;
   UINT_32 y = 17u;
 
   i= j;          /* not compliant */
   i = j /k;      /* not compliant */
   i = j <<k;     /* not compliant */
   i = j && k;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 149  
FSB582-C : 3.3.9  
FSB582-C++ : 10.12  
NETRINO : 3.1.b, 3.1.c  
187 S
Tab character in source.

Spaces should be used for indentation rather than tab characters, as this makes the printout independent of tab length.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************
 *  Standard 187 S : Tab character in source.
 *********************************************/ 
 
	INT_32 g;
 
	void static_187(void)
        {
		g = 9;
	}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 138  
FSB582-C : 3.1.5  
FSB582-C++ : 10.6  
HIC++ : 14.2  
JSF++ AV : 43  
LMTCP : 66  
NETRINO : 3.5.a  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
188 S
{ or } not on line by itself.

To increase readability the bodies must have explicit braces (even if the body consists of only one line). This will also eliminate the "dangling else" problem. This LDRA penalty is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 188 S : { or } not on line by itself.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct tagnotok { CHAR a; } data; /* not compliant */
 
struct
{
  CHAR x;
} moredata;
 
void proc_ok()
{
  ;
}
 
void static_188 (void){   /* not compliant */
   ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 142  
FSB582-C : 3.3.1, 3.3.2, 3.3.8, 3.7.5  
FSB582-C++ : 9.18, 10.1, 10.3  
JSF++ AV : 61  
LMTCP : 86  
NETRINO : 1.3.b  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
189 S
Input line exceeds limit.

This limitation is imposed to help to ensure that source code, when displayed or printed out, remains legible. Longer lines must be broken down nicely. The maximum width of characters is configured in the c/cppvals.dat file against the entry marked as type 177 (MAXLIN). Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

177  120      Maximum source line length for standard 189 S. MAXLIN

Alternatively, the limit may be specified in the c/cppreport.dat file against the penalty detail, in association with the chosen programming model:

189 S C "AV:vals 177 120" "EADS:M:vals 177 132" "UML" "LMTCP:C:vals 177 75"
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 189 S : Input line exceeds limit.
 * 
 * Note: To see the message in this example,
 *       set the parameter to 80 in the vals.dat file
 ********************************************************/ 
 
int_32 main(void)
{
  INT_32 iiiiiiiiiiiii = 0;
  iiiiiiiiiiiii = iiiiiiiiiiiii + iiiiiiiiiiiii + iiiiiiiiiiiii + iiiiiiiiiiiii + iiiiiiiiiiiii;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 140   Modifiers : 177 = 132
FSB582-C : 3.1.6   Modifiers : 177 = 120
FSB582-C++ : 10.14   Modifiers : 177 = 120
JSF++ AV : 41   Modifiers : 177 = 120
LMTCP : 64   Modifiers : 177 = 75
NETRINO : 1.2.a   Modifiers : 177 = 80
Related standards filter models
UML
190 S
{ ... } contents not indented by *** spaces.

This LDRA penalty is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 2. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

This standard can be relaxed to allow indentation which is greater than the specified amount by setting the modifier 324 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 190 S : { ... } contents not indented by 2 spaces.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void static_190( INT_32 * g){
   * g = 77;       /* not compliant */
   *g = * g + 77;  
 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 139, 144   Modifiers : 324 = 1
FSB582-C : 3.3.3, 3.3.4  
FSB582-C++ : 9.18, 10.1, 10.3, 10.4, 10.5  
JSF++ AV : 44   Modifiers : 324 = 1
LMTCP : 67   Modifiers : 324 = 1
NETRINO : 3.4.a, 3.4.b  
191 S
Space between function name and parenthesis.

A space has been detected between a function name and an opening round bracket in a function declaration or definition.

Example
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 191 S : Space between function name and parenthesis.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
 
void notokproc1 () /* not compliant */
{
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 152  
192 S
Static not on separate line in function defn.

Due to improved readability it is recommended that inline, static and a trailing const for the function definition appears on a line on their own. Function arguments can be declared on a single line if enough space is available, otherwise one argument per line.

Example
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 192 S : Static not on separate line in function defn.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void proc1(void) /* not compliant */
 {
   ; /* .... */
 }
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
193 S
Inline not on separate line in function defn.
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 193 S : Inline not on separate line in function defn.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {public:
  INT_32 x;
  void mem1(void)const;
};
 
inline void one::mem1(void) /* not compliant */
const
{
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

194 S
Const not on separate line in member defn.

For ease of readability and maintainability, a const qualifier for a member definition shall be placed on a separate line to that of the member identifier. The const-ness of a member is much easier to pick out when formatted in this way.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 194 S : Const not on separate line in member defn.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
 
class one {public:
  INT_32 x;
  void mem2(void)
  const;
};
 
 
inline
void one::mem2(void) const  /* not compliant */
{
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

195 S
Function return type needs a new line.

For ease of readability and maintainability, a function return type shall be placed on a separate line to that of the function identifer. Function names and their return types are much easier to pick out when formatted in this way.

Example
/**************************************************************
 *  Standard 195 S : Function return type needs a new line.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
static void proc2(void)
{
}
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JPL : 4  
196 S
Access specifier missing (added by Testbed).

The order of protection sections in a class declaration shall be:

  • Public
  • Protected
  • Private
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 *  Standard 196 S : Access specifier missing (added by Testbed).
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
class notok1 
{
  INT_32 d;  /* not compliant */
};
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 82  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

197 S
Access specifiers in invalid order.

Access specifiers in a class shall be ordered by decreasing scope of audience. Public is first and at the top of the class declaration, followed by Protected, and lastly Private - which is only of concern to the implementers of the class.

This standard can be relaxed to allow for classes with no protected section by setting the modifier 210 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 *  Standard 197 S : Access specifiers in invalid order.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
class class_197{
   public:
   INT_16 d;
   private:   /* not compliant */
   INT_32 a;
   protected: /* not compliant */
   INT_32 q;
};
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 2   Modifiers : 210 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 4.1   Modifiers : 210 = 1
HIC++ : 3.1.1   Modifiers : 210 = 1
JSF++ AV : 57   Modifiers : 210 = 1
LMTCP : 82   Modifiers : 210 = 1
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

198 S
Use of privacy statement in struct.

Structs are to be used as in C. Class-like facilities such as access specifiers shall not be utilised.

Example
/**************************************************************
 *  Standard 198 S : Use of privacy statement in struct.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
typedef int INT;
typedef short S;
 
 
struct tag {
  INT l;
  private:
  S b;
} okstr;
 
INT main(void)
{
}
 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 54  
HIC++ : 15.2  
LMTCP : 97  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

199 S
Use of anonymous namespace.

Unnamed, or anonymous, namespaces shall not be used. An anonymous namespace is a facility for establishing identifiers as global but within the scope of a single file. It is preferred that each non-local identifier be qualified using a 'tagged' namespace.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 199 S : Use of an anonymous namespace.
 ********************************************************/
 
namespace
{ /* not compliant */
  SINT_16 index = 0;
}
 
 
namespace NS
{
  SINT_32 index = 1;
  SINT_32 some_ref = 99;
}
 
 
SINT_32 static_199(void)
{
  SINT_32 sum = index +         // could be confused with NS::index
                NS::some_ref;
  return sum;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

200 S
Define used for numeric constant.

#define should not be used to define numeric constants. It is preferable to use const variables or enumeration constants, since these can support name scopes and type checking. It should be noted that in C, as opposed to C++, that it is not always possible to replace a #define with a const declaration. For example, a const variable cannot be use to declare the size of an array.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define ACONSTAT 100       /* not compliant */
 
const INT_16 BCONSTAT 100; /* preferred definition */
/********************************************************
 * Standard 200 S : Define used for numeric constant.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_200 ( void )
{
   INT_16 ss;
   ss = ACONSTAT;
   ss = BCONSTAT;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL00-C  
EADS-C : 80, 88  
EADS-C++ : 51  
HIC++ : 14.17  
JSF++ AV : 30  
LMTCP : 36  
NETRINO : 1.8.b  
Related standards filter models
UML
201 S
Use of numeric literal in expression.

The use of numeric literals, i.e. magic numbers, is generally accepted as undesirable due to the impact on maintainability. A typical example of a magic number would be a value used to limit the number of iterations for a fixed loop. Symbolic names in the form of const variables, or possibly enum constants, will be used instead, and ideally, placed in header files.

This standard also extends to numeric literals substituted via macros. It is acknowledged that macros might have to be used - particularly with the C language, where the usage of const is more limited than C++. However, the const type qualifier is demanded for complex data types (structures, arrays etc) and is also easier to modify with a debugger. The standard can be relaxed to allow numeric literals substituted via macros by setting the modifier 163 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. By default, the standard is configured to allow numeric literals substituted via macros.

It is also recognised that 0 and 1, in many cases, are not regarded as magic numbers, being literals with intuitive meaning, and so may be excluded from the rule check. This may be done by setting the modifier 217 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Alternatively, all numbers in a specified range can be allowed by configuring the corresponding parametrised value in the c/cppreport.dat file. For example:

 201 S C  CWE:128  will not produce a warning for literals in the range -128 to 128 (for the CWE model)

This standard permits the use of numeric literals when a variable is initialised at the same point as its declaration. It can also be relaxed to allow the assignments of numeric literals to array elements in constructors by configuring the modifier 237 in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define ACONSTANT 101
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 201 S : Use of numeric literal in expression.
 ********************************************************/
 
SINT_32 static_201(void)
{
   const SINT_16 max = 17; /* compliant */
   SINT_16 y = 77;         /* compliant */
   SINT_16 z;              /* compliant */
 
   z = 131;        /* not compliant */
   z = ACONSTANT;  /* compliant but can be prohibited with modifier 163 */
 
   z = 0; /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 217 */
   z = 1; /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 217 */
   z = 2; /* not compliant */
 
   return 0;  /* not compliant but permitted with modifier 217 */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL06-C, EXP07-C, EXP09-C  
CWE : 547   Modifiers : 217 = 1
EADS-C : 80, 87  
FSB582-C++ : 1.3   Modifiers : 217 = 1
HIC++ : 10.1   Modifiers : 217 = 1
JSF++ AV : 151   Modifiers : 217 = 1
LMTCP : 272   Modifiers : 217 = 1
NETRINO : 8.4.a  
SEC-C : M1.10.1  
Related standards filter models
UML , VSOS
202 S
Class data is not explicitly private.

Avoid public or protected data in a class. Use access functions to provide access to data in a class.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 202 S : Class data is not private.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
  public:
   one(){;}
   long along;        /* not compliant */
  protected:
   short asort;       /* not compliant */
  private:
   unsigned unsign;
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 18  
FSB582-C++ : 4.3  
HIC++ : 3.4.1  
JSF++ AV : 67  
LMTCP : 100, 153  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 11-0-1  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

203 S
Cast on a constant value.

The const qualification of an object or data member is an indication by the programmer that the object is not expected to be changed. In addition, the behaviour is undefined if an object with a const-qualified type is modified via another object with a non-const-qualified type.

Some authorities believe that all casts that remove const should be flagged. Other authorities only require that the casts that might lead to undefined behaviour are flagged. These occur when the cast removes the const qualification on a pointer to const type. This standard can be restricted to check only pointer types by setting the modifier 390 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 203 S : Cast on a constant value.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
const INT_16 con = 19;
const INT_16 * pcon;
 
static void static_203(void)
{
   INT_16 x;
   INT_16 *p;
   x = (INT_16)con;      /* not compliant if modifier = 0 */
   p = (INT_16 *)pcon;   /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP05-C  
CWE : 704  
FSB582-C++ : 1.11  
HIC++ : 7.4  
LMTCP : 328, 335  
MISRA-AC : 11.5   Modifiers : 390 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-5   Modifiers : 390 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.5   Modifiers : 390 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.8   Modifiers : 390 = 1
SEC-C : R2.7.2   Modifiers : 390 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
204 S
continue or goto not defined to rubbish.

The reserved words goto and continue shall be redefined in the standard project/product header file to produce a compilation error.

Example
#define goto  some_total_rubbish ----------
 
/* continue not in # define - not compliant */
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 204 S : continue or goto not defined to rubbish.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_204 (void)
{ 
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
205 S
Use of multiple inheritance.

Avoid the use of complex inheritance structures. Derived classes that inherit from more than one base class, whether through mulitple inheritance or a multi-layered structure, generally do not justify the added complexity.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 205 S : Use of multiple inheritance.
 ************************************************/
 
class basic
{
  public:
    INT_32 anint;
    basic()
    {
      anint = 7;
    }
};
 
class basic1 : public basic /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    INT_32 anint1;
    basic1()
    {
      anint1 = 7;
    }
};
 
class two : public basic1  /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    INT_32 extra;
};
 
static INT_32 static_205 (void)
{
   two atwo;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 60  
FSB582-C++ : 4.5  
Related standards filter models
Standard
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

206 S
Class initialiser out of order.

Data members in the initialisation list should be written in the order in which they are declared in the class. Otherwise, unexpected behaviour can occur since data members are initialised in the order in which they are declared, not the order in which they appear in the initialisation list.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 206 S : Class initialiser out of order.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
class one {
 public:
   one():  twoint(7),  /* not compliant */
           oneint(9)   /* not compliant */
   {
   }
   INT_32 oneint;
   INT_32 twoint;
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 9, 10  
FSB582-C++ : 7.2  
HIC++ : 3.2.2  
JSF++ AV : 75  
LMTCP : 116  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

207 S
Use of old style /* comments in C++.

C++ comments shall be used in preference to C style comments. Single line comments are clearer and without the risks associated with nesting of comments.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
// *****************************************************
// Standard 207 S : Use of old style /* comments in C++.
// *****************************************************
 
void static_207 (void)
{
  /* not compliant -  Old style C comment at head of procedure */ 
 
  UINT_32 local;
 
  // Rest of procedure
  // ... 
}
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 46  
HIC++ : 14.1  
JSF++ AV : 126  
LMTCP : 237  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

208 S
Private data name needs trailing underscore.

In order to clearly distinguish between private data members and other identifiers, the use of a trailing underscore shall be used in the name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 208 S : Private data name needs trailing underscore.
 ***************************************************************/
 
class MyClass
{
  private:
    UINT_32 m_ok_item_;
    UINT_32 m_not_ok_item;  /* not compliant */ 
  protected:
  public:
};
 
static void static_208 ( void )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

209 S
Preprocessor command indented.

All preprocessor directives shall begin in column 1 by convention. A consistent layout promotes readability.

Example
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 209 S : Preprocessor command indented.
 *******************************************************************/
 
#ifndef  XXX
   /* not compliant */
  #define XXX
#endif
 
static void static_209( void )
{
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 14.3, 14.4  
LMTCP : 94  
NETRINO : 3.2.d  
210 S
Macro name is not upper case.

All macro names shall be in upper case by convention. By using all upper case, macros are easily distinguishable from other identifiers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define my_sq_macro(X) ((X) * (X)) /* not compliant */
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 210 S : Macro name is not upper case.
 *************************************************/
 
UINT_32 static_210(UINT_32 p1)
{
  return my_sq_macro(p1);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 61  
FSB582-C : 3.2.4  
NETRINO : 6.1.f, 7.1.f  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
211 S
Overloaded &&, || or comma.

Never overload the operators &&, || and ,(comma operator). Their original behaviour can not be mimicked when overloading them.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 211 S : Overloaded && , || or comma.
 *************************************************/
 
class one
{ public:
    INT_64 along;
    one(){;}
 
    INT_32 operator && (one & x) { return 1; } /* not compliant */
    INT_32 operator || (one & x) { return 1; } /* not compliant */
    INT_32 operator ,  (one & x) { return 1; } /* not compliant */
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 21  
FSB582-C++ : 8.1  
HIC++ : 3.5.1  
JSF++ AV : 159  
LMTCP : 288  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-11  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

212 S
Use of friend function in class.

Use friends sparingly; a redesign of a class hierarchy and interface can be more appropriate. Friends of a class should be used to provide functions that are best kept outside of the class. If friends are used, assign friendship to specific functions and avoid assigning to a complete class if possible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 212 S: Use of friend function in class.
 ********************************************************/
 
void proc(INT_32 i){;}
 
class one
{ public:
    friend void proc(INT_32 i); /* not compliant */
};
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 20  
HIC++ : 3.4.4  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

213 S
Use of friend class.

Use friends sparingly; a redesign of a class hierarchy and interface can be more appropriate. Friends of a class should be used to provide functions that are best kept outside of the class. If friends are used, assign friendship to specific functions and avoid assigning to a complete class if possible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************
 * Standard 213 S : Use of friend class.
 ******************************************/
 
class two
{ public:
   INT_16 ashort;
   two(){;}
};
 
class one
{ public:
    friend class two; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 20  
FSB582-C++ : 4.4  
HIC++ : 3.4.4  
Related standards filter models
TBrun Requires
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

214 S
Member not declared virtual.

Use the keyword virtual for all definitions in derived classes of a function that is defined as virtual in a base class, even though this is optional.

Example
/*************************************************
 * Standard 214 S : Member not declared virtual.
 *************************************************/
 
class one
{ public:
    one(){;}
    virtual void proc();
};
 
class two: one
{ public:
   two(){;}
   virtual void proc(); /* compliant */
};
 
class thr: one
{ public:
   thr(){;}
   void proc();   /* not compliant */
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 15  
FSB582-C++ : 6.4  
HIC++ : 3.3.16  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 10-3-2  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

215 S
Struct or class called by value.

Avoid declaring functions that create big temporary objects for return values and parameters, such as structures, unions, or classes passed by value.

This standard can be further restricted to check for functions with constant struct or class parameters by setting the modifier 328 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 215 S : Struct or class called by value.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct tag { INT_32 s;};
 
static void static_215( struct tag str ) /* not compliant */
{
  ;   
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 11.4   Modifiers : 328 = 1
LMTCP : 212  
SEC-C : E1.1.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
216 S
Pointer name does not have required suffix.

The names of pointer objects shall end in the same suffix. The suffix can be specified by the user in the c/cpptbend.dat file. By default the suffix is set to ptr. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

ptr                               20 character suffix for pointers
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 216 S : Pointer name does not have required suffix.
 * uses default setting of "ptr" in ctbend.dat
 *************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_216( void )
{
  UCHAR * pointer;    /* not compliant */
  UCHAR * ptr;        /* ok as allowed suffix is ptr */
  UCHAR * aptr;       /* ok as allowed suffix is ptr */
 
  /***/
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 72  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
217 S
Names only differ by case.

Don't use names where the only difference is the case in a single scope; i.e. don't use foobar and fooBar in any part of the code where both are accessible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 217 S : Names only differ by case.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 Foobar;
INT_32 foobar;  /* not compliant */
INT_32 fOobar;  /* not compliant */
 
void aproc(CHAR aC2; INT_32 FooBar) {;} /* not compliant */
 
void static_217 (void)
{
  struct tag{ CHAR aC1, INT_32 FooBar;} local; /* Ok as different scope */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 52  
FSB582-C : 3.2.8  
HIC++ : 8.3.4  
JSF++ AV : 48  
LMTCP : 71  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-1  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.5  
Related standards filter models
Standard , VSOS
218 S
Name is used in standard libraries.

Functions should not be declared if they are present in the standard libraries. This may lead to unexpected behaviour.

The list of standard library functions can be found in the data file c/cpptbend.dat, in the section starting with the line:

A list of typed library procedures
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 218 S : Name is used in standard libraries.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void strstr(INT_32 x){;}  /* not compliant */
void strcmp(INT_32 x){;}  /* not compliant */
 
static void static_218 (void)
{
    strstr(2);
    strcmp(1);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ERR31-C  
EADS-C : 49  
HIS : 115  
LMTCP : 93  
MISRA-AC : 20.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 17-0-2, 17-0-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 115  
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.21.2  
NETRINO : 6.1.b, 7.1.b  
SEC-C : M1.7.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
219 S
User name starts with underscore.

Names with leading underscore shall not be defined by any programmer, since they are reserved for the compiler.

This standard can be further restricted to prohibit the use of the #undef operator on names with a leading underscore by setting the modifier 412 to 1 in the c/cppvals.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Using the modifier will also highlight the use of #undef on C reserved words such as __LINE__ as this may indicate that the user plans to re-use the name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 219 S : User name starts with underscore.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
typedef int _INT_NOK;  /* not compliant */
 
static void static_219 ( void  )
{
  INT_32 _ohno;  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 48, 59  
FSB582-C : 3.2.9  
FSB582-C++ : 12.1  
JSF++ AV : 47  
LMTCP : 70  
MISRA-AC : 20.1, 20.2   Modifiers : 412 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.1, 20.2   Modifiers : 412 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.21.1, R.21.2   Modifiers : 412 = 1
NETRINO : 6.1.c, 7.1.c  
SEC-C : M1.7.3  
Related standards filter models
UML
220 S
No prefix for global type.

Prefix the name of globally visible types (i.e. classes, enum types, typedefs, unions, classes structs etc.). The prefix, which can be up to 6 characters, is specified as type 179 in the c/cppvals.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual. By default, the prefix is set to PREFIX.

179     PREFIX              6 chars for global type prefix.
Example
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 220 S : No prefix for global type.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
typedef int NOTOK_INT;   /* not compliant */
 
typedef int PREFIX_int;  /* compliant */
 
class PREFIX_class       /* compliant */
{ private:
    PREFIX_int anint;
    PREFIX_class(){;}
};
 
class NOTOK_class       /* not compliant */
 { public: 
    NOTOK_INT another;
    NOTOK_class(){;}
};
 
PREFIX_int main(void)
{
   typedef long okok;     /* compliant as local typedef */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
221 S
Start of class/struct/union/enum lower case.

Structures and unions shall be given names that start with an upper-case letter.

This standard can be extended to cover enumerated and class types by setting the modifier 204 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct lower  /* not compliant */
{
  CHAR c;
};
 
struct Upper
{
 CHAR c;
};
 
union lowerun /* not compliant */
{
 CHAR   cu;
 INT_16 iu;
};
 
typedef struct Upper lowstrtype;  /* not compliant */
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 221 S : Start of struct/union is lower case.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_221 (void)
{
  struct lower s;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 66  
JSF++ AV : 50   Modifiers : 204 = 1
LMTCP : 73  
222 S
Start of variable is upper case.

Variable names shall start with a lower-case letter (not including subsystems/package prefixes).

Example
typedef int INT;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 222 S : Start of variable is upper case.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT ok;
INT ok1,Notok1;
INT Ok2;
 
INT main(void){
  INT NOTOK3,ok3;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 70  
223 S
No prefix for global function.

Globally declared functions shall have a prefix. The prefix, which can be up to 6 characters, is specified as type 180 in the c/cppvals.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual. By default, the prefix is set to GLOBpx. 

180     GLOBpx              6 chars for global function prefix
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 223 S : No prefix for global function.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 func(INT_32 p){return 7;}              /* Not compliant */
 
INT_32 GLOBpx_func(INT_32 q){return 11;}     /* Compliant */
 
INT_32 main(void){
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
224 S
Start of enumeration is upper case.

Enumeration constant names should start with a lowercase letter (not including subsystem/package prefixes). Using the same naming conventions as for macros (or enumeration values) is allowed, provided that usage is consistent.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 224 S : Start of enumeration is upper case.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
enum { red, green, Blue};  /* not compliant - Blue */
 
void static_224 ( void )
{
    ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 52  
225 S
Inappropriate file extension.

C source code files should end with the extension '.c' and C header files with the extension '.h'.

C++ source code files should end with the extension '.cpp' and C++ header files with the extension '.hpp'.

Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 2.2.2  
LMTCP : 78  
226 S
Bit field is not octal, hex or suffix u.

Bit patterns shall be defined in hexadecimal or octal format or have a u suffix. In these formats the values are unsigned, which is what should be used in bit-wise operations.

Example
typedef unsigned UINT;
 
enum {won=1,too=2};
 
struct tag{
  UINT dec:2;     /* not compliant */
  UINT oct:02;
  UINT hex:0x3;
  UINT enumr:won; /* not compliant */
  UINT decu:3u;
};
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 226 S : Bit field is not octal, hex or suffix u.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void static_226 (void)
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
SEC-C : P1.3.3  
Related standards filter models
UML
227 S
Numeric bit operand is not octal,hex or u.

Bit patterns shall be defined in hexadecimal or octal format or have a u suffix. In these formats the values are unsigned, which is what should be used in bit-wise operations.

Example
typedef unsigned UINT;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 227 S : Numeric bit operand is not octal, hex or u.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_227 (void)
{
   UINT x=1, y;
   y = x & 20;   /* not compliant */
   y = x & 20u;
   y = x & 020;
   y = x & 0x20;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2002 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
228 S
Bracket mismatch ( or { in macro definition.

Macro definitions, where permitted, should be clearly structured with correctly balanced brackets. Heavy use of parentheses around arguments shall be used when defining macros to avoid surprises.

Example
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 228 S : Bracket mismatch ( or { in macro definition.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
/* Missing right parenthesis (!) in this macro definition of a 'common' symbolic constant */ 
 
#define COMMON_SYM_CONSTANT ((2U * 3U) + 2U
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
229 S
Bracket mismatch ) or } in macro definition.

Macro definitions, where permitted, should be clearly structured with correctly balanced brackets. Heavy use of parentheses around arguments shall be used when defining macros to avoid surprises.

Example
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 229 S : Bracket mismatch ) or } in macro definition.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
/* Missing left parenthesis (!) in this macro definition of a 'common' symbolic constant */ 
 
#define COMMON_SYM_CONSTANT 2U * 3U + 2U)
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
230 S
No copy constructor defined for class.

The compiler provides a default copy constructor, but this is not always appropriate because it does not initialise members that are of POD type.

Defining a minimal standard interface comprising: a default constructor; a copy constructor, a copy assignment operator and a destructor for all classes ensures a more maintainable and extensible implementation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 230 S : No copy constructor defined for class.
 ********************************************************/
 
class Person  /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person );
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
 
void static_230(void)
{
  Person p1(10U);
  Person q1(p1);  // invokes (compiler provided) copy constructor
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.1.13  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

231 S
No assignment operator defined for class.

The compiler will provide a default copy assignment operator, but is not always appropriate because it does not initialise members that are of POD type.

Defining a minimal standard interface comprising: a default constructor; a copy constructor, a copy assignment operator and a destructor for all classes ensures a more maintainable and extensible implementation. This standard checks for the presence of an assignment operator if a destructor or a copy constructor are present.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 231 S : No assignment operator defined for class.
 ***************************************************************/
 
class Person /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
 
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
 
void static_231(void)
{
  Person p1(10U);
  Person q1(p1);   // invokes (compiler provided) copy assignment constructor
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.1.13  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

232 S
No destructor defined for class.

The compiler provides a default destructor, but it is not always appropriate because it does not initialise members that are of POD type.

Defining a minimal standard interface comprising: a default constructor; a copy constructor, a copy assignment operator and a destructor for all classes ensures a more maintainable and extensible implementation.

Example

<code cpp Static_232.cpp>#include c_standards.h

/* * Standard 232 S : No destructor defined for class. */

class Person /* not compliant */ {

};

void static_232(void) {

}

/* * * Copyright 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates * */code>

Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 13  
HIC++ : 3.1.13  
LMTCP : 118  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

233 S
No copy constructor for class with pointers.

A copy constructor shall be declared for classes that manage resources, i.e. contain pointers to data items or nontrivial destructors.

The default copy constructor provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 233 S : No copy constructor for class with pointers.
 ***************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    CHAR *personName;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 personNum)
{
  personalNumber = personNum;
}
 
void static_233(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(p1);  // invokes (compiler provided) copy constructor 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 4  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
JSF++ AV : 76  
LMTCP : 117, 118  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

234 S
No assignment operator for class with pointers.

A copy assignment operator shall be declared for classes that manage resources, i.e. contain pointers to data items or non-trivial destructors.

The default assignment operator provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 234 S : No assignment operator for class with pointers.
 ******************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    CHAR *personName;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 personNum)
{
  personalNumber = personNum;
}
 
 
void static_234(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(10);
  q1 = p1;  // invokes (compiler provided) copy assignment constructor 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 4  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
JSF++ AV : 76  
LMTCP : 117, 118  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

235 S
No destructor for class with pointers.

A destructor shall be declared for classes that manage resources, i.e. contain pointers to data items.

The destructor should be declared because the implicit destructor will not release resources (normally dynamically allocated memory). Failure to release resources could result in resource leaks.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 235 S : No destructor for class with pointers.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
class Person /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person& person);
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    CHAR*personName;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 personNum)
{
  personalNumber = personNum;
}
 
 
void static_235(void)
{
  Person *p1 = new Person(10);
 
  // Statements...
 
  delete p1;  // invokes (compiler provided) destructor 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 4  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

236 S
New used in class without assignment op.

If a class uses new to allocate instances managed by the class, define an assignment operator.

Define or, at least, declare a copy assignment operator for classes which manage resources. The default assignment operator provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 236 S : New used in class without assignment op.
 *************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    UINT_32 *skillsList;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 personNum)
{
  personalNumber = personNum;
  skillsList = new UINT_32[10];  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
static void static_236(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(10);
  q1 = p1;  /* invokes (compiler provided) copy assignment constructor */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
LMTCP : 118  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

237 S
Assignment operator parameter not const.

The passed object reference shall not be modified by the copy assignment operator. Hence declare the (read-only) parameter as const in accordance with the general rule that const be used whenever possible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************************
 *  Standard 237 S : Assignment operator parameter not const.
 ************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(Person &person);  // should be a const parameter
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
Person &Person::operator=(Person &person)
{
  if (this != &person)
  {
    // Assignment code
  }
  return *this;
}
 
 
void static_237(void)
{
  Person p1(10U);
  Person q1(10U);
  q1 = p1;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

238 S
Number of templates exceeds ***.

The use of templates should be minimised. This standard checks that the number of templates does not exceed a pre-determined number. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 6. The configuration is made in the cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 *  Standard 238 S : Number of templates exceeds ***.
 ******************************************************/
 
 
template < class T >
class tplate1
{
  public:
    tplate1();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value1;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate2
{
  public:
    tplate2();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value2;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate3
{
  public:
    tplate3();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value3;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate4
{
  public:
    tplate4();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value4;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate5
{
  public:
    tplate5();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value5;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate6
{
  public:
    tplate6();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value6;
};
 
template < class T >
class tplate7        // This declaration causes a violation when
{                    // limit configured to 6. 
  public:
    tplate7();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 value7;
};
 
 
void static_238(void)
{
  // ...
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

239 S
New used in class without copy constructor.

If a class uses new to allocate instances of the class, then a copy constructor shall be defined.

Define or, at least, declare a copy constructor for classes which manage resources. The default copy constructor provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 239 S : New used in class without copy constructor.
 *************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    UINT_32 *skillsList;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 personNum)
{
  personalNumber = personNum;
  skillsList = new UINT_32[10];  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
static void static_239(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(p1);  /* invokes (compiler provided) copy constructor */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
LMTCP : 118  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

240 S
Use of dynamic_cast.

Dynamic casts shall not be used due to their dependency on run-time type information (for those casts resolved at run-time). Casts involving pointers/references from a base class to a derived class and casts between different derived classes are those casts that are made at run-time.

Example
/**********************************************
 * Standard 240 S : Use of dynamic_cast.
 **********************************************/
 
class Base
{
  public:
    Base();
    explicit Base(const Base &base);
    Base& operator=(const Base &base);
    virtual ~Base();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class Derived : public Base
{
  public:
    Derived();
    explicit Derived(const Derived &derived);
    Derived& operator=(const Derived &derived);
    virtual ~Derived();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class DifferentDerived : public Base
{
  public:
    DifferentDerived();
    explicit DifferentDerived(const DifferentDerived &dderived);
    DifferentDerived& operator=(const DifferentDerived &dderived);
    virtual ~DifferentDerived();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
 
static void static_240(void)
{
  Derived *d1 = new Derived;
  DifferentDerived *dd1 = dynamic_cast <DifferentDerived *> (d1); /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.12  
JSF++ AV : 185  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

241 S
Use of reinterpret_cast.

This is an unsafe cast as the result may not be well defined.

This standard is only enabled when the the # symbol is removed from the start of the line in the c/cppreport.dat file.

Example
/**********************************************
 * Standard 241 S : Use of reinterpret_cast.
 **********************************************/
 
class AClass
{
  public:
    AClass();
    explicit AClass(const AClass &ac);
    AClass& operator=(const AClass &ac);
    ~AClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class BClass
{
  public:
    BClass();
    explicit BClass(const BClass &ac);
    BClass& operator=(const BClass &ac);
    ~BClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
 
static void static_240(void)
{
  AClass *a1 = new AClass();
  BClass *b1 = reinterpret_cast <BClass *> (a1); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.12  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

242 S
Use of const_cast.

The supplied type and argument must be of the same type except for a const or volatile specifier. This cast is only used to add or remove constness from an object. However, removing constness should be avoided if possible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 242 S : Use of const_cast.
 **********************************************/
 
static void static_242(void)
{
   const char * c = "sample text";
   char *new_c;
   new_c = const_cast<char *>(c);  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.12  
HIC++ : 7.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-5  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

243 S
Included file not protected with #define.

A header file will contain a mechanism that prevents multiple inclusions of itself. The following styles are accepted by Testbed.

  1. A test for a name of the form #ifndef, #if !defined, #ifdef
  2. #define of the same name ( in #else section in the case of #ifdef )
  3. #endif
Example

Static_243.h

/************************************************************
 * Standard 243 S : Included file not protected with #define.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
/***
#ifndef STATIC_243_H
#define STATIC_243_H
***/ 
 
/* All declarations and definitions - should be excluded
   by the preprocessor if the file is included more than once. */ 
 
/***
#endif
***/ 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Static_243.c

#include "Static_243.h"
/* not compliant */
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 243 S : Included file not protected with #define.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
 static void static_243 ( void )
 {
	 ;
 }
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : PRE06-C  
CWE : 735  
EADS-C : 9  
FSB582-C : 2.3.2  
FSB582-C++ : 3.6
