HIC++ : 14.11  
JSF++ AV : 27, 35  
LMTCP : 33, 50  
MISRA-AC : 19.15  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-2-3

Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
244 S
new or delete overloaded.

The new and delete operators shall not be overloaded. Customising memory management by implementing different behaviour from the standard versions of the new and delete operators is considered dangerous.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 244 S : new or delete overloaded.
 **********************************************/
 
class X
{
  public:
    X();
    ~X();
    static void *operator new(const UINT_32 size); /* not compliant */
    static void operator delete(void*);           /* not compliant */
    explicit X(const X &xx);
    X & operator=(const X &xx);
  protected:
  private:
};
 
static void static_244(void)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

245 S
Case statement in nested block.

The scope of a case or default label shall always be the compound statement which is the body of the switch statement. All case clauses and the default clause shall be at the same scope. Furthermore, every switch statement shall have at least one case clause.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef enum Choice
{
  first,
  second,
  third,
  fourth
} Choice;
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 245 S : Case statement in nested block.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 a1 = 1;
INT_32 errorflag = 0;
 
static void static_245(Choice chooser)
{
  INT_32 b1 = 2;
  INT_32 c1 = 1;
 
  switch (chooser)
  {
    case first:
      a1 = b1;
      break;
    case second:  /* flow through to next case label */ 
    case third:
      a1 = c1;
      if (a1 == b1)
      {
        /* case is not allowed here - not compliant */ 
        case fourth:
      }
      break;
    default:
      errorflag = 1;
      break;
  }
}
 
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.9.2.1  
LMTCP : 343, 348  
MISRA-AC : 15.1, 15.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.1, 15.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.2  
SEC-C : M1.3.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
246 S
Class has missing access specifiers.

Public, protected and private sections (in that order) shall be specified explicitly in the class declaration.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 246 S : Class has missing access specifiers.
 *******************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
}; /* not compliant */
 
void static_246(void)
{
  // Statements... 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

247 S
Macro definition calls itself.

An invocation of a macro definition contains, as its parameter, a nested call to itself.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 247 S : Macro definition calls itself.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#define COMMON_MACRO(X) (ANOTHER_MACRO(X))
 
#define SOME_MACRO(X) (NESTED_MACRO1(X))
#define NESTED_MACRO1(X) (NESTED_MACRO2(X))
#define NESTED_MACRO2(X) (COMMON_MACRO(X))
#define ANOTHER_MACRO(X) (X)
 
const SINT_32 s1 = 42;
 
void static_247(void)
{
  SINT_32 myInt = COMMON_MACRO(SOME_MACRO(s1)); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JPL : 8  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
248 S
Divide by zero in preprocessor directive.

A preprocessor directive has the potential to cause a divide by zero run-time failure. Explicit coding checks should be used to handle run-time faults.

Example
/************************************************************
 * Standard 248 S : Divide by zero in preprocessor directive.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
#define DEBUG2 2
#define DEBUG1 0
 
#define COMMON_MACRO(X,Y) ((X)/(Y))
 
#if (COMMON_MACRO(DEBUG2,DEBUG1)) == 1   /* not compliant */
  /* ....  */ 
#endif
 
void static_248(void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT33-C  
CWE : 369, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-3-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
249 S
Operation not appropriate to boolean type.

The performed operation on a boolean type is not appropriate.

Other inappropriate boolean operations are covered by 136 S, 389 S and 402 S. This standard covers >>, << and postfix ++ and -- operators.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 249 S : Operation not appropriate to boolean type.
 *************************************************************/
 
static void static_249 (void)
{
  BOOL bvar = FALSE;
  bvar ++;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 12.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
250 S
Cyclic included file nesting found.

An include file "abc.h" contains an include for a file "xyz.h" which in return includes the first file "abc.h".

This standard is not available if "SHORTEN" is set to TRUE, which is the default value.

Related standards filter models
Legacy
251 S
Use of stdio.h instead of iostream.h.

Function declarations in stdio.h, defined in the C function libraries, should not be used in C++ programs. The iostream.h standard header file shall be used in preference.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>  /* not compliant */
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 251 S : Use of stdio.h instead of iostream.h.
 *******************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
static void static_251(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

252 S
Lower case suffix to literal number.

Literal suffixes shall use uppercase rather than lowercase letters for readability.

This standard can be relaxed to check only l by setting the modifier 418 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 252 S : Lower case suffix to literal number.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
const SINT_64 fr1 = 64l; /* not compliant - looks too much like 641 */ 
const SINT_64 fr2 = 64L; /* compliant */ 
 
void static_252(void)
{
  SINT_64 x1 = fr2;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 23, 24  
HIC++ : 6.1, 6.2  
JSF++ AV : 14  
LMTCP : 14  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-13-4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.7.3   Modifiers : 418 = 1
SEC-C : M1.2.2   Modifiers : 418 = 1
253 S
Opposite type operator missing.

An overloaded operator has been declared without its corresponding opposite type. For consistency, paired operators, such as < and >= shall both be overloaded together.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************
 * Standard 253 S : Opposite type operator missing.
 **************************************************/
 
class X
{
   public:
     X();
     bool operator <(const SINT_32 val) const; /* not compliant */
 
   protected:
   private:
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 8.2  
LMTCP : 130  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

254 S
Operator = doesn't return reference to *this.

The copy assignment operator shall return a reference to this.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 254 S : Operator = doesn't return reference to *this.
 ****************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
 
    // by making return type const, cannot return ref to *this
    const Person & operator=(const Person &person); /* not compliant */
 
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
 
void static_254(void)
{
  Person p1(10U);
  Person q1(11U);
  q1 = p1;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 8.3  
HIC++ : 3.1.5  
JSF++ AV : 82  
LMTCP : 121, 127  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

255 S
Found #if, #ifdef, #else, #elif .

Only the #ifndef, #define, #endif, and #include pre-processor directives shall be used. The use of the pre-processor should be limited to these directives in cases where it is necessary, e.g. to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file.

Example
#define DEBUG 1
#define DEBUG_ERROR 1
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 255 S : Found #if, #ifdef, #else, #elif.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#if DEBUG == 1
	 /* not compliant */ 
#ifdef DEBUG_ERROR
	 /* not compliant */ 
#endif
#elif DEBUG == 2
	 /* not compliant */ 
#else
	 /*not compliant */ 
#endif
 
void static_255(void)
{
	 /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.11.2  
JSF++ AV : 26  
LMTCP : 32  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-2-1  
256 S
Procedure exceeds *** source lines of code.

A procedure will contain no more than the specified pre-determined maximum number of logical lines of code. Long procedures tend to be complex and therefore difficult to comprehend and test.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 200. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Instead of counting logical lines, the number of pure source lines can be counted by setting the modifier 203 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. This will exclude blank or comment lines. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 115  
FSB582-C : 3.7.8  
FSB582-C++ : 6.7  
JPL : 4  
JSF++ AV : 1   Modifiers : 203 = 1
LMTCP : 1  
NETRINO : 6.2.a  
257 S
Filename in #include not in < > .

The #include directive shall use the <filename.h> notation to include header files. Although "filename.h" is typically used to include local header files, due to the divergence in vendor implementations, only the <filename.h> form will be used. For files not located in the source directory, relative pathnames may also be used.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 257 S : Filename in #include not in < >.
 * A/Ref:
 ********************************************************/ 
 
#include <foo.h>            /* Good */ 
#include "anotherFoo.h"     /* Bad: "filename.h" form used */ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 33  
LMTCP : 51.1  
258 S
More than one class in header file.

Each class declaration should be held in a separate header file.

Example
#ifndef STATIC_258_H
#define STATIC_258_H
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 258 S : More than one class in header file.
 *********************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
class MalePerson : public Person
{
  public:
    MalePerson();
    explicit MalePerson(const UINT_32 personNum);
    MalePerson(const UINT_32 personNum,
               const UINT_16 weight);
    explicit MalePerson(const MalePerson &mperson);
    MalePerson & operator=(const MalePerson &mperson);
    ~MalePerson();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_16 weightAmount;
};
 
#endif
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 3.3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

259 S
Statement not on new line (added by Testbed).

For the sake of simplicity, readability and style, each statement shall be placed on a separate new line. Testbed inserts the required carriage return into the reformatted code to permit instrumentation. This LDRA penalty is not applicable to code substituted into the source through macro expansion, as these checks are based on the original code and do not extend to macro definitions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 259 S : Statement not on new line (added by Testbed).
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_259(void)
{
  UINT_32 x1;
  SINT_32 y1;
  x1 = 5U; y1 =7;  /* not compliant. multiple expression statements on the same line. */ 
  y1 = 3;          /* compliant */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.3.6  
FSB582-C++ : 10.7  
JPL : 4  
JSF++ AV : 42  
LMTCP : 65  
260 S
No default constructor declared for class.

The compiler will provide a default constructor, but is not always appropriate because it does not initialise members that are of POD type. Defining a minimal standard interface comprising: a default constructor; a copy constructor, a copy assignment operator and a destructor for all classes ensures a more maintainable and extensible implementation.

This standard can be relaxed so that it only applies to classes with virtual functions by setting the modifier 205 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 260 S : No default constructor declared for class.
 **************************************************************/
 
class Person  /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    Person(const UINT_32 pNumber);  // Single parameter constructor...
                                    // but no default constructor. 
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
static void static_260(void)
{
  ; /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.13  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

262 S
Non virtual function redefined.

Overloading or hiding non-virtual member functions can result in unexpected behaviour as non-virtual functions are statically bound. This results in the declaration type of the pointer or reference determining the selection of member functions and not what the pointer or reference is actually pointing at.

This standard can be further restricted to check for overloaded members with differing parameter types by setting the modifier 379 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 262 S : Non virtual function redefined.
 **************************************************************/
 
class Base
{
  public:
    void myFunc(void);
};
 
class Derived : public Base
{
  public:
    void myFunc(void);   /* not compliant */
};
 
void someFunc(void)
{
  Derived derived;
  Base *base_ptr = &derived;
  Derived *derived_ptr = &derived;
 
  base_ptr->myFunc();    // Calls Base::myFunc despite pointing at Derived object! 
  derived_ptr->myFunc();
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.11  
JSF++ AV : 94   Modifiers : 379 = 1
LMTCP : 140  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

263 S
Namespace prohibited.

This standard checks for the use of C++ namespaces.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 263 S : Namespace prohibited.
 ********************************************************/
 
namespace MySpace1 /* not compliant */
{
  class MyString
  {
    // ...
  };
}
 
void static_263 ( void )
{
    ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

264 S
Class template prohibited.

The use of class templates is prohibited as they are regarded as dangerous.

Example
/***************************************************
 *  Standard 264 S : Class template prohibited.
 ***************************************************/
 
template <class Atype> class tplate /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    tplate ();
    Atype getvalue ();
    void setvalue (Atype val);
  protected:
  private:
    Atype value;
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

265 S
Function template prohibited.

The use of function templates is prohibited as they are regarded as dangerous.

Example
#include <vector>
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 265 S : Function template prohibited.
 *******************************************************/
 
template <class Tplate> void sort(std::vector <Tplate> array ); /* not compliant */
 
static void static_265(std::vector <int> &iv)
{
  sort(iv);  // invoke sort(vector <int> )
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

266 S
Constructor defined within class declaration.

Constructors should not be implicitly inlined by defining them in the class body. Inline functions that invoke other inline functions often become too complex for the compiler to handle - this is especially true of constructors and destructors.

Example
typedef unsigned Uint_32;
 
//
// Standard 266 S : Constructor defined within class declaration.
// A/Ref: 6.1.9.5
// 
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    Uint_32 personalNumber;
  public:
    explicit Person(const Uint_32 pNumber)    // Constructor definition 
    {
      personalNumber = pNumber;
    }
};
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 7.3  
HIC++ : 3.1.6  
LMTCP : 225  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

267 S
Hexadecimal number with lower case char.

Hexadecimal constants will be represented using all upper case letters.

This standard can be relaxed so as to allow a lower case x by setting the modifier 208 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 267 S : Hexadecimal number with lower case char.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
typedef enum mask_enum_type
{
  mask_first = 0X01,
  mask_all = 0xff    /* not compliant */
} mask_enum_type;
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 150   Modifiers : 208 = 1
LMTCP : 271   Modifiers : 208 = 1
268 S
Empty initialisation exprsn in for loop.

Null initialise expressions in for loops will not be used; a while loop will be used instead.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 268 S : Empty initialisation exprsn in for loop.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Uint_32 loop;
  Uint_32 myVar = 0;
  const Uint_32 max = 10U;
  /* ... */ 
  for (; loop < max; loop++)
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 165  
JSF++ AV : 200  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
269 S
Empty increment exprsn in for loop.

The 3rd clause in a for loop should not be empty when there is a test in the 2nd clause, as it is not clear to the user how the loop counter is changed. A while loop should be used instead of a for loop if there is no loop counter.

This standard can be further restricted to prohibit an empty 3rd clause if the 2nd clause is empty by setting the modifier 424 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. An exception is made for for loops where all the clauses are empty.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 269 S : Empty increment exprsn in for loop.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_269(void)
{
  UINT_32 loop;
  UINT_32 myVar = 0U;
  const UINT_32 max = 10U;
 
  for (loop = 0U; loop < max;)  /* not compliant  */
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 165   Modifiers : 424 = 1
HIS : 66  
JSF++ AV : 200   Modifiers : 424 = 1
LMTCP : 350, 352  
MISRA-AC : 13.5   Modifiers : 424 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 66  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5   Modifiers : 424 = 1
SEC-C : M3.3.1   Modifiers : 424 = 1
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
270 S
For loop initialisation is not simple.

The initialisation expression in a for loop will perform no actions other than to initialise the value of a single for loop parameter.

This standard can be relaxed to permit function calls in the initialisation expression of a for loop by setting the modifier 249 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 270 S : For loop initialisation is not simple.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_270(void)
{
  UINT_32 loop;
  UINT_32 myVar = 0U;
  const UINT_32 max = 10U;
 
  for ( ++myVar, loop = 0U; loop < max; loop++ ) /* not compliant */
  {
    /* ... */
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIS : 66  
JSF++ AV : 198   Modifiers : 249 = 1
LMTCP : 351   Modifiers : 249 = 1
MISRA-AC : 13.5   Modifiers : 249 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 66  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5   Modifiers : 249 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2   Modifiers : 249 = 1
SEC-C : M3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
271 S
For loop incrementation is not simple.

The increment expression in a for loop will perform no action other than to change a single loop parameter using the ++ or operators. The loop parameter must be a variable with a simple integer or float type.

If MISRA-C++:2008 checking is enabled, the behaviour is modified so that += and -= are permitted, providing the increment step remains constant.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 271 S : For loop incrementation is not simple.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_271(void)
{
  UINT_32 loop;
  UINT_32 myVar = 0U;
  const UINT_32 max = 10U;
 
  for (loop = 0U; loop < max; myVar++, loop++) /* not compliant - 2 loops parameters */
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 9.3  
HIS : 66  
JSF++ AV : 199  
LMTCP : 351  
MISRA-AC : 13.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-5-4   Modifiers : 331 = 1
MISRA-C:1998 : 66  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2  
SEC-C : M3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
272 S
Found #ifndef (ref. removed).

The #ifndef and #endif pre-processor directives shall only be used as part of the technique to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file. It is preferable to use code rather than the #ifndef pre-processor directive in all other cases.

Any #ifndef and #endif pre-processor directives that are not used to prevent multiple inclusions will be removed in the reformatted text (ref. removed).

Example

Static_272.h

#ifndef STATIC_272_H
#define STATIC_272_H
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 272 S : Found #ifndef (ref. removed).
 ************************************************/ 
 
/* not compliant */
#ifndef REPORT_ERRORS
#define REPORT_WARNINGS
#endif
 
/* All declarations and definitions - excluded
   by the preprocessor if the file is included more than once. */ 
 
#endif
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.11.2  
JSF++ AV : 28  
LMTCP : 34  
273 S
Found #define.

The #define pre-processor directive shall only be used as part of the technique to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file. Using #define for inline macros and constants shall be avoided.

Example
#ifndef STATIC_273_H
#define STATIC_273_H
 
/*************************************
 * Standard 273 S : Found #define.
 *************************************/ 
 
/* not compliant */
#define MYSQMACRO ((X) * (X))
 
/* All declarations and definitions - excluded
   by the preprocessor if the file is included more than once. */ 
 
#endif
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 31  
LMTCP : 37  
274 S
Name found with length less than ***.

In order that an identifier name be meaningful, it must be no shorter than the specified pre-determined minimum length.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 274 S : Name found with length less than ***.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Uint_32 x;            /* Avoid - too short to be meaningful */ 
  Uint_32 yCoordinate;  /* Okay - a meaningful name */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 8.1.1  
EADS-C : 37  
FSB582-C : 3.2.3  
GJB : 4.8.1.1  
NETRINO : 6.2.f, 7.1.e  
Related standards filter models
UML
275 S
Tag missing in struct, union or enum.

Omission of a tag has the disadvantage that no further definitions of the structure, union or enum may be made later in the program code. Without a tag, the declaration cannot be referred to and definitions are not possible.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 275 S : Tag missing in struct, union or enum.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
struct             /* not compliant - tag missing */ 
{
  UINT_32 x_value;
  UINT_32 y_value;
} pos_var;
 
struct Position    /* compliant - struct tag included, allowing multiple definitions */ 
{
  UINT_32 anon_x_value;
  UINT_32 anon_y_Value;
};
 
void static_275(void)
{
  pos_var.x_value = 0U;
  pos_var.y_value = 0U;
 
  struct Position first_pos = {1U, 1U};
  struct Position second_pos = {2U, 1U};
  /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
276 S
Case is not part of switch enumeration.

The switch statement contains a case constant expression which is not part of the switch chooser enumerated list of values. Case values shall be restricted to those identified in the enumeration.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
typedef enum Seasons
{
  spring,
  summer,
  autumn,
  winter
} Seasons;
 
Seasons season;
Uint_32 x1;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 276 S : Case is not part of switch enumeration.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  switch (season)
  {
    case spring:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    case summer:
      x1 = 4U;
      break;
    case autumn:
      x1 = 7U;
      break;
    case 4:
      x1 = 10U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
GJB : 5.1.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
277 S
Switch chooser is not an enumeration.

The switch chooser shall be an enumeration so that the list of possible values are well-defined and that the switch statement may be checked to cater for all expected cases.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
Uint_32 season;
Uint_32 x1;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 277 S : Switch chooser is not an enumeration.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  switch (season)
  {
    case 1:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    case 2:
      x1 = 4U;
      break;
    case 3:
      x1 = 7U;
      break;
    case 4:
      x1 = 10U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
278 S
Switch has missing or extra cases.

There is a mismatch between the defined enumerated value list and the cases catered for by the switch statement. All switch statements that do not intend to test for every enumeration value shall, at least, contain a final default clause.

This standard can be relaxed to allow switch statements that do not test for every enumeration value, but have a default clause. This is done by setting the modifier 233 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef enum Seasons
{
  spring,
  summer,
  autumn,
  winter
} Seasons;
 
Seasons season;
UINT_32 x1;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 278 S : Switch has missing or extra cases.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_278(void)
{
  switch (season)  /* not compliant */
  {
    case spring:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    case summer:
      x1 = 4U;
      break;
    case autumn:
      x1 = 7U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.17  
CMSE : 3.1.9  
GJB : 5.1.6  
HIC++ : 5.11  
JSF++ AV : 194   Modifiers : 233 = 1
LMTCP : 357  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
279 S
Try keyword found.

Exceptions shall not be used. The use of exceptions can lead to unexpected code branches, especially in library code which was not designed to handle exceptions. Also, other code may generate unexpected exceptions for which there is no handler.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************
 * Standard 279 S : Try keyword found.
 **************************************/
 
static void f(void)
{
  // ...
  // UINT_32 type exception thrown here
  // ...
}
 
static void static_279 (void)
{ 
  try  /* not compliant */
  {
    f();
  }
  catch (UINT_32 u )
  {
    // ...
    // handle UINT_32 exceptions here...
    // ...
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 35  
JSF++ AV : 208  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

280 S
Catch keyword found.

Exceptions shall not be used. The use of exceptions can lead to unexpected code branches, especially in library code which was not designed to handle exceptions. Also, other code may generate unexpected exceptions for which there is no handler.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************
 * Standard 280 S : Catch keyword found.
 **************************************/
 
static void f(void)
{
  // ...
  // UINT_32 type exception thrown here
  // ...
}
 
static void static_280 (void)
{
  try
  {
    f();
  }
  catch (UINT_32 u ) /* not compliant */
  {
    // ...
    // handle UINT_32 exceptions here...
    // ...
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 35  
FSB582-C++ : 1.15, 1.17  
JSF++ AV : 208  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

281 S
Throw keyword found.

Exceptions shall not be used. The use of exceptions can lead to unexpected code branches, especially in library code which was not designed to handle exceptions. Also, other code may generate unexpected exceptions for which there is no handler.

Example
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 281 S : Throw keyword found.
 *************************************************************/
 
static void static_281(void)
{
  try
  {
    throw 20; /* not compliant */
  }
  catch (int e)
  {
    // ...
    // handle int exceptions here...
    // ...
 
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 35  
FSB582-C++ : 1.15, 1.17  
JSF++ AV : 208  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

282 S
Mutable keyword found.

Avoid the use of mutable where possible. The 'mutable' keyword can be used to declare member data which can be modified in const functions, this should only be used where the member data does not affect the externally visible state of the object.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
//
// Standard 282 S : Mutable keyword found.
// A/Ref:
// 
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const Uint_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
    Uint_32 bar(void) const;
  protected:
  private:
    Uint_32 personalNumber;
    mutable Uint_32 pNum;
};
 
Uint_32 Person::bar(void) const
{
  // ... 
  // ok to amend pNum here, even though this is a const member function 
  // ... 
  return pNum;
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 6  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

283 S
Multiple direct inheritance found.

Multiple direct inheritance describes an inheritance structure where more than one direct base class appears in the base list of a derived class declaration. Multiple inheritance can lead to complicated inheritance hierarchies that are difficult to comprehend and maintain.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the following forms by setting the modifier 378 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file:

  • private inheritance
  • 1 protected inheritance
  • public inheritance if all members are pure virtual functions, except for the destructor

Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
/******************************************************
 * Standard 283 S : Multiple direct inheritance found.
 ******************************************************/
 
class AClass
{
  public:
    AClass();
    explicit AClass(const AClass &ac);
    AClass& operator=(const AClass &ac);
    ~AClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class AAClass
{
  public:
    AAClass();
    explicit AAClass(const AAClass &aac);
    AAClass& operator=(const AAClass &aac);
    ~AAClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class BClass : public AClass,  // not compliant
               public AAClass  // direct multiple inheritance 
{
  public:
    BClass();
    explicit BClass(const BClass &bc);
    BClass& operator=(const BClass &bc);
    ~BClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class CClass : public BClass  // indirect multiple inheritance 
{
  public:
    CClass();
    explicit CClass(const CClass &cc);
    CClass& operator=(const CClass &cc);
    ~CClass();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 60  
HIC++ : 3.4.6  
JSF++ AV : 88   Modifiers : 378 = 1
LMTCP : 133  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

284 S
Cast preceded by a cast.

A cast preceded by a cast is likely to result in a redundant stage of conversion in the statement.

Example
typedef unsigned short Uint_16;
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
typedef unsigned long Uint_64;
 
/*******************************************
 * Standard 284 S : Cast preceded by a cast.
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************/ 
 
void foo(Uint_16 original)
{
  Uint_64 myInt;
 
  myInt = (Uint_64)(Uint_32)original;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
285 S
Class definition not needed in file.

Declarations of classes should not be included unless they are used. Classes for which member definitions have been provided, or contain a class, or are nested within another class, or used as a base, are exempt from this standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 285 S : Class definition not needed in file.
 ******************************************************/
 
class Person   /* not compliant */
{
  public:
    Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
 
void static_285( void )
{
  // Statements... 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 38  
LMTCP : 56, 138  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

286 S
Functions defined in header file.

Header files shall not contain function definitions. A definition may not be suitable for all files which include the header file.

Header files should typically contain interface declarations - not implementation details.

This standard can be relaxed to allow inline definitions in header files by setting the modifier 238 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example

Static_286.h

#ifndef STATIC_286_H
#define STATIC_286_H
 
/* Some declarations... */ 
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 286 S : Functions defined in header file.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void static_286_header(void)  /* not compliant */
{
  /* Statements... */ 
}
 
#endif
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 2.3.1  
FSB582-C++ : 3.8   Modifiers : 238 = 1
JSF++ AV : 39   Modifiers : 238 = 1
LMTCP : 57, 204   Modifiers : 238 = 1
MISRA-AC : 8.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-1-1   Modifiers : 238 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.5  
NETRINO : 4.2.c  
SEC-C : M4.4.5  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
287 S
Variable definition in header file.

Header files shall not contain variable definitions. A definition may not be suitable for all files which include the header file. Header files should typically contain interface declarations - not implementation details.

This standard can be relaxed to allow const declarations by setting the modifier 250 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example

Static_287.h

#ifndef STATIC_287_H
#define STATIC_287_H
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 287 S : Variable definition in header file.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
const UINT_32 const_var = 99U;  /* not compliant, but permitted with modifier 250 */ 
UINT_32 myVar = 3U;             /* not compliant */ 
 
#endif
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 2.3.1  
FSB582-C++ : 3.8  
JSF++ AV : 39   Modifiers : 250 = 1
LMTCP : 57, 204   Modifiers : 250 = 1
MISRA-AC : 8.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-1-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.5  
NETRINO : 4.2.c  
SEC-C : M4.4.5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
288 S
Header file is not .h.

By convention, header files shall end with the extension '.h'.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the '.hpp' extension by setting the modifier 301 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example

Static_288.x

/* Header file ends in "x" */

Static_288.hpp

/* Header file ends in "hpp" */

Static_288.c

#include "Static_288.x"   /* not compliant */
#include "Static_288.hpp" /* not compliant, but permitted by modifier 301 */
 
/*****************************************
 * Standard 288 S : Header file is not .h.
 *****************************************/
 
static void static_288 ( void )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 13  
FSB582-C : 2.2.2, 3.11.1   Modifiers : 301 = 1
FSB582-C++ : 3.1   Modifiers : 301 = 1
JSF++ AV : 32, 53  
LMTCP : 38, 76  
NETRINO : 4.1.b, 4.3.f  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
289 S
Header file name does not include class name.

Each header file shall include no more than one class declaration (see S 258), and, if it does indeed contain a single class declaration, the header file name should reflect its content by containing the name of that class. Underscores and case are ignored when comparing the class and header file name.

S 290 provides a similar check on a source file containing a class definition.

Example

Static_289.h

#ifndef STATIC_289_H
#define STATIC_289_H
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 289 S : Header file name does not include class name.
 ****************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
#endif
/* not compliant - filename does not include class name */

Static_289.cpp

#include "Static_289.h"
 
static void static_289(void)
{
 ; /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 3.2  
JSF++ AV : 55  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

290 S
File name does not contain defined class name.

Source code files that contain the definition of a particular class (or struct) shall have a name that reflects the content and contain the defined class name. Note, that for files that contain definitions for more than one class, or specialisations of a templated class, this penalty is not applicable. Underscores and case are ignored when comparing the class and source file name.

289 S provides a similar check on a header file containing a class declaration.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 290 S : File name does not contain defined class name.
 *
 * Filename is Static_290.cpp
 ****************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    UINT_32 get_number ( void ) { return number; } /* not compliant */
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 number;
};
 
static void static_290(void)
{
 ; /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 3.2  
JSF++ AV : 56  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

291 S
First parameter not on same line as function.

When declaring and defining functions, the leading parenthesis and the first argument will be written on the same line as the function name. Each additional argument will be written on a separate line (with the closing parenthesis directly after the last argument) to promote readability and a consistent style.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
//
// Standard 291 S : First parameter not on same line as function.
// A/Ref:
// 
 
void someFunc(
         Uint_32 &firstParam,
         Uint_32 &secondParam)
{
  // Statements ...
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 6.6  
JSF++ AV : 58  
LMTCP : 83  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

292 S
No space between #include and filename.

The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or filename sequence, and separated by a space.

Example
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 292 S : No space between #include and filename.
 **********************************************************/ 
 
#include <foo.h>          /* compliant */ 
#include<anotherFoo.h>    /* not compliant: no space */ 
 
static void static_292 (void)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 19.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-2-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.3  
SEC-C : P1.4.1  
Related standards filter models
UML
293 S
Non ANSI/ISO construct used.

All code constructs shall be ANSI/ISO compliant, i.e. conform to the ISO C/C++ Standard.

In order to support portability and compiler compatibility, avoid compiler specific language or pre-processor extensions.

To enable this penalty the user must indicate to what extent the check should be performed. The c/cppvals.dat file provides a mechanism to select specific extensions to the language through the 165 record entry. For example, extensions supported under a particular language dialect may be checked in isolation:

165    4GREEN         4 indicates dialect-specific, and GREEN (Green Hills) is the name of the dialect
Example
/*****************************************
 * Standard 293 S : Non ANSI/ISO construct used.
 ***************************************************/
 
  /* cvals.dat has entry "GREEN   35  10 __inline__",
     which indicates __inline__ is used by the GREEN dialect */
 
__inline__ void check_ansi(void) /* non-compliant if GREEN dialect selected */
{
   ;
}
 
void static_293 ( void )
{
    check_ansi ( );
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 135  
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
HIC++ : 13.4  
HIS : 1  
JSF++ AV : 8  
LMTCP : 8, 402, 403  
MISRA-AC : 1.1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.2  
NETRINO : 1.1.a, 1.1.b  
SEC-C : P1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , UML
294 S
Namespace nested more than *** deep.

Namespaces will not be nested more than a pre-determined maximum number of levels deep. Deeply nested namespaces can be difficult to comprehend and use correctly.

Example
//
// Standard 294 S : Namespace nested more than *** deep.
// 
 
namespace MySpace1L1
{
  namespace MySpace1L2
  {
    namespace MySpace1L3
    {
      class MyString
      {
        public:
          // ...
        protected:
          //...
        private:
          //...
      };
    }
  }
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 99  
LMTCP : 157  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

295 S
Use of digraph.

Digraphs are special two character sequences that are translated into specific single characters like { or #.

Digraphs, and specifically the alternatives for: { } [ ] # ##, will not be used. The use of digraphs leads to poor readability of code.

Example
/************************************
 * Standard 295 S : Use of digraph.
 ************************************/ 
 
static void static_295(void)
<%   /* Represents {  */
 
  /* ...  */
 
%>  /* Represents } */
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 52  
HIC++ : 14.18  
JSF++ AV : 12  
LMTCP : 13  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-5-1  
Related standards filter models
UML
296 S
Function declared at block scope.

Functions shall always be declared at file scope. Declaring functions at block scope may be confusing, and can lead to undefined behaviour.

Example
/****************************************************
 * Standard 296 S : Function declared at block scope.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  void bar(void);
 
  /* Statements ... */
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
HIS : 68  
JSF++ AV : 107  
LMTCP : 202  
MISRA-AC : 8.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-1-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 68  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , UML
297 S
Inline member has more than *** source lines.

Only declare trivial functions 'inline'. Limit inline member functions to the pre-determined maximum number of source lines. Inline functions do not necessarily improve performance and they can have a negative effect. Inappropriate use will lead to longer compilation times, slower runtime performance and larger binaries.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard, defaulting to 2. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const UINT_32 agelimit = 18U;
const UINT_32 junior = 0U;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 297 S : Inline member has more than *** source lines.
 ****************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
  public:
    void adjustNum(void)
    {
      if (personalNumber < agelimit)
      {
        personalNumber =
          junior;
      }
    }  /* not compliant */
};
 
 
static void static_297(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  p1.adjustNum();
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 5.1  
HIC++ : 3.1.6, 11.8  
LMTCP : 222  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

298 S
Non const pointer to function.

Non const pointers to functions shall not be used. There is a danger that a pointer whose value is calculated at run-time, may, due to an error, point to an arbitrary location.

Furthermore pointers to functions cause problems with dependence on the order in which function-designator and function arguments are evaluated when calling functions.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
Uint_32 drawline(Uint_32 length);
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 298 S : Non const pointer to function.
 * A/Ref: 6.1.6.6
 *************************************************/ 
 
/*
 * Define a pointer to a function
 * with an 'unsigned int' as a parameter.
 */ 
 
typedef Uint_32 (*fptr)(Uint_32 len);  /* Should be const */ 
 
/* Now assign a function address to the pointer... */ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /* Invoke the function through the function pointer... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
NETRINO : 1.8.b  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
299 S
Pointer to function declared without typedef.

A typedef will be used to simplify program syntax when declaring function pointers.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
Uint_32 drawline(Uint_32 length);
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 299 S : Pointer to function declared without typedef.
 * A/Ref: 6.1.6.4
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
/*
 * Define a pointer to a function
 * with an 'unsigned int' as a parameter.
 */ 
 
Uint_32 (*fptr)(Uint_32 len);  /* Should be a typedef */ 
 
/* Now assign a function address to the pointer... */ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /* Invoke the function through the function pointer... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL05-C  
CWE : 736  
JSF++ AV : 176  
LMTCP : 319  
Related standards filter models
UML
300 S
Filename extension is not .cpp.

C++ source code files shall end with the extension '.cpp'.

Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 3.1  
JSF++ AV : 54, 56  
LMTCP : 78  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

301 S
} not aligned vertically below {.

When using braces to define the structure of the code, matching pairs shall be vertically aligned in the same column.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
const Uint_32 limit = 32U;
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 301 S : } not aligned vertically below {.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void foo(Uint_32 myParam)
{
  if (myParam > limit)
  {
    myParam = limit;
 
}
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 143  
FSB582-C : 3.3.1, 3.3.2, 3.3.8, 3.7.5  
FSB582-C++ : 9.18, 10.1, 10.3  
JSF++ AV : 60  
LMTCP : 85  
NETRINO : 1.3.b  
302 S
Comment possibly contains code.

Code that is not used (commented out) shall be deleted unless it is part of an explanation. The block commenting of code can lead to the inadvertent omission of more than was intended.

It is not always possible to tell the difference between natural language text and c/cpp program text, therefore from time to time natural language text will be flagged up as code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const UINT_32 limit = 32U;
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 302 S : Comment possibly contains code.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void static_302 (UINT_32 myParam)
{
  if (myParam > limit)
  {
    myParam = limit;
    /* myParam--;*/ /* not compliant */
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC04-C  
CMSE : 10.2.1  
CWE : 747  
DERA : 10  
EADS-C : 32, 168  
FSB582-C++ : 11.3  
GJB : 4.10.2.1  
HIS : 10  
JSF++ AV : 127  
LMTCP : 238  
MISRA-AC : 2.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-7-2, 2-7-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 10  
MISRA-C:2004 : 2.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.4  
NETRINO : 2.1.c  
SEC-C : M1.1.2  
Related standards filter models
UML
303 S
Virtual class members need virtual destructor.

All base classes with a virtual function shall define a virtual destructor. If the base class destructor is not virtual, and an attempt to destroy an object (of a derived class) is made through a pointer to its base class, the destructor for the base class will be invoked rather than the derived base class destructor.

In most cases, destructors should be virtual, because maintenance or reuse may add derived classes that require a virtual destructor.

By default, the violation is associated with the base class, but it can be associated with the derived classes by by setting the modifier 292 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
/*****************************************************************
 * Standard 303 S : Virtual class members need virtual destructor.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
class Base
{
  public:
    Base();
    explicit Base(const Base &base);
    Base & operator=(const Base &base);
    virtual void myFunc(void);
    ~Base();  // should be virtual... 
  protected:
  private:
};  /* not compliant */
 
class Derived : public Base
{
  public:
    Derived();
    explicit Derived(const Derived &derived);
    Derived & operator=(const Derived &derived);
    virtual void myFunc(void);
    virtual ~Derived();
  protected:
  private:
};  
 
void static_303(void)
{
  Derived *derived_ptr =  new Derived();
  Base *base_ptr = derived_ptr;
 
  //... 
 
  delete base_ptr;  // Does not call derived destructor! 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 14  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.3.2  
JSF++ AV : 78   Modifiers : 292 = 1
LMTCP : 123   Modifiers : 292 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

304 S
Arithmetic performed on unsigned values.

Arithmetic on unsigned values shall not be performed. This avoids potential mixed arithmetic or comparison operations between unsigned and signed values.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const UINT_32 scale = 32U;
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 304 S : Arithmetic performed on unsigned values.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void static_304( UINT_32 myParam )
{
  myParam = myParam * scale;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.16  
CMSE : 14.1.5  
GJB : 5.1.5  
HIC++ : 8.4.13  
JSF++ AV : 163  
LMTCP : 293  
305 S
Unused inspect annotation for standard ...

A spurious inspect annotation for a particular standard is present in the code. The line should be removed to avoid confusion and aid readability.

Further checks on the INSPECTED annotation are performed by 47 D and 2 J.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const UINT_32 scale = 32U;
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 305 S : Unused inspect annotation for standard ...
 *************************************************************/ 
 
/*LDRA_INSPECTED 303 S*/  /* not compliant */
 
void static_305 (UINT_32 myParam)
{
  UINT_32 result = myParam * scale;
     /* this actually triggers penalty 304 S not 303 S*/
  /* ... */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
306 S
Use of C type cast.

C++ style casts (const_cast, reinterpret_cast, and static_cast) shall be used instead of traditional C type casts. A C++ style cast is easier to locate in large programs and makes the intended conversion explicit.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************
 * Standard 306 S : Use of C type cast.
 ********************************************/ 
 
void static_306(UINT_16 *original)
{
  UINT_64 myInt;
 
  myInt = (UINT_64) *original; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 25  
FSB582-C++ : 1.12  
HIC++ : 7.1  
JSF++ AV : 185  
LMTCP : 333  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-4  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

307 S
Use of #line, #error preprocessor directives.

Only specific pre-processor directives shall be used, namely: #ifndef #define #endif #include.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const UINT_32 limit = 32U;
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 307 S : Use of #line, #error preprocessor directives.
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_307(UINT_32 myParam)
{
  if (myParam > limit)
  {
#error
     /* not compliant */
  }
  else
  {
#line 4 myOtherFile.c
    /* not compliant */
    myParam++;
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JPL : 8  
JSF++ AV : 26  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-2-1  
SEC-C : M1.8.3  
309 S
* or & not attached to type in declaration.

If '*' or '&' is used in a declaration, then no space should occur between the type and the '*' or '&'.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 309 S : * or & not attached to type in declaration.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
void static_309 (UINT_16 *my_int_ptr) /* not compliant */
{
  ; 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.4.12  
JSF++ AV : 62  
LMTCP : 87  
Related standards filter models
UML
310 S
Array parameter found.

Arrays shall not be passed as parameters. The degeneration of arrays to pointers when passed as parameters is often the source of errors. Array bounds checking is not performed on C-style arrays and undefined behaviour may arise from an attempt to access memory outside the bounds of an array.

C++ classes that enforce appropriate bounds should be used.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the use of argv by setting the modifiers 285 to 1 in the cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************
 * Standard 310 S : Array parameter found.
 ******************************************/ 
 
void static_310 ( UINT_16 my_int_array[] ) /* not compliant */
{
  // Statements... 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.4.9  
JSF++ AV : 97  
LMTCP : 268  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

311 S
Non local declaration not in a namespace.

Every non-local name, except main(), should be placed in some namespace. The unnamed namespace may be used to declare non-member functions, which are not part of the external interface, non-linkable from other translation units.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 *  Standard 311 S : Non local declaration not in a namespace.
 *************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 outside_namespace_int;   /* not compliant */
 
const UINT_32 initial_int = 0U;  /* not compliant */
 
namespace MySpace
{
 
  UINT_32 inside_namespace_int;  // inside namespace - ok
 
  void static_311(void)
  {
     inside_namespace_int = initial_int;
     // ....
  }
 
}
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 11.2  
JSF++ AV : 98  
LMTCP : 156, 236  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

312 S
Function name is not all lower case.

All letters contained in function names will be composed entirely of lower case letters as a matter of style.

A deviation from this standard, and standards 313 S and 318 S, can be permitted where a specific upper case acronym or identifier must be part of the name. See S 318 for details.

Example
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 312 S : Function name is not all lower case.
 ********************************************************/
 
void Static_312(void)  /* not compliant */
{
   /* ..... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 51  
LMTCP : 74  
NETRINO : 6.1.e  
313 S
Variable name is not all lower case.

All letters contained in variable names will be composed entirely of lower case letters as a matter of style.

A deviation from this standard, and standards 312 S and 318 S, can be permitted where a specific upper case acronym or identifier must be part of the name. See S 318 for details.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 *  Standard 313 S : Variable name is not all lower case.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_313(void)
{
   UINT_32 myVar;  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 51  
314 S
Switch has only 1 case and default.

All switch statements should have at least two cases and a default statement. The use of an if statement provides a more natural representation in this situation.

This standard checks for 1 case and a default, 61 S checks for only a default, 60 S checks for no case or default.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef enum FavouriteSeasons
{
  spring
} FavouriteSeasons;
 
FavouriteSeasons season;
UINT_32 x1;
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 314 S : Switch has only 1 case and default.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
void static_314 (void)
{
  switch (season) /* not compliant */
  {
    case spring:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 196  
LMTCP : 348  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
315 S
Blank before/after . operator.

Spaces should not be used around the . operator.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 315 S : Blank before/after . operator.
 *************************************************/ 
 
const UINT_32 xstart = 1U;
const UINT_32 yend = 240U;
 
typedef struct Position
{
  UINT_32 xValue;
  UINT_32 yValue;
} Position;
 
void static_315( void )
{
  Position myPos;
 
  myPos .xValue = xstart;  /* not compliant */ 
  myPos. yValue = yend;    /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 155  
FSB582-C : 3.3.9  
FSB582-C++ : 10.13  
JSF++ AV : 63  
LMTCP : 88  
NETRINO : 3.1.g  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
316 S
Bit field is not unsigned integral.

Bit fields shall have explicitly unsigned integral types only. Explicitly declaring a bit field unsigned prevents unexpected sign extension or overflow.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 316 S : Bit field is not unsigned integral.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct Message
{
  SINT_32 x_set:0x4;  /* not compliant */
  UINT_32 y_set:0x4;
} Message;
 
void static_316(void)
{
  Message message_chunk;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 154  
NETRINO : 5.3.a  
Related standards filter models
UML
317 S
Typedef name starts with lower case letter.

The first word of the name of a class, structure, namespace, enumeration, or type created with typedef will begin with an uppercase letter. All other letters will be lowercase.

Example
typedef unsigned int uint_32;  /* bad */ 
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 317 S : Typedef name starts with lower case letter.
 * A/Ref:
 **************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct Position        /* good */ 
{
  uint_32 x_value;
  uint_32 y_value;
} Position;
 
void foo(void)
{
  Position my_pos;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 66  
JSF++ AV : 50  
318 S
Name letters after first not lower case.

The first word of the name of a class, structure, namespace, enumeration, or type created with typedef may begin with an upper case or lower case letter. All other letters will be lower case.

A deviation from this standard, and standards 312 S and 313 S, can be permitted where a specific upper case acronym or identifier must be part of the name. If names incorporating upper case acronyms or identifiers are required, the acronyms may be specified in the c/cpptbend.dat file: 

..
  0 Text for acronyms
  3 ZZZ  This may be removed or replaced by required acronyms
  4 ACRO
  3 RGB
  0 <end of acronyms> 
..

In addition, the modifier 256 must be set in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Acronyms within a name must be either at the start or end of the name, or separated by one or more underscore (_) characters from other parts of the name.

Example
typedef unsigned int UINT_32;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 318 S : Name letters after first not lower case.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct Position
{
  UINT_32 x_value;
  UINT_32 y_value;
} Position;                      /* Ok */ 
 
typedef enum Colour_RGB
{
  red,
  green,
  blue
} Colour_RGB;                    /* Ok */ 
 
typedef struct ACRORGB
{
  UINT_32 red_el;
  UINT_32 green_el;
  UINT_32 blue_el;
} ACRORGB;                       /* Not compliant - not separated by an underscore */ 
 
 
void static_318(void)
{
  Position my_pos;
  Colour_RGB col = red;
  ACRORGB my_col_struct;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 50   Modifiers : 256 = 1
319 S
Constructor has insufficient initialisers.

Each constructor must provide values for all member data items, either via an initialisation list or through assignment in the body of the constructor.

It is more efficient to perform the initialisation through the initialisation list rather than through assignment in the body of the constructor. This standard can be further restricted to enforce the use of initialisation rather than assignment by setting the modifier 237 to 1 in the cppreport.dat file. The standard can be relaxed to allow the default constructor of the base class to initialise its member variables by setting the modifier 444 to 1 in the cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 319 S : Constructor has insufficient initialisers.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    UINT_32 personAge;
};
 
Person::Person(const UINT_32 &pNum ) : personalNumber(pNum) /* not compliant */
{
//personAge is not given a value
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 9  
FSB582-C++ : 4.9, 7.1   Modifiers : 237 = 1
HIC++ : 3.2.1  
JSF++ AV : 74, 77   Modifiers : 237 = 1
LMTCP : 109, 115, 119  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

322 S
Default is not last case of switch.

A default case shall be added at the end of each switch statement to trap all unspecified cases and remove the possibility of runtime errors occurring. Any further case statement placed after a default case should be removed or replaced at an earlier position.

This standard can be relaxed to allow the default case at the start of the switch statement by setting the modifier 419 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
typedef enum FavouriteSeasons
{
  spring,
  summer,
  autumn,
  winter
} FavouriteSeasons;
 
FavouriteSeasons season;
UINT_32 x1;
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 322 S : Default is not last case of switch.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
static void static_322(void)
{
  switch (season)
  {
    case spring:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    case summer:
      x1 = 4U;
      break;
    case autumn:
      x1 = 7U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
    case winter:
      x1 = 10U;
      break;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 163  
FSB582-C : 3.9.2.3  
FSB582-C++ : 10.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-4-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 15.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.16.5   Modifiers : 419 = 1
SEC-C : R3.5.2  
Related standards filter models
Standard , UML
323 S
Switch has more than one default case.

Any further default case statement placed after the first default case is redundant and should be removed as it could cause user confusion. Such behaviour is a constraint error, but may not be detected by all compilers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
typedef enum FavouriteSeasons
{
  spring,
  summer,
  autumn,
  winter
} FavouriteSeasons;
 
FavouriteSeasons season;
UINT_32 x1;
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 323 S : Switch has more than one default case.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_323(void)
{
  switch (season)
  {
    case spring:
      x1 = 1U;
      break;
    case summer:
      x1 = 4U;
      break;
    case autumn:
      x1 = 7U;
      break;
    case winter:
      x1 = 10U;
      break;
    default:
      break;
    default:  /* constraint error */
      break;
  }  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 163  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard
324 S
Macro call has wrong number of parameters.

A function-like macro shall not be invoked without all of its arguments.

Example
typedef signed int Sint_32;
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 324 S : Macro call has wrong number of parameters.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
#define COMMON_MACRO(X, Y) ((X) * (Y))
 
const Sint_32 s1 = 42;
 
void foo(void)
{
  Sint_32 myInt = COMMON_MACRO(s1);
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
HIS : 94  
LMTCP : 46  
MISRA-AC : 19.8  
MISRA-C:1998 : 94  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , Standard , UML
325 S
Inconsistent use of tag.

No tag name shall be reused either to define a different tag or for any other purpose within the program.

Example
typedef signed int Sint_32;
typedef signed char Char;
 
/*******************************************
 * Standard 325 S : Inconsistent use of tag.
 *******************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
 
  {
    struct tag_name
    {
      Sint_32 tag_component2;
    } tag_name2;
    /* ... */ 
  }
 
 
  {
    union tag_name              /* Not Compliant */ 
    {
      Sint_32 tag_component3;
      Char tag_component4;
    } tag_name3;
	 /* ... */ 
  }
 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 90  
MISRA-AC : 5.4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
UML
326 S
Declaration is missing type.

Data types shall be explicitly stated.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************
 * Standard 326 S : Declaration is missing type.
 ***********************************************/ 
 
static foo(void);          /* Non-compliant - implicit return type */ 
static SINT_32 static_326(void);  /* Compliant - explicit type */ 
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL31-C  
CWE : 628  
FSB582-C : 3.8.1  
LMTCP : 232  
MISRA-AC : 8.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.1  
SEC-C : M1.3.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
327 S
Reuse of struct or class member name.

Identifier names for struct or class members shall not be reused in another construct. Reusing identifier names leads to code which is confusing.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
 /********************************************************
 * Standard 327 S : Reuse of struct or class member name.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
struct I_var_a
{
  INT_32 ip1;
  INT_32 ip2;
} I_var_a;
 
struct I_var_b
{
  INT_32 ip2;   /* not compliant */ 
  INT_32 ip3;
  INT_32 ip4;
} I_var_b;
 
void static_327 ( void )
{
  ;
}  
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.7  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7  
Related standards filter models
UML
328 S
Non bit field member in bitfield struct.

Structures containing sets of bits shall not include any other data within the same structure.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 328 S : Non bit field member in bitfield struct.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct Message
{
  Uint_32 x_set:0x4;
  Uint_32 y_set:0x4;
  Uint_32 z_set;
} Message;
 
void foo(void)
{
  Message message_chunk;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 284  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 9-6-1  
Related standards filter models
UML
329 S
Operation not appropriate to plain char.

Do not perform an numeric operation on an object with a plain char type. Always declare such objects with an explicit signed char or unsigned char type. Operations between more than one type are handled by other standards.

This standard can be relaxed to allow comparisons between plain chars by selecting the MISRA-C:2012 programming model or by explicitly enabling the 391 modifier in the c/cppreport.dat file (TBmisra license permitting). Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 329 S : Operation not appropriate to plain char.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void static_329 (char ic_byte)
{
  ic_byte++;     /*not compliant - plain char used for numeric operation */ 
 
}
 
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.10  
CERT-C : INT07-C, STR00-C, STR04-C  
CMSE : 1.1.15  
CWE : 327, 682  
DERA : 14  
FSB582-C : 4.1.3  
GJB : 4.1.1.15  
HIC++ : 8.4.5  
HIS : 14  
LMTCP : 11, 267  
MISRA-AC : 6.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 4-5-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 14  
MISRA-C:2004 : 6.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1, R.10.2   Modifiers : 391 = 1
NETRINO : 5.2.c  
SEC-C : P1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML , VSOS
330 S
Implicit conversion of underlying type.

There shall be no implicit conversions between expressions of one underlying type to another. Specifically this penalty highlights conversions from wider to narrower types.
