 * Standard 415 S : Single dimension array param size specified.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
void static_415(char arr[10]) /* not compliant */
{
  INT_32 sub;
 
  for (sub = 0; sub < max_num; sub++)
  {
    if (arr[sub] == '\0')
    {
      break;
    }
 
    (void) printf("%c", arr[sub]);
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.10  
CMSE : 1.1.23  
GJB : 5.1.10  
416 S
First array param dimension specified.

A multi-dimensional array type formal parameter shall not have its first dimension specified. An array intended to be passed by value is in fact always passed by reference, i.e. a copy of the address of the first entry in the array. Specifying the size of an array parameter serves no purpose but to add confusion, and may potentially conflict with the actual array size.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
const INT_32 max_num = 10;
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 416 S : First array param dimension specified.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_416(char arr[10][2]) /* not compliant */
{
  INT_32 sub;
 
  for (sub = 0; sub < max_num; sub++)
  {
    if (arr[sub][0] == '\0')
    {
      break;
    }
 
    (void) printf("%c", arr[sub][0]);
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.11  
CMSE : 1.1.24  
GJB : 5.1.11  
417 S
Use of #if preprocessor command.

The use of the pre-processor should be limited such that only the presence of a definition is checked using #ifndef, rather than using #if. In particular, the control of conditional compilation through a specific value of a pre-processor token is prone to error.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
#define DEBUG1 1
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 417 S : Use of #if preprocessor command.
 * A/Ref:
 ***************************************************/ 
 
#if DEBUG1
 
const Uint_32 init = 1U;
 
#else
 
const Uint_32 init = 0;
 
#endif
 
void foo(void)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 14.5  
JPL : 8  
418 S
Class Derivation is not public.

Inheritance shall be exclusively used to represent an is-a relationship using the public classifier. Hence the is-implemented-in-terms-of relationship should be constructed via composition or some other means rather than using private inheritance which is purely an implementation technique.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 418 S : Class Derivation is not public.
 ********************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
class Student : private Person /* not compliant */
{
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.1  
LMTCP : 137, 139  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

419 S
Deprecated class initialisation.

Class type variables shall be defined using direct initialisation rather than copy initialisation, thereby removing the extra step of constructing a temporary object before copy constructing the resultant variable.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 419 S : Deprecated class initialisation.
 ***************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
static void static_419(void)
{
  Person p1 = Person(42);  /* not compliant */
  Person p2(7);
  // ...
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 3  
HIC++ : 3.1.2  
LMTCP : 277  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

420 S
Virtual function should not be inline.

Virtual functions shall not be inlined either explicitly with the inline keyword or implicitly through method definition in a class declaration. Due to polymorphism a compiler cannot possibly know which instance of a virtual function will be called at compile time.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 420 S : Virtual function should not be inline.
 **********************************************************/
 
class Base
{
  public:
    Base();
    explicit Base(const Base &base);
    Base & operator=(const Base &base);
    virtual ~Base();
 
 
    virtual void foo(void)  /* not compliant */
    {
      ;
    }
 
 
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 m_var;
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 5  
HIC++ : 3.1.6  
LMTCP : 224  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

421 S
New or delete not explicitly static.

Operator new and delete should be declared explicitly static. Although they are by default implicitly static, documenting the static nature in this way helps improve maintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 421 S : New or delete not explicitly static.
 **********************************************************/
 
class X
{
  public:
    X();
    ~X();
    void *operator new(const size_t size);  // should be explicitly 'static'
    static void operator delete(void*);
    explicit X(const X &xx);
    X & operator=(const X &xx);
  protected:
  private:
};
 
static void static_421(void)
{
  // ...
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 12.7  
LMTCP : 377  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

422 S
More than one synonym in typedef.

To avoid confusion and aid maintainability declare one type only in each typedef statement.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 422 S : More than one synonym in typedef.
 * A/Ref:
 ***************************************************/ 
 
typedef Uint_32* My_ptr, Value;  /* Not intuitive that Value is an int type
                                  * whereas My_ptr is an int* type.
                                  */ 
 
void foo(My_ptr ptr,
         Value val)
{
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.4.7  
LMTCP : 265  
423 S
Operator new and no operator delete.

Overloaded operators new and delete should be paired such that any custom memory management scheme is complete.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 423 S : Operator new and no operator delete.
 **********************************************************/
 
 
class X
{
  public:
    X();
    ~X();
    static void *operator new(const size_t size);
    explicit X(const X &xx);
    X & operator=(const X &xx);
  protected:
  private:
};
 
static void static_423(void)
{
  // ...
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 12.6  
LMTCP : 376  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

424 S
Operator new[] and no operator delete[].

Overloaded operators new[] and delete[] should be paired such that any custom memory management scheme is complete.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 424 S : Operator new[] and no operator delete[].
 **********************************************************/
 
class X
{
  public:
    X();
    ~X();
    static void *operator new[](const size_t size);
    explicit X(const X &xx);
    X & operator=(const X &xx);
  protected:
  private:
};
 
static void static_424(void)
{
  // ...
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 12.3  
LMTCP : 376  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

425 S
float literal with no F suffix.

Use the upper case suffix F for all float constants. It is regarded as good programming practice to make explicit the type when using floating-point numbers. All un-suffixed floating constants are of type double by default.

Example
typedef float Float_32;
typedef double Float_64;
 
/**************************************************
 * Standard 425 S : float literal with no F suffix.
 * A/Ref:
 **************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Float_32 my_floata = 3.5F;  /* ok */ 
  Float_64 my_double = 4.5;   /* ok - compiler will assume double */ 
  Float_32 my_floatb = 2.5;   /* not ok - will result in implicit conversion... */ 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 6.2  
HIS : 18  
MISRA-C:1998 : 18  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
426 S
#undef used in a block.

Use of a #undef in a block is misleading as it implies a scope restricted to that block, which is not the case. Place all pre-processing directives near the top of a file, and explicitly at file scope.

Example
#define AA 1
/* compliant */
#undef  BB
 
/******************************************
 * Standard 426 S : #undef used in a block.
 ******************************************/ 
 
static void static_426 (void)
{
#define BB 2
 
/* not compliant */
#undef  CC
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 91  
HIS : 91  
MISRA-AC : 19.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-0-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 91  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.5  
SEC-C : M4.7.5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
427 S
Filename in #include not in < > or " ".

All filenames used in conjunction with #include shall be enclosed in angled-brackets or quotes, either directly or via macro substitution. Any other sequence following a #include results in undefined behaviour.

Example
#define MYFILE "myfile.h"
#include MYFILE
#include filename.h
 
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 427 S : Filename in #include not in < > or " ".
 **********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_427(void)
{
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 19.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 16-2-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 19.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.3  
SEC-C : P1.4.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , UML
428 S
No {} for switch (added by Testbed).

A switch statement should always be enclosed by braces to form a compound statement. If omitted, Testbed inserts the required braces into the reformatted code to permit instrumentation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef enum Seasons
{
  spring,
  summer,
  autumn,
  winter
} Seasons;
 
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 428 S : No {} for switch (added by Testbed).
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_428(Seasons season)
{
  UINT_16 weather_score;
 
  switch (season)  /* not compliant */
    case spring:
    {
	  weather_score = 1U;
	  break;
    }
    case summer:
    {
	  weather_score = 3U;
	  break;
    }
    case autumn:
    {
	  weather_score = 2U;
	  break;
    }
    case winter:
    {
	  weather_score = 0U;
	  break;
    }
    default:
    {
	  weather_score = 0U;
	  break;
    }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 483  
FSB582-C : 3.9.2.1  
FSB582-C++ : 10.2  
HIC++ : 5.1  
MISRA-AC : 14.8  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.15.6  
NETRINO : 1.3.a  
SEC-C : M2.1.2  
Related standards filter models
UML
429 S
Empty middle expression in for loop.

The middle expression in a for loop shall include testing of the loop control variable. In the interests of simplicity and maintainability, expressions in a for statement should be only concerned with loop control.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 429 S : Empty middle expression in for loop.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void static_429( void )
{
  UINT_32 index;
 
  for (index = 0; ; index++) /* not compliant */
  {
    /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIS : 66  
JPL : 2  
MISRA-AC : 13.5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 66  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2  
SEC-C : M3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
UML
430 S
Inconsistent usage of loop control variable.

The loop control variable shall only be initialised, tested, and incremented or decremented. In the interests of simplicity and maintainability, expressions in a for statement should be wholly concerned with loop control only.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
 
 
const SINT_32 max_ind = 10;
 
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 430 S : Inconsistent usage of loop control variable.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
void static_430 (void)
{
  for (SINT_32 index = 0; index < max_ind; printf("index = %d\n", index)) /* not compliant */
  {
 
    index = index + 2;
 
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIS : 66  
MISRA-AC : 13.5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 66  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2  
NETRINO : 8.4.b  
SEC-C : M3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

431 S
Char used instead of (un)signed char.

Plain char values shall not be used where a value of signed or unsigned char type is expected.

Example
typedef signed char int8_t;
 
static int8_t static_431(int8_t);
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 431 S : Char used instead of (un)signed char.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static int8_t static_431(int8_t signed_numeric_param)
{
   int8_t signed_numeric_local;
   switch ( signed_numeric_param )
   {
      case 1:
         signed_numeric_local = 1;
         break;
      case 'a':       /* Not Compliant */ 
         signed_numeric_local = 2;
         break;
      default:
         signed_numeric_local = 3;
         break;
   }
   return signed_numeric_local;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.10  
CMSE : 1.1.15  
DERA : 14  
FSB582-C : 4.1.3  
GJB : 4.1.1.15  
HIS : 14  
MISRA-AC : 6.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-11, 5-0-12  
MISRA-C:1998 : 14  
MISRA-C:2004 : 6.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
SEC-C : P1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
432 S
Inappropriate type - should be plain char.

Signed or unsigned character values shall not be used where a value of plain char type is expected.

Example
typedef char char_t;
 
static char_t static_432(char_t);
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 432 S : Inappropriate type - should be plain char.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
static char_t static_432(char_t plain_char_param)
{
   char_t plain_char_local;
 
   switch ( plain_char_param )
   {
      case 1:        /* Not Compliant */ 
         plain_char_local = ' ';
         break;
      case 'a':
         plain_char_local = '1';
         break;
      default:
         plain_char_local = '2';
         break;
   }
   return plain_char_local;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.1.10  
CERT-C : INT07-C, STR00-C, STR04-C  
CMSE : 1.1.15  
CWE : 682  
DERA : 14  
FSB582-C : 4.1.3  
GJB : 4.1.1.15  
HIS : 14  
LMTCP : 267  
MISRA-AC : 6.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-11, 5-0-12  
MISRA-C:1998 : 14  
MISRA-C:2004 : 6.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
SEC-C : P1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
433 S
Type conversion without cast.

Conversions to a different type require explicit type casting to ensure there is no unintentional loss of information. Implicit conversion is typically implementation-defined and may also result in undefined behaviour. This standard is applied to assignments and initialisations to/from plain char, boolean and void types. Other situations are covered by standards such as 93 S, 96 S, 98 S, 101 S, 331 S, 434 S and 458 S.

This standard can be extended to report implicit conversion from void * by setting the modifier 441 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

When the modifier 191 is set to 1, conversions from double to float are reported by 445 S.

Example
/************************************************
 * Standard 433 S : Type conversion without cast.
 ************************************************/ 
 
void static_433(long s64)
{
  char ch = s64; /* not compliant */
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO34-C, FLP03-C, INT02-C, INT31-C, STR34-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CMSE : 6.1.9  
CWE : 192, 197   Modifiers : 191 = 1
DERA : 43  
GJB : 4.6.1.9  
HIC++ : 10.7  
HIS : 43  
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 267  
MISRA-AC : 6.1, 6.2, 10.1, 10.2, 10.3, 10.4   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-11, 5-0-12  
MISRA-C:1998 : 43  
MISRA-C:2004 : 6.1, 6.2, 10.1, 10.2, 10.3, 10.4   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.1, R.10.3, R.10.4   Modifiers : 441 = 1, 191 = 1
NETRINO : 5.3.c, 5.4.b   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : P1.3.1, R2.4.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
434 S
Signed/unsigned conversion without cast.

Conversions to a different type require explicit type casting to ensure there is no unintentional loss of information. Implicit conversion is typically implementation-defined and may also result in undefined behaviour.

This standard is applied to assignments and initialisations with non-constant values. Other situations are covered by standards such as 93 S, 96 S, 98 S, 101 S, 331 S and 458 S.

This standard can be relaxed to allow zero literal values without a U by setting the modifier 358 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
typedef signed int SINT_32;
typedef unsigned int UINT_32;
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 434 S : Signed/unsigned conversion without cast.
 **********************************************************/ 
 
void static_434(UINT_32 us1)
{
  SINT_32 ss1 = us1;  /* converting to signed may result in a loss of information */ 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C, INT31-C  
CWE : 192, 195, 196, 197   Modifiers : 358 = 1
DERA : 43, 48  
GJB : 4.6.1.9  
HIC++ : 10.13, 10.14  
HIS : 43, 48  
JSF++ AV : 162  
LMTCP : 292, 302, 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 43, 48  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3, R.10.4  
NETRINO : 5.3.c  
SEC-C : R2.3.3, R2.4.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
435 S
Float/integer conversion without cast.

Conversions to a different type require explicit type casting to ensure there is no unintentional loss of information. Implicit conversion is typically implementation-defined and may also result in undefined behaviour.

This standard is applied to assignments and initialisations with non-constant values. Other situations are covered by standards such as 93 S, 96 S, 98 S, 101 S, 331 S and 458 S. By default, this standard applies to all conversions from floating-point types to integer types, and for conversions to floating-point types where the bit size of the integer type is greater or equal to that of the floating point type. The standard can be further restricted to prohibit all implicit integer to float conversions by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file or via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model(TBmisra license permitting). Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Note: Setting this modifier may have other effects on your code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 435 S : Float/integer conversion without cast.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_435(FLOAT_32 ff)
{
  SINT_32 ss1 = ff;  /* not compliant */
                     /* converting to signed int may result in a loss of information */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FLP33-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CWE : 192   Modifiers : 191 = 1
DERA : 43  
EADS-C++ : 29  
GJB : 4.6.2.3  
HIC++ : 7.6  
HIS : 43  
JSF++ AV : 180, 184  
LMTCP : 325, 332  
MISRA-AC : 10.1, 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 43  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1, 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3, R.10.4   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : R2.4.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
436 S
Declaration does not specify an array.

Array indexing, as a form of pointer arithmetic, shall only be applied to objects declared with an array type or to objects that point to an array. Pointers assigned to non-array objects have the potential to access unintended or invalid memory.

This standard can be restricted to check that array indexing is only applied to objects declared with array type by setting the modifier 400 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 436 S : Declaration does not specify an array.
 *********************************************************/
 
void static_436 (INT_8 * ptr, INT_8 arr[10])
{
  INT_8  * p1 = ptr;
  INT_8  * p2 = arr;
 
  ptr[5] = 0;   /* not compliant - ptr was not declared as an array */
  p1[5] = 0;    /* not compliant - p1 and ptr were not declared as an array */
 
  p2[5] = 0;    /* not compliant if modifier 400 is set
                   - p2 not declared as an array, but does point to an array */
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 315, 400  
MISRA-AC : 17.1, 17.4   Modifiers : 400 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-15, 5-0-16  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.1, 17.4   Modifiers : 400 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.1  
SEC-C : R1.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
437 S
< > <= >= used on different object pointers.

Pointers which do not point to the same object cannot be logically compared, without the result being undefined behaviour.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 437 S : Logical comparison of unlike pointers.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_437(void)
{
  INT_32 ss1[10];
  INT_32 ss2[10];
 
  INT_32 *ss1_ptr = &ss1[0];
  INT_32 *ss2_ptr = &ss2[0];
 
  if (ss1_ptr > ss2_ptr) /* not compliant */
  {
     /* ... */ 
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 17.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-18  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.3  
SEC-C : R1.3.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
438 S
Pointer subtraction not addressing one array.

Pointer subtraction cannot be performed with pointers that do not point to the same object, without the result being undefined behaviour.

Example
typedef signed int Sint_32;
 
void foo(void);
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 438 S : Pointer subtraction not addressing one array.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Sint_32 ss1[10];
  Sint_32 ss2[10];
 
  Sint_32 *ss1_ptr = &ss1[0];
  Sint_32 *ss2_ptr = &ss2[0];
  Sint_32 ss3 = ss1_ptr - ss2_ptr;
 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ARR36-C, EXP08-C  
CWE : 468, 469, 758  
MISRA-AC : 17.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-17  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.2  
SEC-C : R1.3.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
439 S
Cast from pointer to integral type.

A cast from a pointer to an integral type shall not be performed. The size of integer required is implementation-defined, and, not only does the cast circumvent type integrity, the result may be undefined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 439 S : Cast from pointer to integral type.
 ******************************************************/
 
void static_439 (INT_32 *ss_ptr)
{
  INT_32 ss = (INT_32)ss_ptr; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT11-C, INT15-C  
CWE : 681  
DERA : 45  
EADS-C++ : 15, 16  
GJB : 4.12.1.1  
HIC++ : 7.5, 7.7, 13.7  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182  
LMTCP : 328, 329  
MISRA-AC : 11.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-9  
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.2, R.11.4, R.11.6, R.11.7  
SEC-C : R2.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
440 S
Cast from integral type to pointer.

A cast from an integral type to a pointer shall not be performed. The size of an integer used to represent a pointer is implementation-defined, and, not only does the cast circumvent type integrity, the result may be undefined. Casts on a numeric literal with the value zero are permitted.

This standard can be relaxed to allow casts on hexadecimal constants by setting the modifier 397 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 440 S : Cast from integral type to pointer.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
void static_440(INT_32 ss)
{
  INT_32 *ss_ptr = (INT_32 *)ss; /* not compliant */
 
  ss_ptr = (INT_32 *)0x8ff7ffff; /* compliant when modifier 397 is set */
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT11-C, INT15-C  
CWE : 587, 588, 681  
DERA : 45  
EADS-C++ : 28  
GJB : 4.12.2.1  
HIC++ : 7.5  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182  
LMTCP : 328, 331  
MISRA-AC : 11.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-8  
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.1, R.11.2, R.11.4, R.11.6, R.11.7  
SEC-C : R2.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , TBrun Requires
441 S
Float cast to non-float.

The value of a complex expression of floating type shall not be explicitly converted to a different type. Only a cast to a narrower floating type is permitted.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and explicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and unexpected results.

This standard must be enabled by setting the modifier 323 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Alternatively, the standard can be enabled via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by explicitly enabling the the modifier 191 (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************
 * Standard 441 S : Float cast to non-float.
 *******************************************/ 
 
void static_441( void )
{
  UINT_16  u16r;
  FLOAT_32 f32a,
           f32b;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  u16r = (UINT_16)(f32a + f32b);  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C   Modifiers : 323 = 1
CWE : 758   Modifiers : 323 = 1
JSF++ AV : 184   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-AC : 10.4   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.4   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.8   Modifiers : 323 = 1
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
442 S
Signed integral type cast to unsigned.

The value of a complex expression of signed integer type shall not be explicitly converted to unsigned integer. Only a cast to an integer type which is of the same signedness and narrower is permitted.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and explicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and unexpected results.

This standard must be enabled by setting the modifier 323 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Alternatively, the standard can be enabled via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by explicitly enabling the the modifier 191 (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 442 S : Signed integral type cast to unsigned.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_442( void )
{
  UINT_32 u32;
  INT_32 s32a,
         s32b;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  u32 = (UINT_32)(s32a + s32b);  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C   Modifiers : 323 = 1
CWE : 192, 195, 197   Modifiers : 323 = 1

LMTCP : 365

MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.8   Modifiers : 323 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
443 S
Unsigned integral type cast to signed.

The value of a complex expression of unsigned integer type shall not be explicitly converted to signed integer. Only a cast to an integer type which is of the same signedness and narrower is permitted.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and explicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and unexpected results.

This standard must be enabled by setting the modifier 323 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Alternatively, the standard can be enabled via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by explicitly enabling the the modifier 191 (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 443 S : Unsigned integral type cast to signed.
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void static_443( void )
{
  INT_32  s32;
  UINT_32 u32a,
          u32b;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  s32 = (INT_32)(u32a + u32b);  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C   Modifiers : 323 = 1
CWE : 192, 196, 197   Modifiers : 323 = 1
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 365

MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-9   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.3   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.8   Modifiers : 323 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
444 S
Integral type cast to non-integral.

The value of a complex expression of integer type shall not be explicitly converted to a different type. Only a cast to an integer type which is of the same signedness and narrower is permitted.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and explicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and unexpected results.

This standard must be enabled by setting the modifier 323 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. Alternatively, the standard can be enabled via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by explicitly enabling the the modifier 191 (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 444 S : Integral type cast to non-integral.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 s32a = 4;
SINT_32 s32b = 3;
 
void static_444( void )
{
  FLOAT_64 f64 = (FLOAT_64) (s32a + s32b);
  /*...*/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 681   Modifiers : 323 = 1
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 365  
MISRA-AC : 10.3   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.3   Modifiers : 323 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.8   Modifiers : 323 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
445 S
Narrower float conversion without cast.

Conversions to a narrower type require explicit type casting to ensure there is no unintentional loss of information. Implicit conversion is typically implementation-defined and may result in undefined behaviour.

Note that this standard is only available when the 191 modifier is enabled in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
typedef float Float_32;   /* 32 bit float */ 
typedef double Float_64;  /* 64 bit float */ 
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 445 S : Narrower float conversion without cast.
 **********************************************************/ 
 
void static_445( void )
{
  Float_32 f32;
  Float_64 f64a,
           f64b;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  f32 = f64a + f64b;  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
HIC++ : 10.7, 10.14  
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3   Modifiers : 191 = 1
NETRINO : 5.4.b   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : R2.3.3, R2.5.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
446 S
Narrower int conversion without cast.

Conversions to a narrower type require explicit type casting to ensure there is no unintentional loss of information. Implicit conversion is typically implementation-defined and may result in undefined behaviour.

Note that MISRA-C:2004 checking needs to be enabled in order for this violation to be detected, either via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by explicitly enabling the 191 entry configuration flag in the c/cppvals.dat file (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 446 S : Narrower int conversion without cast.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_446 ( void )
{
  UINT_16 u16;
  UINT_32 u32a,
          u32b;
 
  u16 = u32a + u32b;  /* not compliant */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CWE : 192, 194, 197   Modifiers : 191 = 1
HIC++ : 10.7, 10.14  
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : R2.3.3, R2.5.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
447 S
Loop termination not a simple constant test.

The middle expression in a for loop shall perform simple testing of a single loop control variable against a constant value. This can aid readability and maintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 447 S : Loop termination not a simple constant test.
 ****************************************************************/
 
const INT_32 max_ind = 10;
INT_32 flag = 1;
 
static void static_447(void)
{
  for (INT_32 index = 0; (index < max_ind) && (flag > 0); index++) /* not compliant */
  {
    /* ... */
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 606  
HIC++ : 5.7  
448 S
Base class pointer cast to derived class.

Down-casting base class object pointers to a derived class shall be avoided. The use of virtual functions (polymorphism) is preferable, for example, to casting down the inheritance hierarchy to call a particular method defined by a derived class.

Example
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 448 S : Base class pointer cast to derived class.
 *************************************************************/
 
class Base
{
   public:
    Base();
    virtual ~Base();
};
 
class Derived: public Base
{
};
 
 
static void static_448 ( void )
{
  Derived d;
  Base *pB = &d;
 
  Derived * pD1  = static_cast < Derived* >(  pB );  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 15  
HIC++ : 3.3.3  
JSF++ AV : 178, 179  
LMTCP : 322  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

449 S
Derived class pointer cast to virtual base.

Casting up to a virtual base class object shall be avoided. The use of a cast on a pointer to traverse up the inheritance hierarchy to a base class is irreversible.

Example
//
// Standard 449 S : Derived class pointer cast to virtual base.
// A/Ref:
// 
 
class Base
{
  public:
    Base();
    explicit Base(const Base &base);
    Base & operator=(const Base &base);
    virtual void my_func(void);
    virtual ~Base();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class Derived : public virtual Base
{
  public:
    Derived();
    explicit Derived(const Derived &derived);
    Derived & operator=(const Derived &derived);
    virtual void my_func(void);
    virtual ~Derived();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
Base * someFunc(void)
{
  Derived *derived_ptr =  new Derived();
  return static_cast<Base*>(derived_ptr); // not compliant 
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 16  
HIC++ : 3.3.4  
LMTCP : 324  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

450 S
Wide string and string concatenated.

String literals shall not be concatenated with wide string literals. If a narrow string literal token is adjacent to a wide string literal token, the behaviour is undefined.

Example
typedef char Char_8;
 
//
// Standard 450 S : Wide string and string concatenated.
// A/Ref:
// 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Char_8 *text = L"Wide string ""and string";
 
  // ... 
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
HIC++ : 6.5  
LMTCP : 275  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-13-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
451 S
No cast for widening complex float expression.

The value of a complex expression of floating type shall not be implicitly converted to a different type without an explicit cast to ensure arithmetic consistency.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and implicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and the dangers associated with integral promotion.

Note that this standard is only enabled by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
typedef float Float_32;   /* 32 bit float */ 
typedef double Float_64;  /* 64 bit float */ 
 
/*****************************************************************
 * Standard 451 S : No cast for widening complex float expression.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
void static_451( void )
{
  Float_64 f64;
  Float_32 f32a,
           f32b;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  f64 = f32a + f32b;  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.6, R.10.7   Modifiers : 191 = 1
NETRINO : 5.4.b   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : R2.4.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
452 S
No cast for widening complex int expression.

The value of a complex expression of integer type shall not be implicitly converted to a different type without an explicit cast to ensure arithmetic consistency.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and implicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and the dangers associated with integral promotion.

Note that this standard is only enabled by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 452 S : No cast for widening complex int expression.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void static_452(void)
{
  UINT_64 u64a;
  UINT_32 u32a,
          u32b;
 
  u64a = u32a + u32b;       /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C, INT35-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CWE : 192   Modifiers : 191 = 1
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.6, R.10.7   Modifiers : 191 = 1
SEC-C : R2.4.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
Related standards filter models
Legacy
453 S
Throw found in destructor.

Code which may result in an exception being thrown is present in a destructor. Throwing an exception from within a destructor shall be avoided as it may result in program termination if another exception is active further up the call stack. A try-catch block may be used in the destructor to prevent the thrown exception from propagating outside, provided the catch block has no code which may in turn throw a different exception.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 453 S : Throw found in destructor.
 ************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
Person::~Person()
{
  // ...
  throw "Exception thrown"; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 9.1  
LMTCP : 382  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 15-5-1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

454 S
Throw type is not a class type.

Thrown exception objects shall be of class type. A class instance provides the ability to pass information via its member data to the point at which error handling is performed. Furthermore, the class type itself can be used to document the nature of the exception, thereby aiding maintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 454 S : Throw type is not a class type.
 ************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person();
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
Person::~Person()
{
  // ...
  throw "Exception thrown"; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 9.2  
LMTCP : 383  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

455 S
Catch is not by reference.

Catch exception blocks shall be passed arguments by reference in favour of pass-by-pointer or pass-by-value. Additional memory management is required by pass-by-pointer which may in turn cause further exceptions or memory loss if the exception object is not deleted. Information in a derived class may be sliced from the exception in the exception handler if an exception is caught by value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 455 S : Catch is not by reference.
 ************************************************/
 
static void f(void)
{
  // ...
  // UINT_32 type exception thrown here
  // ...
}
 
 
static void static_455(void)
{
  try
  {
    f();
  }
  catch (UINT_32 someInt)  /* not compliant */
  {
    // handle UINT_32 exceptions here...
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 9.3  
LMTCP : 384  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 15-3-5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

456 S
Implicit float widening for function return.

The value of an expression of floating type shall not be implicitly converted to a different type if the expression is a return type.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and implicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and the dangers associated with integral promotion.

Note that this standard is only enabled by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
typedef float Float_32;   /* 32 bit float */ 
typedef double Float_64;  /* 64 bit float */ 
 
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 456 S : Implicit float widening for function return.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
Float_64 static_456( void )
{
  Float_32 f32a;
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  return (f32a);  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 704   Modifiers : 191 = 1
HIC++ : 10.7, 10.14  
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.2   Modifiers : 191 = 1
NETRINO : 5.4.b   Modifiers : 191 = 1
457 S
Implicit int widening for function return.

The value of an expression of integer type shall not be implicitly converted to a different type if the expression is a return type.

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and implicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and the dangers associated with integral promotion.

Note that this standard is only enabled by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 457 S : Implicit int widening for function return.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_16 static_457(void)
{
  UINT_8 u8a;
 
  return u8a;  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C   Modifiers : 191 = 1
CWE : 192   Modifiers : 191 = 1
HIC++ : 10.7, 10.14  
JSF++ AV : 180  
LMTCP : 325  
MISRA-AC : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1   Modifiers : 191 = 1
458 S
Implicit conversion: actual to formal param.

The value of an actual parameter shall not be implicitly converted to the type of a formal parameter, if that conversion might result in the loss of information. This standard checks for:

  • Conversion to a narrower integer type of the same signedness
  • Conversion from signed to unsigned
  • Conversion from unsigned to signed where the values of the unsigned are not in the signed range
  • Conversion from float to integral and vice versa
  • Conversion from plain char to any other type and vice versa

All arithmetic operations should be performed in a consistent (underlying) type, and implicit conversions restricted, so as to avoid programmer confusion and the dangers associated with integral promotion.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;    /* 32 bit unsigned int */ 
typedef unsigned long Uint_64;   /* 64 bit unsigned int */ 
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 458 S : Implicit conversion: actual to formal param.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
static void narrow_int(Uint_32 u32b)
{
  ;  /* ... */ 
}
 
static void static_458(void)
{
  Uint_64 u64a;
 
  narrow_int(u64a); /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT02-C, INT07-C, STR04-C  
CWE : 192, 197  
DERA : 77  
HIC++ : 7.8, 10.7  
HIS : 77  
MISRA-AC : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 77  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1, 10.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3  
NETRINO : 5.3.c, 5.4.b  
SEC-C : R2.5.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
459 S
Array passed as actual parameter.

Arrays shall not be passed as parameters. The degeneration of arrays to pointers when passed as parameters is often the source of errors. Array bounds checking is not performed on C-style arrays and undefined behaviour may arise from an attempt to access memory outside the bounds of an array. This standard does not apply when arrays are passed as parameters to library routines.

The standard can be relaxed to allow arrays to be passed to a function with a parameter which is a reference to an array by setting the modifier 443 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 459 S : Array passed as actual parameter.
 ****************************************************/
 
static void foo(UINT_32 *uptr)
{
  /* ... */
}
 
 
void static_459(void)
{
  UINT_32 uarray[10];
 
  foo(uarray);  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 97  
LMTCP : 268  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-12   Modifiers : 443 = 1
460 S
Inline or template function not in header.

Inline and template functions shall not be defined in the implementation file. Every implementation file shall include the header files that uniquely define the inline functions and templates used, and hence enforce the one definition rule.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 460 S : Inline or template function not in header.
 *************************************************************/
 
namespace Ldra_test_f
{
  inline INT_32 min_32(INT_32  x1, INT_32  y1)
  {
    return (x1 <y1) ? x1 : y1;
  }
 
 
  template <class T>
  T min(T x2, T y2)
  {
    return (x2 < y2) ? x2 : y2;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.1.2, 8.1.3  
JSF++ AV : 40  
LMTCP : 61  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

461 S
Identifier with ambiguous linkage.

An identifier shall be uniquely declared with either external or internal linkage in any given translation unit.

Other aspects concerning linkage are covered by standards 575 S and 2 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 461 S : Identifier with ambiguous linkage.
 *****************************************************/
 
extern UINT_8 x;
 
static UINT_8 x = 0u; /* not compliant */
 
static void static_461(void)
{
    /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL36-C  
DERA : 24  
HIC++ : 8.3.2  
HIS : 24  
JSF++ AV : 138  
LMTCP : 251  
MISRA-AC : 8.11  
MISRA-C:1998 : 24  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.11  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.8  
NETRINO : 1.8.a  
SEC-C : M2.2.2, M2.2.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
462 S
Struct initialisation has insufficient items.

A structure shall be fully populated upon initialisation. If there are fewer initialising data objects than the number of members, then the aggregate is padded with zeros of the appropriate type. However, the content of the padding may be garbage for an 'auto' struct.

Example
typedef unsigned int Uint_32;
 
typedef struct MyStruct
{
  Uint_32 x1;
  Uint_32 x2;
  Uint_32 x3;
} MyStruct;
 
void foo(void);
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 462 S : Struct initialisation has insufficient items.
 * A/Ref:
 ****************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  MyStruct a_struct = {1, 2};
 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
GJB : 4.13.1.3  
MISRA-AC : 9.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 9.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
463 S
Unnecessary comma in initialisation list.

Initialiser lists shall contain the correct number of comma separators. Superfluous use of a comma may make code confusing to reading.

Example
static struct { char * string;
                int anint;
              } types [] =
 {
   { "one green bottle",1},
   { "two green bottles",2},
   { "three green bottles",3}, /* not compliant */
 };
 
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 463 S : Unnecessary comma in initialisation list.
 ***********************************************************/
 
static void static_463( void )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
SEC-C : M4.5.3  
464 S
Use of auto specifier.

Auto is the default storage class specifier for local declarations and need not be explicitly declared. For a variable to be an auto, it must be defined within a function.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************
 * Standard 464 S : Use of auto specifier.
 *****************************************/
 
auto UINT_32 glob_var;     /* not compliant - constraint error  */
 
static void static_464(void)
{
  UINT_32 r1;
  auto UINT_32 local_var;  /* not compliant 'local_var' is auto by default */
 
  /* ... */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.3.3  
LMTCP : 255  
NETRINO : 1.7.a  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
465 S
Struct/union not completely specified.

A complete declaration of a struct/union shall be included within a translation unit. Behaviour is undefined if a struct/union type is used to define an identifier without that type being previously or subsequently specified.

Example
struct static_465_s;  /* incomplete declaration */ 
 
void foo(void);
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 465 S : Struct/union not completely specified.
 * A/Ref:
 *********************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 18.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 18.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , RUNTIME
466 S
long literal with no L suffix.

An L suffix should be applied to all constants of long type. In the case of C99, a LL suffix should be applied to all constants of long long type.

Applying a suffix, or suffixes, to a numeric constant explicitly indicates its type and signedness, thereby avoiding ambiguity where implementation dependencies may apply.

Example
typedef signed long Sint_32;
typedef unsigned long Uint_32;
 
const Sint_32 slong = 1;       /* not compliant */
 
const Sint_32 slong_ok = 1L; 
 
const Uint_32 ulong = 2U;     /* not compliant */
 
const Uint_32 ulong_ok = 2UL;
 
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 466 S : Long literal with no L suffix.
 *************************************************/ 
 
void static_466 (void)
{
 
  /* ... */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 18  
HIS : 18  
MISRA-C:1998 : 18  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
467 S
Virtual member called in ctor/dtor.

A virtual member shall not be invoked from a class constructor. The method for the current class, or its base, will always be called, even when invoked as part of the construction of a derived class.

Example
/********************************************************
 * Standard 467 S : Virtual member called in constructor.
 ********************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    virtual void func();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
class Student : public Person
{
  public:
    Student() : Person() { func(); };  // Person::func called not Student::func 
    virtual void func();
  protected:
  private:
};
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.13  
JSF++ AV : 71.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 12-1-1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

468 S
Member function redeclared.

In order to support the one definition rule (ODR), declarations are required to be made once (preferably in a shared header file), regardless of scope or namespace, to safeguard against duplicate definitions.

Example
//
// Standard 468 S : Member function redeclared.
// A/Ref:
// 
 
namespace H
{
  namespace G
  {
    class HM
    {
      public:
        HM(){};
        virtual ~HM();
      protected:
      private:
    };
  } // namespace H 
} // namespace G 
 
namespace H
{
  namespace G
  {
    HM::HM();  // redeclaration 
    HM::~HM() {};
  }
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

469 S
No copy constructor for complex destructor.

A copy constructor shall be declared for classes that contain non-trivial destructors, i.e. manage resources.

The default copy constructor provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 469 S : No copy constructor for complex destructor.
 **************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person);
    ~Person() { release_resources(); };  // non-trivial destructor 
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
    void release_resources(void);
};
 
 
void static_469(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(p1);  // invokes (compiler provided) copy constructor 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 4  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
JSF++ AV : 76  
LMTCP : 117  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

470 S
No assignment operator for complex destrtor.

A copy assignment operator shall be declared for classes that contain non-trivial destructors, i.e. manage resources.

The default assignment operator provided by the compiler performs a bitwise or shallow copy, resulting in a shared resource when a duplicated resource may be necessary. An explicit declaration makes the intention clear.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 470 S : No assignment operator for complex destrtor.
 **************************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 person_num);
    explicit Person(const Person &person);
    ~Person() { release_resources(); };  // non-trivial destructor 
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personal_number;
    void release_resources(void);
};
 
 
static void static_470(void)
{
  Person p1(10);
  Person q1(10);
  q1 = p1;  // invokes (compiler provided) copy assignment constructor 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 4  
FSB582-C++ : 4.2  
HIC++ : 3.1.3  
JSF++ AV : 76  
LMTCP : 117  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

471 S
Function returns constant value.

Functions that return a constant literal value may indicate a problem with the program structure and hence redundant code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 471 S : Function returns constant value.
 ***************************************************/ 
 
INT_32 static_471 (void)
{
  /* ... */ 
  return 42;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
472 S
No comment after declaration.

Every declaration shall have a sidebar comment indicating the purpose of the object or function. Commenting the code in this way improves readability and maintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void static_472(void);
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 472 S : No comment after declaration.
 ************************************************/ 
 
void static_472(void)
{
   char * entry_name = "Anon.";
   INT_32 entry_number = 0;      /* Id of current entry - comment provided,
                                  * unlike prior function & variable declarations
                                  */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 11.8, 11.10  
473 S
Typedef should not be used.

Typedefs shall not be used. For the sake of clarity, it is preferred that programmer-defined data types be represented explicitly in the code.

Example
#include <string.h>
 
#define STRING_BUFFER_LENGTH 256
 
typedef struct
{
  int stringSize;
  char stringBuffer[STRING_BUFFER_LENGTH];
} sized_string;
 
struct another_string
{
  int stringLength;
  char stringContainer[STRING_BUFFER_LENGTH];
};
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 473 S : Typedef should not be used.
 **********************************************/ 
 
void static_473(void)
{
  sized_string myString;               /* create an instance of typedef struct */ 
  struct another_string myContainer;   /* explicit definition of struct type instance */ 
 
  /* ... */ 
 
  myContainer.stringLength = myString.stringSize;
  memcpy(myContainer.stringContainer, myString.stringBuffer, myContainer.stringLength);
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
474 S
Enum name is not all upper case.

Enumeration names shall be all upper case. Making enumerated constants all upper case aids readability of the code, enabling the programmer to easily distinguish between literal constants and variable/function names.

Example
typedef enum Bool
{
  FALSE,  /* all upper case */ 
  TRUE    /* all upper case */ 
} Bool;
 
typedef enum MyEnum
{
  First,  /* not compliant - mixed lower and upper case */ 
  Second, /* not compliant -  mixed lower and upper case */ 
  THIRD   
} MyEnum;
 
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 474 S : Enum name is not all upper case.
 ***************************************************/ 
 
void static_474(MyEnum ee)
{
  Bool top_two = FALSE;
 
  if (ee == First)
  {
    top_two = TRUE;
  }
  else
  {
    if (ee == Second)
    {
      top_two = TRUE;
    }
    else
    {
      top_two = FALSE;
    }
  }
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.2.5  
LMTCP : 75  
475 S
Parameter needs IN/OUT/INOUT marker.

Function parameters shall be marked by standard macros to indicate whether they are input (IN), output (OUT), or bidirectional (INOUT), immediately before the parameter type.

Example
#define IN
 
typedef signed int Sint_32;
 
Sint_32 foo(IN Sint_32 si);  /* Use of a (empty) standard macro
                              * to mark direction of parameter.
                              */ 
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 475 S : Parameter needs an IN/OUT/INOUT marker.
 * A/Ref:
 **********************************************************/ 
 
Sint_32 foo(Sint_32 si)       /* Direction marker omitted ! */ 
{
  /* ... */ 
  return si;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
476 S
Array index not unsigned.

Array subscripts must always be zero or positive. Hence any variable used to index into an array should be of an unsigned type.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 476 S : Array index not unsigned.
 *************************************************/ 
 
void static_476(INT_32 si)
{
  UINT_32 my_array[3] = {0, 0, 0};
 
  UINT_32 element = my_array[si];  /* not compliant - signed index */ 
 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ARR30-C  
FSB582-C++ : 9.11  
477 S
Empty else clause following else if.

The body of an else that follows a final else if shall contain either a non-null statement (action) or a suitable comment to indicate that the alternative case has been considered.

Example
typedef enum Pos
{
  FIRST,
  SECOND,
  THIRD
} Pos;
 
typedef enum Bool
{
  FALSE,
  TRUE
} Bool;
 
Bool foo(const Pos xx);
 
 /*******************************************************
 * Standard 477 S : Empty else clause following else if.
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************/ 
 
Bool foo(const Pos xx)
{
  Bool top_two;
  /* ... */ 
  if (xx == FIRST)
  {
    top_two = TRUE;
  }
  else if (xx == SECOND)
  {
      top_two = TRUE;
  }
  else
  { ; }  /* Not compliant - no action or comment present */ 
  /* ... */ 
  return top_two;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.9.1.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.19  
MISRA-AC : 14.10  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.10  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.15.7  
NETRINO : 8.2.d  
SEC-C : M1.9.1, R3.5.1  
478 S
Name starts with ISO reserved prefix.

Macro names that start with is or to and are followed by a lowercase letter are ISO reserved words. Section 7.13 of the ISO/IEC 9899:1990 C programming standard lists possible future changes to names in the standard library and states that such names are reserved. This includes all names starting with is or to and followed by a lowercase letter.

This standard will only be enabled by setting the modifier 316 to 1 in the creport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Note that MISRA-C:2004 checking needs to be enabled in order for this violation to be detected, either via selection of the MISRA-C:2004 programming model or by setting the modifier 191 to 1 in the creport.dat (TBmisra license permitting).

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/* Not compliant */
#define isillegal 11
 
SINT_32 total = 12;  /* compliant */
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 478 S : Name starts with ISO reserved prefix.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 static_478(SINT_32 p1)
{
  SINT_32 result = total + (p1 * isillegal);
  return result;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 20.1   Modifiers : 316 = 1, 191 = 1
MISRA-C:2004 : 20.1   Modifiers : 316 = 1, 191 = 1
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

479 S
Right shift loses all bits.

A right bit shift operation shall not be performed when the number of bits shifted results in the value held by the lvalue operand to be lost.

Example
typedef unsigned char Uint_8;
 
void foo(void);
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 479 S : Right shift loses all bits.
 * A/Ref:
 **********************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)
{
  Uint_8 ss = 15U;
  Uint_8 res;
 
  res = ss >> 4U;
 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT34-C  
CWE : 189  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
480 S
String function params access same variable.

An object shall not be copied to another when the two objects have some overlap in memory. The behaviour is undefined. This standard applies to the string handling library functions.

Example
#include <string.h>
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 480 S : String function params access same variable.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
void static_480(void)
{
  char str[] = {"ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"};
  (void)memcpy(&str[10], &str[13], 6U);
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL33-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 18.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-2-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 18.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.19.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
481 S
Array with no bounds in struct.

A user-defined structure or union type declaration shall be complete within any translation unit that refers to it. Specifically the C90 standard stipulates that no incomplete array definitions be permitted in a structure or union. Such behaviour is a constraint error, but may not be detected by all compilers.

C99 does allow incomplete arrays as the last member of a structure, but it is also restricted by this penalty.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 481 S : Array with no bounds in struct.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
void static_481 ( void )
{
   struct static_481_tag {
      INT_16 a;
      INT_16 b [ ];    /* not compliant */ 
   };
 
   struct static_481_tag static_481_st = { 1, { 2, 3, 4 } };
 
   /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 1.1  
MISRA-AC : 18.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 1-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 18.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1, R.18.7  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
482 S
Incomplete structure referenced.

A user-defined structure or union type declaration shall be complete within any translation unit that dereferences it.

Opaque pointers are permitted where the internal implementation is hidden using a pointer. This allows the implementation of the whole interface to change without the need to recompile the modules using it.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 482 S : Incomplete structure referenced
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
extern struct st *pst1;
extern struct st *pst2;
 
void static_482 ( void )
{
   pst2 = pst1;         /* Ok - use of opaque pointer */ 
 
   *pst2 = *pst1;       /* not compliant */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 18.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 18.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
483 S
free parameter is not heap item.

free de-allocates the memory pointed to by the specified parameter, and makes it available for other use. Before free is called, memory must have been allocated (on the heap).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 483 S : free parameter is not heap item.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct S
{
  UINT_32 ac;
  UINT_32 bc;
};
 
void static_483 ( void )
{
    UINT_32 ic;
    UINT_32 *jc;
 
    struct S *sptr;
    sptr = (struct S*)malloc(sizeof(struct S));
 
    jc = &ic; 
    free(jc);     /* not compliant - free performed on non-heap item */ 
 
    free(sptr);   /* Ok */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM34-C  
CWE : 590, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
484 S
Attempt to use already freed object.

Once memory for an object has been de-allocated, the pointer that was used to identify the location of the object no longer points to a valid address. A freed object shall not be accessed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 484 S : Attempt to use already freed object
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct S
{
  UINT_32 ac;
  UINT_32 bc;
};
 
 
void static_484 ( void )
{
    UINT_32 ic;
    struct S *sptr;
 
    sptr = (struct S*)malloc(sizeof(struct S));
    free(sptr);
    ic = sptr->ac;   /* not compliant */
                     /* use after free, dereferencing freed pointer "sptr" */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM01-C, MEM31-C  
CWE : 415, 416, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
485 S
Array deletion without [].

To destroy an array and ensure that all destructors are called, delete[] must be used rather than delete. Failure to invoke destructors for each array element may result in memory leaks.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
//
// Standard 485 S : Array deletion without []
// 
 
class helper
{
    // Resources dynamically allocated in constructor
    // and destroyed in destructor. 
};
 
void static_485( void )
{
    helper * buffer = new helper[10];
 
    delete buffer;    // Not Ok - should be "delete[] buffer"/ 
}
 
 
//
//
// Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
//
//
Related standards model rules
CWE : 762  
FSB582-C++ : 2.5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

486 S
Incorrect number of formats in output function.

Arguments of an output function shall each be associated with a format code. Omission of a format code is likely to result in the incorrect representation of any output.

Note: This standard is pessimistic and assumes that if a variable is used as the format argument that is might contain the incorrect number of formats.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 486 S : Incorrect number of formats in output function.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void static_486 ( char * my_string )
{
    printf ( my_string );      /* Not Compliant - missing format string */ 
 
    printf ( "My string is %s", my_string );  /* Compliant */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO00-C  
CWE : 134, 685, 686, 688, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
487 S
Insufficient space allocated.

When allocating space to an object from heap/free store, enough space shall be reserved to fully accommodate the object. Access to under-allocated memory may result in reading out of bounds or overwriting adjacent memory locations.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h> 
 
/**************************************************
 * Standard 487 S : Insufficient space allocated
 **************************************************/ 
 
 
struct S
{
  UINT_32 ac;
  UINT_32 bc;
  CHAR cc[100];
};
 
 
static void static_487 ( void )
{
    UINT_32 tt;
    struct S *sptr;
 
    sptr = (struct S*)malloc(sizeof(sptr)); /* Not compliant - should be "sizeof(*sptr)" */ 
    sptr->ac = 0U;
    sptr->bc = 0U;
    tt = sptr->bc;
    /***/ 
 
    free(sptr);
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM35-C  
CWE : 131, 190, 680, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
488 S
Value outside range of underlying type.

All operations shall be conducted in exactly the same arithmetic (underlying) type. Irrespective of implementation, operands must be within the range of the underlying type used. Mismatching types leads to unexpected results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 488 S : Outside range of underlying type
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void static_488 ( void )
{
    SCHAR s8a = 0;
    SCHAR s8b = 0;
 
    s8a = s8a + 127;  /* Compliant */ 
 
    s8b = s8b + 150;  /* Not compliant  - addition performed in 8-bit signed */ 
}                     /* and so "150" too big */ 
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT08-C  
CWE : 190  
HIC++ : 6.3  
MISRA-AC : 10.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 10.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.10.3, R.10.4  
NETRINO : 5.3.c  
SEC-C : R2.3.1, X2.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
489 S
Insufficient space for operation.

When copying from source to destination, the destination must not overrun as a result of the operation. Overrun leads to data corruption. Standards 66 X, 70 X and 71 X report copies via procedure calls.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <string.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 489 S : Insufficient space for operation
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void static_489 ( void )
{
    char source[200];
    char destination[100];
 
    /***/ 
 
    strncpy( destination, source, 200 );  /* Not compliant - destination is overrun */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ARR33-C, STR31-C  
CWE : 121, 122, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
490 S
