A function pointer shall not be cast to a different function pointer type. An implicit cast is illegal in C, but not all compilers will produce an error. An explicit cast may lead to undefined behaviour.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_576( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 576 S : Function pointer is of wrong type.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef void (*fptr1)(void);
 
typedef UCHAR (*fptr2)(UCHAR uc);
 
 
static void static_576( void )
{
  /***/ 
  fptr1 afp;
  fptr2 bfp;
  afp = bfp; /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL35-C, EXP08-C  
CWE : 468, 686, 688, 758  
MISRA-AC : 11.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
577 S
Sizeof argument is a pointer.

The argument of sizeof is a pointer. Taking the size of a pointer to a type always returns the size of the pointer and not the size of the type. This can lead to unexpected behaviour if the developer mistakenly assumes that the size of the type is returned.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_577( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 577 S : Sizeof argument is a pointer.
 *******************************************************************/ 
UCHAR * puc;
 
static void static_577( void )
{
  UCHAR xx;
  /***/ 
  xx = sizeof(puc)  ;    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP01-C  
CWE : 467  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
578 S
Sizeof used in arithmetic expression.

Sizeof is used in an arithmetic expression. This may indicate that the developer is calculating the size of a type in a way that may lead to an incorrect value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_578( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 578 S : Sizeof used in arithmetic expression.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
UCHAR xx;
 
static void static_578( void )
{
  /***/ 
  xx = sizeof(xx) + 10U;    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP03-C  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
579 S
More than one variable per declaration.

Variable declarations shall not be combined with other declarators. Multiple declarators may lead to confusion regarding the type of an identifier.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 579 S : More than one variable in declaration.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct astr {
   UCHAR f1;
   SCHAR f2;
} okstr1,notokstr2;   /* not compliant */ 
 
struct astr okstruct1;
 
struct astr okstruct2,notokstruct1;  /* not compliant */ 
 
UCHAR global_ok1;
 
UCHAR global_ok2,gobal_notok1;  /* not compliant */ 
 
static void static_579( void )
{
  UINT_32 local_ok1;
 
  UINT_32 local_ok2,
          localnot_ok1;  /* not compliant */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL04-C  
CWE : 736  
FSB582-C++ : 1.5  
NETRINO : 8.1.a  
SEC-C : M1.2.1  
580 S
Macro redefinition without using #undef.

A macro shall not be redefined by another #define declaration unless a #undef is used. A redefinition is illegal in C unless the replacement lists are identical. However, not all compilers will produce an error.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
#define WHAT static
/* the next macro is not compliant */ 
#define WHAT volatile
 
INT_16 xx = 9;
 
#define OK   static
#undef OK
#define OK static
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 580 S : Macro redefinition without using #undef.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_580( void )
{
  /***/ 
  ;
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 1.1  
MISRA-AC : 1.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 1-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1, R.20.4  
SEC-C : X6.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
581 S
Loop conditions are independent.

The use of the logical or operator (||) in the terminating expression of a for loop may lead to unexpected behaviour. The logical and operator (&&) is preferred.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_581( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 581 S : Loop conditions are independent.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
INT_32 endcond ( void )
{
    return 1;
}
 
static void static_581( void )
{
   INT_32 ii = 0;
   INT_32 data[10];
   INT_32 end = 0;
 
   for ( ii=0; ( ii < 10 ) || ( !end ) ; ii++ ) /* not compliant */ 
   {
      data[ii] = ii;
      if ( endcond() != 0 )
      { end = 1;
      }
   }
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 13.5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2  
SEC-C : M3.3.1  
582 S
const object reassigned.

A const object shall not be reassigned. This is illegal in C and C++, but not all compilers will produce an error.

An exception is made if the object is not initialised or if a char* object is originally initialised or assigned to NULL. For the purposes of this standard a const char* pointer is treated as potentially pointing to a string literal and is therefore not allowed to be reassigned.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 582 S : const object reassigned.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
static void static_582( const UINT_16 * par1 )
{
  const char *str;
  str = NULL;    /* compliant - not previously initialised */
  str = "Ok";    /* compliant - previous assigned to NULL  */
 
  *par1 = 78U;    /* not compliant, object is const */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
SEC-C : X6.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
583 S
Comparison of pointer and string literal.

A pointer comparison will only succeed if two pointers point to the same memory location. A pointer to a string literal is unlikely to refer to the address of the string literal.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_583( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 583 S : Comparison of pointer and string literal.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
static void static_583( void )
{
    CHAR * str;
    str = "def" ;
    if ( str == "def" )    /* not compliant */ 
    {
       /***/ 
    }
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 597  
SEC-C : X2.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
584 S
Remainder of % op could be negative.

In some languages the sign of the result is dependent on the compiler, an example of this is C90.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
static void static_584( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 584 S : Remainder of % op could be negative.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
INT_16 ss = 0;
 
static void static_584( void )
{
  INT_16 rem;
   /***/ 
  rem = ss  % 4;    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT10-C  
CWE : 121, 122, 124, 126, 127, 129, 682, 823  
HIC++ : 10.18  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
585 S
Bitwise and arith operations on same data.

Mixing bitwise and arithmetic operations on the same data can reduce code readability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
#include <stdio.h>
 
static void static_585( void );
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 585 S : Bitwise and arith operations on same data.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef enum
{
   shift = 2U,
   mask  = 0x10U,
   part  = 1U
} constants;
 
static void static_585( void )
{
            UINT_32 a = ( getchar () == EOF ) ? 50U : 100U;
   volatile UINT_32 r;
  /***/ 
     r = a + ( a << shift ) + part;    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT14-C  
CWE : 738  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

586 S
Format is not %j for user defined type.

The length modifier %j should be used on user-defined integer types.

This standard will only be enabled by setting the modifier 350 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 586 S : Format is not %j for user defined type.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_586( void )
{
  /***/ 
   typedef   signed long long long s_t;
   s_t       s;
 
   if ( scanf ( "%lld" , & s ) != 1 )       /* not compliant  */ 
   {
      (void) printf ( "*" );
   }
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT15-C  
CWE : 738  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

587 S
Const local variable not immediately initialised.

A const local variable shall be immediately initialised, as a value cannot be assigned later.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_587( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 587 S : Const local variable not immediately initialised.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
static void static_587( void )
{
  /***/ 
  const INT_32 loc;    /* not compliant */ 
  loc = 0;
  INT_32 rr = loc;
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
SEC-C : R1.1.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
588 S
Use of system function.

The use of system function may lead to a security vulnerability or unexpected behaviour unless the input string is validated.

Example
#include <stdlib.h>
 
static void static_588( void );
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 588 S : Use of system function.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_588( void )
{
  /***/ 
  system(" wow" );    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ENV04-C  
CWE : 78, 88  
589 S
Format is not appropriate type.

The conversion format specifier does not match the argument used in the function call. This may lead to undefined behaviour.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 589 S : Format is not appropriate type.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_589( void )
{
    int x = 7;
    float ff = 8.9F;
    unsigned u = 9U;
    char * ss = "oh my" ;
    (void) printf(" \n %d ", u);
    (void) printf(" \n %d ", ff); /* not compliant */  
    (void) printf(" \n %s ", x);  /* not compliant */ 
    (void) printf(" \n %d ", ss); /* not compliant */ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL11-C, FIO00-C  
CWE : 686, 688, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
590 S
Mode fault in fopen.

The mode string in the call of fopen is not one of the standard strings. This may lead to undefined behaviour. The permitted modes are "r", "w", "a", "r+", "w+", "a+" and those modes with "b" appended.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/****************************************
 * Standard 590 S : Mode fault in fopen.
 ****************************************/ 
 
static void static_590( void )
{
  /***/ 
  fopen("afile1.h" , "wb+" ); 
  fopen("afile2.h" , "c" );  /* Not Compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO11-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
591 S
Inappropriate use of file pointer.

The use of a copy of a FILE object may lead to unexpected behaviour. The address of the FILE pointer may be significant.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
static void static_591( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 591 S : Inappropriate use of file pointer.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
FILE file_f;
FILE file_g;
FILE * hptr;
FILE * iptr;
 
static void static_591( void )
{
   hptr = fopen(" afile.h" ," w" );
 
   iptr = hptr;        /* OK */
   file_f = *hptr;     /* not compliant */ 
   file_g = file_f;    /* not compliant */ 
 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO38-C  
CWE : 743  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
592 S
Use of filename based functions.

fopen, freopen, remove and rename use a filename as an argument. This may lead to a security vulnerability or unexpected behaviour unless the input string is validated.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
static void static_592( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 592 S : Use of filename based functions.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
static void static_592( void )
{
  /***/ 
 
  (void) remove(" afile.h" );             /* not compliant */ 
  (void) rename(" afile.h" , "bfile.h" );  /* not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO01-C  
CWE : 367, 676  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
593 S
Use fseek() rather than rewind().

The fseek function should be used instead of the rewind function, since fseek returns a value to indicate that the rewind has been successful.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
static void static_593( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 593 S : Use fseek() rather than rewind().
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_593( void )
{
  FILE *fptr = fopen(" afile.h" ," r" );
  /***/ 
  rewind(fptr);    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO07-C  
CWE : 743  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
594 S
Use setvbuf() rather than setbuf().

The setvbuf function should be used instead of the setbuf function, since setvbuf returns a value to indicate that the stream has been successfully altered.

Example
#include <stdio.h> 
 
static void static_594( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 594 S : Use setvbuf() rather than setbuf().
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void static_594( void )
{
  FILE *fptr = fopen(" afile.h" ," w" );
  setbuf(fptr, NULL);    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO12-C  
CWE : 743  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
595 S
Base member with change of access.

A base member has undergone a change of access. The behaviour may be contrary to the developer's expectations.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_595( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 595 S : Base member with change of access.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
class base_595 {
   public:
   SINT_32 basefield;
};
 
 
class derived_595: private base_595 {
   public:
   base_595::basefield;  /* not compliant */ 
};
 
static void static_595( void )
{
  /***/ 
  ;
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

596 S
Namespace name starts with lower case letter.

The first word of the name of a namespace will begin with an uppercase letter. All other letters will be lowercase.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_596( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 596 S : Namespace name starts with lower case letter.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
namespace lowercase  /* not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 nn = 0;
}
 
static void static_596( void )
{
  /***/ 
  ;
  /***/ 
}
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 50  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

597 S
Use of placement new.

The placement version of the new operator has been used.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
static void static_597( void );
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 597 S : Use of placement new.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
class CApple {
   public:
   CApple(SINT_32 iWorms = 0, FLOAT_32 fPrice = 1.0)
   : m_iWorms(iWorms)
   , m_fPrice(fPrice)
   {
   }
   public:
   SINT_32 m_iWorms;
   FLOAT_32 m_fPrice;
};
 
inline void * operator new(unsigned int st, CApple * ca)
{
  return ca;
}
 
static void static_597( void )
{
  /***/ 
   CApple automaticApple (8,0.0);
   CApple * pApple4 = new(& automaticApple) CApple  ;    /* not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

598 S
Alternative array indexing used.

The subscripting operator does not specify which operand is the pointer to the array and which is its index. This standard reports when the index is used as first operand.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 598 S : Alternative array indexing used.
 *******************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 static_598( const UINT_32 val )
{
  UINT_32 data[2];
 
  1U[data] = val;       /* not compliant */
 
  return  1U[data];     /* not compliant */
 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
599 S
Use of && or || in initialisation.

A logical operator ( && or || ) has been detected within an initialisation of a non-boolean variable. It is likely that it has been confused with a bitwise operator, e.g. && instead of &.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 599 S : Use of && or || in initialisation.
 *******************************************************************/
 
#define a  77U
#define b  32U
 
UINT_32  arr[4]= {  a | b, 
                    a || b,  /* Not compliant */ 
                    a && b,  /* Not compliant */
                    a & b 
                  }; 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
600 S
Argument of strlen is unterminated.

The argument of strlen shall be terminated by a null character. Otherwise, the behaviour of the program is undefined.

Example
#include <string.h>
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 600 S : Argument of strlen is unterminated.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void static_600( void )
{
  SINT_32 xx;
  char arr [3] = { 'a', 'b', 'c' };
  xx = strlen(arr);    /* not compliant */  
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : STR32-C  
CWE : 170  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
601 S
Insufficient overridden members.

In a derived class, if not all of the overloaded virtual functions of the base class are overridden, then other functions will be hidden. Hidden member functions can make the code more difficult to understand and lead to unexpected results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 601 S : Insuffient overriden members.
 *******************************************************************/
 
class  Base {
   public:
   void f( char ){;}
   void f( int ){;}
   virtual void one (int &ll);
   virtual void one (char ll);
};
 
class Derived: public Base {
   public:
   void f( int ){;}
   virtual void one (char ll);   // not compliant 
};
 
void static_601 ( void )
{
   Derived d;
   Base& bref = d;
   bref.f('c');         // calls Base::f(char)
   bref.one('c');       // calls Derived::one(char)
   bref.one((int)'c');  // calls Base::one(int)
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2009 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.5  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

602 S
strtok may change the parse string.

The function strtok modifies its parse string, which is the first argument. Each time strtok is called the function parses the string up to the first instance of a character in the second argument. This character is then overwritten with the null character \0. This can lead to unexpected results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <string.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 602 S : strtok may change parse string.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void STATIC_602 ( void )
{
   char *token;
   char *path = "/usr/bin:/bin:/sbin";
   token = strtok ( path, ":" );         /* not compliant */
   while ( token = strtok ( 0, ":" ) )
   {
      ;
   }
   /* path is now just "/usr/bin" */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : STR06-C  
CWE : 464, 741  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
603 S
Parameter should be declared * const.

Any pointer parameter, whose value is not intended to change, should be protected by the use of const. This refers to the pointer it-self, not the data to which the pointer is pointing to. Making the use of the parameter explicit leads to greater precision in the definition of the function interface.

This standard does not apply to the parameters of main.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 603 S : Parameter should be declared * const.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 global;
 
void static_603 ( SINT_32 * ptr1,        /* Not Compliant */
                  SINT_32 * const ptr2,  /* Compliant */
                  SINT_32 * ptr3         /* Compliant */
                )
{
  *ptr1 = global;   /* ptr1 not changed, only its data */
  *ptr2 = global;   
  ptr3 = &global;   /* ptr3 changed */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2011 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-1-1  
604 S
Use of numeric literal as array bound/subscript.

The use of numeric literals, i.e. magic numbers, is generally accepted as undesirable due to the impact on maintainability. This standard checks for uses of literals in array declarations and array indexing. Symbolic names in the form of const variables, or enum constants, should be used instead.

This standard also extends to numeric literals substituted via macros. It is acknowledged that macros might have to be used - particularly with the C language, where the usage of const is more limited than C++. The standard can be relaxed to allow numeric literals substituted via macros by setting the modifier 163 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file. By default, the standard is configured to allow numeric literals substituted via macros.

It is also recognised that 0 is commonly used in denoting a pointer to the start of an array and so may be excluded from the rule check. This may be done by setting the modifier 217 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Alternatively, all numbers in a specified range can be allowed by configuring the corresponding parametrised value in the c/cppreport.dat file. For example:

 604 S C  CWE:128  will not produce a warning for literals up to 128 (for the CWE model)
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 604 S : Use of numeric literal as array bound/subscript.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
enum { LIMIT = 100 };
 
#define ARRAY_SIZE 100
 
void static_604( void )
{
   SINT_32 array_ok1[ARRAY_SIZE]; /* Compliant but can be prohibited with modifier 163 */
   SINT_32 array_ok2[LIMIT];
   SINT_32 array_nok[100];        /* Not Compliant */
 
   SINT_32 *ptr = &array_ok1[0];  /* Not compliant but permitted with modifier 217*/
 
   array_nok[99] = 3;             /* Not Compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2011 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JSF++ AV : 151   Modifiers : 217 = 1
605 S
Use of long long.

This standard reports the use of the long long type, which is not part of the C 90 or C++ languages.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 605 S : Use of long long.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_605(void)
{
  long long llvar = 3LL; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
606 S
Cast involving function pointer.

Casts to and from a function pointer can lead to undefined behaviour if a function is then called by means of a pointer whose type is not compatible with the called function.

This standard can be relaxed to allow casts to function pointers by setting the modifier 398 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
typedef INT_32 (* fptr) (INT_32 p); 
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 606 S : Cast involving function pointer.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void myProc(UINT_32 x)
{
}
 
void static_606 ( UINT_32 u, fptr fp )
{
  fp = (fptr) & myProc; /* not compliant */
  fp = (fptr) & u;      /* not compliant if modifier is 0 */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP36-C  
CWE : 737  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-2-6   Modifiers : 398 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.1  
607 S
Double negation found.

A double negation may be used to ensure the result of an expression is boolean (0/1). However, the use of a double negation can make code difficult to read and maintain, potentially obscuring the intentions of the programmer.

The use of such constructs should therefore be avoided.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 607 S : Double negation found.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_607(void)
{
  UINT_32 x = 1;
 
  if (!!(x == 1)) /* not compliant */
  {
    x = 2;
  } 
  else if (!!!(x == 2)) /* not compliant */
  {
    x = 1;
  }
 
  if (!!!!(x == 1)) /* not compliant */
  {
    x = 2;
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
608 S
Use of explicitly undefined language feature.

No reliance should be placed on undefined behaviour caused by the use of undefined language features specified in the language standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 608 S : Use of explicitly undefined language feature.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_608( void )
{
  INT_32 i = 3 u; /* not compliant */
 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
609 S
Use of implicitly undefined language feature.

No reliance should be placed on undefined behaviour caused by the use of undefined language features.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 609 S : Use of implicitly undefined language feature.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
610 S
Label is unused.

The inclusion of unused labels in source code may lead to confusion over whether the label is intentionally not used. This detracts from long-term maintainability of the code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 610 S : Label is unused.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_610(void)
{
   INT_16 x = 6;
label1:   /* not compliant */
   x = 0;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.6  
611 S
Line splice used in // comment.

The use of line-splicing in single-line comments can lead to confusion and the possibility of unintentional removal of executable code.

Programmers should make their intentions clear by replacing line splices with multiple single-line comments. Testbed can be configured to permit line-splicing by setting the modifier 402 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 611 S : Line splice used in // comment.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_611(BOOL test)
{
 
   INT_32 x = 0; // not compliant  \
   if (test)
   {
     x = 10;    /* This is always executed */
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC04-C  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.3.2  
612 S
inline function should be declared static.

The use of an inline function with external linkage may lead to unexpected behaviour. It is undefined in some languages what happens if no definition of an inline function with external linkage is visible in a translation unit. Even if the definition is present, it is unspecified as to whether the function is inlined or not.

Both these problems can be avoided if the inline function is declared with internal linkage by using the static keyword.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 612 S : inline function should be declared static.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static INT_32 count = 1;
 
inline void static_612 (void)    /* not compliant */
{
  count++;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.10  
613 S
Use of restrict keyword.

The restrict keyword can be used as a declaration of intent to the compiler. It says that for the lifetime of a restrict-qualified pointer declaration, only the pointer itself (or a value derived from the pointer) shall be used to access the object addressed by the pointer.

Although this can lead to improved compiler optimisations, if there is an overlap in the memory addressed by restrict-qualified pointers then the compiler may generate code which does not behave as expected.

This standard is only applicable if using the C99 standard. It will only be enabled by setting the modifier 350 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 613 S : Use of restrict keyword.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_613 (INT_32 * restrict p, /* not compliant */
                        const INT_32 *q
                       )
{
   *p = *q;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL33-C   Modifiers : 350 = 1
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.14   Modifiers : 350 = 1
614 S
Use of static keyword in array parameter.

The use of the static keyword in the declaration of an array parameter index can be used to inform the compiler that the array contains at least a specified number of elements. The compiler may use this information to generate more efficient code.

However, if the programmer passes an array which does not meet the minimum number of elements, the behaviour is undefined.

This standard is only applicable if using the C99 standard. It will only be enabled by setting the modifier 350 to 1 in the c/cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 614 S : Use of static keyword in array parameter.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void static_614 ( INT_16 a [ static 20 ] /* not compliant */ )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.6   Modifiers : 350 = 1
615 S
Conditional operator has incompatible types.

This standard performs strong type checking between the two alternatives of a ternary expression when the two types are pointers. This is a constraint error in C, but not all compilers detect this problem.

Example
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 615 S : Conditional operator has incompatible types.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void static_615(int which)
{
  void *x;
  union 
  {
    int i;
    double d;
  } u;
 
  u.i = 1;
 
  /* not compliant; incompatible types */
  x = which ? &u.i : &u.d;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 144  
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
FSB582-C++ : 1.1  
MISRA-AC : 1.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 1-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.1  
SEC-C : R2.3.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
616 S
Preprocessor result not 0 or 1.

Macro identifiers specified in #if pre-processor directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1.

Example
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 616 S : Preprocessor result not 0 or 1.
 *******************************************************************/
 
#define ONE 1
#define ZERO 0
 
/* compliant set */
#if ONE
int ok1;
#elif ZERO
int ok2;
#elif 0
int ok3;
#elif 1
int ok4;
#elif ONE
int ok5;
#endif
 
#if ZERO
int ok6;
#endif
#if 0
int ok7;
#endif
#if 1
int ok8;
#endif
#if ONE + ZERO
int ok9;
#endif
#if 7449 - 7000 - 448
int ok10;
#endif
 
/* not compliant; result not 0 or 1 */
#if 2
int duff1;
#endif
 
/* not compliant; result not 0 or 1*/
#if -1
int duff2;
#endif
 
void static_616(void)
{
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.8  
617 S
Function call may return unexpected value.

In C90 the behaviour is undefined if a function with no return expression is called and the missing value is used. It is a constraint error in C99 to have a return statement without an expression unless the return type is void.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 617 S : Function call may return unexpected value.
 *************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 func_not_ok(void) 
{ 
  return;
}
 
void static_617(void)
{ 
  UINT_32 i = func_not_ok(); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
/
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM
618 S
Use of memcmp between structures.

memcmp includes the padding data when comparing two structures, but the value of the padding bits is unspecified.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <string.h>
 
struct struct_a
{
  UINT_32 value;
};
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 618 S : Use of memcmp between structures.
 *********************************************************/
 
void static_618(void)
{
  struct struct_a s1 = {10};
  struct struct_a s2 = {10};
 
  BOOL test = memcmp(&s1, &s2, sizeof(struct struct_a)); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP04-C  
CWE : 188  
619 S
Function address compared with zero or NULL.
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 619 S : Function address compared with zero or NULL.
 *******************************************************************/
 
INT_32 fnA ( void )
{
  return 1;
}
 
void static_619 ( void ) 
{
  if (fnA == 0) /* not compliant */
  {
     ;
  }
 
  if ( fnA )  /* not compliant */
  {
    ; 
  } 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
/
620 S
Initialisation designator duplicated.

The C standard does not specify what happens when the use of designated initializers causes the same element of an object to be initialised more than once.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct enddate { INT_32 year; INT_32 month; INT_32 day; };
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 620 S : Initialisation designator duplicated.
 ********************************************************/
 
void static_620(void)
{ 
  INT_32 a3[4] = { [0] = -5, [1] = -4, [2] = -3, [2] = -2 }; /* not compliant */
 
  struct enddate last = { .year = 2012, .month = 12, .year = 2000 }; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
/
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.9.4  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

621 S
Variable-length array declared.

There are various unspecified and undefined behaviours associated with variable-length arrays.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************
 * Standard 621 S : Variable-length array declared.
 **************************************************/
 
void static_621 (UINT_32 n)
{ 
  INT_32 vla [ n ]; /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
/
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.8  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

622 S
Macro parameters are not unique within limits.

Macro parameter names will not rely on the significance of more than 31 characters, as required by the ISO standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/* not compliant as names are unique */
#define M( this_is_a_parameter_of_macro_m_first,  this_is_a_parameter_of_macro_m_second ) \
   ((this_is_a_parameter_of_macro_m_first) +(this_is_a_parameter_of_macro_m_second))
 
 
/*****************************************************************
 * Standard 622 S : Macro parameters are not unique within limits.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
static UINT_32 static_622( void )
{
  return M ( 3U, 5U );
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.4  
623 S
String assigned to non const object.

String literals should only be assigned to objects with pointer to const char type. This includes initialisation, assignments, function arguments and function returns.

The location of a string literal is determined at the time the program is compiled. For example, it may be placed in an area of memory marked as read-only, or physically stored within the binary executable. It is unsafe to attempt to change any such text, as the consequences are unpredictable.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 *  Standard 623 S : String assigned to non const object.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
CHAR * return_string(void)
{
  return "fred";  /* not compliant */
}
 
void static_623(void)
{
 
  CHAR * string_test = "test"; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : STR05-C  
CWE : 741  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.7.4  
626 S
#define of keyword.

The macro pre-processor can define keywords which can lead to confusion.

Note that MISRA-C:2012 checking needs to be enabled in order for this violation to be detected, either via selection of the MISRA-C:2012 programming model or by explicitly enabling the 391 modifier in the cvals.dat file (TBmisra license permitting). Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************
 * Standard 626 S : #define of keyword.
 ****************************************/ 
 
/* not compliant */
#define int UINT_32
 
void static_626(void)
{
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.4   Modifiers : 391 = 1
627 S
Initialiser both positional and designational.

The use of both positional and designated initialisers in the same initialisation is likely to indicate a programming error.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 627 S : Initialiser both positional and designational.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
void static_627(void)
{
  INT_32 a1[2][2] = {{0}, [1][0] = 0, 1};   /* not compliant */
 
  INT_32 a2[2][2] = {[0][1] = 0, {0, 1}};   /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.9.2, R.9.3, R.9.4  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

628 S
Macro not used in translation unit.

Redundant macros reduce the maintainability of code.

This standard does not apply to macro definitions that occur in regions of code that are omitted by the pre-processor.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define SIZE_USED 6
#define DATA 3           /* not compliant */
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 628 S : Macro not used in translation unit.
 *******************************************************/
 
INT_32 static_628(void)
{
#define SIZE_NOT_USED 6   /* not compliant */
 
return SIZE_USED;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.5  
629 S
Divide by zero found.

Measures shall be taken to prevent run-time failures caused by integer divide by zero operations.

The user must then manually check whether the division is appropriately protected.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************
 * Standard 629 : Divide by zero found.
 ***************************************/ 
 
void static_629( void )
{
   SINT_32 local_denominator = 1;
   SINT_32 numerator = 9;
 
   SINT_32 result = numerator / ( local_denominator - 1 );  /* not compliant */ 
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : INT33-C  
CWE : 369  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.1  
630 S
Duplicated enumeration value.

The duplication of an enumeration constant may not be intentional and may lead to unexpected behaviour. Duplication is allowed if both enumeration constants are explicitly initialised to the same value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 630 S : Duplicated enumeration value.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_630(void)
{
   enum traffic{ red=3, amber, green, yellow=4 }; /* Non-compliant - yellow also 4 */
 
   enum traffic_ok{ Xred=3, Xamber=4, Xgreen, Xyellow=4 }; /* Compliant */
   /* ... */ 
 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 738  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.12  
631 S
Declaration not reachable.

Jumping over an initialisation will cause the object to have an indeterminate value when it is used. Though space for the object is created at the start of the enclosing block, the initialisation does not occur until the initialisation statement is reached.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 631 S : Declaration not reachable.
 **********************************************/ 
 
void static_631( void )
{
  goto  L1;               
     UINT_16 x = 10U; /* not compliant - x is never initialised */
  L1:
     x = x + 1U; 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP33-C  
CWE : 457  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.9.1  
632 S
Use of // comment in pre-processor directive or macro defn.

The single line comment // is not available in all compilers and should not be used.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
#define SQ_2 (2*2) // Non-compliant comment
 
/******************************************************************************
 * Standard 632 S : Use of // comment in pre-processor directive or macro defn.
 ******************************************************************************/
 
INT_32 static_632(void)
{
  return SQ_2;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CMSE : 10.2.2  
DERA : 1  
FSB582-C : 3.1.1  
GJB : 4.10.2.2

MISRA-AC : 2.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 2.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.2  
SEC-C : P1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

633 S
Use of a broken or risky cryptography algorithm.

The use of broken or risky cryptographic algorithms is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information. This standard checks for the use various algorithms by highlighting the use of CALG_DES, CALG_3DES or CALG_RC5 as a parameter to CryptDeriveKey.

Example
#include <wincrypt.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 633 S : Use of a broken or risky cryptography algorithm.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void static_633(HCRYPTPROV hProv, HCRYPTHASH hHash, HCRYPTKEY *hKey)
{
   CryptDeriveKey(hProv, CALG_3DES, hHash, CRYPT_EXPORTABLE, hKey); /* Not Compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 327  
634 S
Empty block found.

The use of empty block statements can either be due to incomplete code or deliberate policy to show that the possibility has been considered. The options flagged are: 

	{ }
	{;}

The inclusion of a comment within the empty block statement { /* */ } is deemed to indicate that the absence of executable code is deliberate, and hence no standard will report in this circumstance: 

	{ /* ... */ }
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 634 S : Empty block found
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void static_634 (UINT_32 name_x)
{
   UINT_32 count = 0u;
 
   if (name_x == 0u)
   { count = 1u; }
   else 
   {  }  /* not compliant */
 
   for ( count; count < 10u; count++ )
   { 
     ;  
   }  /* not compliant */
 
   {
     /* compliant empty block, unless modifier 422 set */
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 398   Modifiers : 422 = 1
635 S
Cast from pointer to float type.

A cast from a pointer to a float type shall not be performed, as the result is undefined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 635 S : Cast from pointer to float type.
 ******************************************************/
 
void static_635 (FLOAT_32 *f_ptr)
{
  FLOAT_32 ss = (FLOAT_32)f_ptr; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP11-C  
CWE : 737, 758  
DERA : 45  
GJB : 4.12.1.1  
HIC++ : 7.7  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182  
MISRA-AC : 11.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.6  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
636 S
Cast from float type to pointer.

A cast from a pointer to a float type shall not be performed, as the result is undefined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 636 S : Cast from float type to pointer.
 ******************************************************/
 
void static_636 ( void )
{
  void *p = (void*) 3.4f; /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP11-C  
CWE : 737, 758  
DERA : 45  
GJB : 4.12.2.1  
HIC++ : 7.7  
HIS : 45  
JSF++ AV : 182  
MISRA-AC : 11.2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 45  
MISRA-C:2004 : 11.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.11.6  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
637 S
# operand followed by ##.

The order of evaluation of the # and ## operators is unspecified, which can lead to unexpected behaviour. In particular, the result of the # operator is a string literal, which is unlikely to produce a valid token when concatenated with another pre-processing token.

Example
/************************************************
 * Standard 637 S : # operand followed by ##.
 ************************************************/
 
#define JOIN( x, y ) #x ## y
                     /* not compliant */
 
void static_637(void)
{
    const char *name = JOIN (Control, 1 );
                  /* syntax error unless ## is evaluated before # */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.20.11  
638 S
Memory allocation non-conformant with type.
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h> 
 
/*****************************************************
 * 638 S : Memory allocation non-conformant with type.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
static void static_638 ( void )
{
/* To be added */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
639 S
Potentially missing else statement.

When an if statement is immediately followed by an opening {, it may indicate that an else or else if branch is missing.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * 639 S : Potentially missing else statement.
 *****************************************************/ 
 
static void static_639( void )
{
  UINT_32 name_x = 1u;
 
  if(name_x == 0u)
  { /* ... */ }
  { /* ... */ } /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2014 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
1 C
Cyclomatic complexity greater than ***.

This is similar check to n lines of code. It is used to limit the size (and hence complexity) of procedures. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard. The configuration is made in the c/cppreport.dat or c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 1 C : Cyclomatic Complexity greater than ***
 ********************************************************/ 
 
BOOL isHexDigit( CHAR Hex )
{
  BOOL bResult;
 
  bResult = FALSE;
 
  if ((Hex == '0') || (Hex == '1') || (Hex == '2') || (Hex == '3') ||
      (Hex == '4') || (Hex == '5') || (Hex == '6') || (Hex == '7') ||
      (Hex == '8') || (Hex == '9') || (Hex == 'A') || (Hex == 'a') ||
      (Hex == 'B') || (Hex == 'b') || (Hex == 'C') || (Hex == 'c') ||
      (Hex == 'D') || (Hex == 'd') || (Hex == 'E') || (Hex == 'e') ||
      (Hex == 'F') || (Hex == 'f'))
  {
    bResult = TRUE;
  }
 
  return bResult;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.9  
HIC++ : 4.1  
JSF++ AV : 3  
LMTCP : 3  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
2 C
Procedure is not reducible in terms of intervals.

Reducibility in terms of interval analysis essentially means that the procedure is not a sequence of cleanly nested loops.

Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard
3 C
Procedure contains essential knots.

This means that the code is poorly structured and reordering the constructs might produce an improvement. More information can be found on essential knots in the Testbed documentation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 2 C : Procedure is not reducible in terms of intervals.
 * Standard 3 C : Procedure contains essential knots.
 ******************************************************************/
 
void complex_2_3 ( BOOL c_1, BOOL c_2 )
{
   if (c_1)
   {
label1: ;
   }
   if (c_2)
   {
      goto label1;
   }
}  /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard
4 C
Procedure is not structured.

This follows from the structured programming templates supplied. Details of the structure programming templates can be found in the Testbed documentation.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void complex_4 ( BOOL c_3, BOOL c_4 )
{
label1:
   if (c_3)
   {
      if (c_4) { goto label1; }
   }
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard
5 C
Procedure contains infinite loop.

An infinite loop may arise from a control flow loop that has no exit mechanism of any type.

Further infinite loop detection is performed in by 26 S and 28 D.

Example
void complex_5 ( void  )
{
label1:
     /* .... */
     goto label1;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 835  
DERA : 142  
JPL : 2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , TBrun Requires
6 C
Procedure has more than one entry point.

This involves the use of entry statements which is compiler dependent.

Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.7.9  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
7 C
Procedure has more than one exit point.

Structured programming usually requires procedures to be single entry single exit. Exits occur at the end of the procedure and at each return statement in functions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 7 C : Procedure has more than one exit point.
 ********************************************************/
 
INT_32 complex_7 (INT_32 status)
{
   if ( status == 0 )
   {
       return 1;
   }
   return 2;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 82  
EADS-C : 111  
FSB582-C : 3.7.9  
FSB582-C++ : 9.6  
HIC++ : 5.9  
JSF++ AV : 113  
LMTCP : 208, 356  
MISRA-AC : 14.7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-6-5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 82  
MISRA-C:2004 : 14.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.15.5  
NETRINO : 6.2.c  
SEC-C : M3.1.5  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , UML , VSOS
8 C
Unused LDRA_INSPECTED annotation.

A spurious inspect annotation for a particular standard is present in the code. The line should be removed to avoid confusion and aid readability.

9 C
Ess Cyclomatic Complexity greater than ***.

Whereas cyclomatic complexity, v(G), is a measure of decision logic, essential cyclomatic complexity, ev(G), is a measure of the quality of that logic. It is derived as the cyclomatic complexity after structured programming primitives have been removed from the control graph. The reduced graph then gives an indication of the unstructured-ness of the code.

1 <= ev(G) <= v(G)

An essential complexity of 1 reflects a perfectly structured control graph. The essential cyclomatic complexity shall not be greater than the value quoted in the violation text. Poor structure makes software harder to understand and also impedes testing.

10 C
Loop depth greater than ***.

Loop nesting is both error prone and makes code difficult to understand and maintain. Loop depth shall be no greater than the specified limit.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number, defaulting to 3 for this standard. The configuration is made in the c/cppreport.dat or c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************
 * Standard 10 C : Loop depth greater than ***.
 ***********************************************/
 
void complex_10 ( UINT_32 ee,
                  UINT_32 ff,
                  UINT_32 gg,
                  UINT_32 hh)
{
  UINT_32 aa,
          bb,
          cc,
          dd;
  for (aa = 1U; aa < ee; aa++)
  {
    for (bb = aa; bb < ff; bb++)
    {
      for (cc = bb; cc < gg; cc++)
      {
        for (dd = cc; dd < hh; dd++)  /* this takes loop depth to > 3 */
        {
          /* something */
        }
      }
    }
  }
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 9.4  
11 C
More than *** depth 1 loops.

A series of same depth loops within a procedure indicates a poorly structured program, which is likely to be inefficient as well as difficult to maintain and test. The number of depth 1 loops shall be no greater than the specified limit.

The *** symbols refer to a user definable number, defaulting to 10 for this standard. The configuration is made in the c/cppreport.dat or c/cpppen.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the manual.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************
 * Standard 11 C : More than *** depth 1 loops
 ***********************************************/
 
void complex_11 ( UINT_32 zz )
{
  UINT_32 aa,
          bb,
          cc,
          dd,
          ee,
          ff,
          gg,
          hh,
          ii,
          jj,
          kk;
 
  for (aa = 1U; aa < zz; aa++)
  {
  }
 
  for (bb = 1U; bb < zz; bb++)
  {
  }
 
  for (cc = 1U; cc < zz; cc++)
  {
  }
 
  for (dd = 1U; dd < zz; dd++)
  {
  }
 
  for (ee = 1U; ee < zz; ee++)
  {
  }
 
  for (ff = 1U; ff < zz; ff++)
  {
  }
 
  for (gg = 1U; gg < zz; gg++)
  {
  }
 
  for (hh = 1U; hh < zz; hh++)
  {
  }
 
  for (ii = 1U; ii < zz; ii++)
  {
  }
 
  for (jj = 1U; jj < zz; jj++)
  {
  }
 
  for (kk = 1U; kk < zz; kk++)  /* this takes number of depth 1 loops to > 10 */
  {
  }
} /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
12 C
More than *** knots.

A knot describes the incidence of one jump in the code crossing another. Hence the number of knots in a procedure is a measure of the disjointed-ness of the code and consequently its complexity. The specified complexity limit shall not be exceeded.

13 C
More then *** essential knots.

A knot describes the incidence of one jump in the code crossing another. The number of essential knots is a measure of the code complexity arising from unstructured constructs. It is derived as the number of knots remaining after structured programming primitives have been removed from the associated control graph. For a structured program the number of essential knots is 0. The specified complexity limit shall not be exceeded.

1 D
Unused procedure parameter.

The procedure does not use the parameter in any way and the resultant computations will be unaffected if the parameter is removed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************
 * Standard 1 D : Unused Procedure Parameter
 ********************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_001( UINT_32 p_1, UINT_32 p_2 )
{
   UINT_32 v_1;
   v_1 = p_1;
   v_1++;
   return v_1;
}  /* not compliant - p_2 is not used */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC13-C  
CMSE : 1.2.10  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-11, 0-1-12  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.7  
SEC-C : M1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , TBrun Requires , VSOS
2 D
Function does not return a value on all paths.

A non-void function that does not return a value can cause undefined behaviour if the calling function tries to use the value.

This standard checks for functions which have one path that returns a value and at least one other path that does not return a value. This may be due to a missing return statement or a return statement containing a null expression. Note that in paths where an exception is thrown there will be no return value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 2 D : Function does not return a value on all paths.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
static INT_32 SDA_002( INT_32 par_1 )
{
  if ( par_1 == 0 )
  {
    return 0;
  }
  else if ( par_1 == 1 )
  {
    return ;  /* return with null expression */
  }
  else
  {
    ;        /* missing return statement */
  }
} /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.9.1  
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CMSE : 9.1.1  
CWE : 758  
DERA : 75  
GJB : 4.9.1.1  
HIC++ : 5.10  
HIS : 75  
JSF++ AV : 114  
LMTCP : 209  
MISRA-AC : 16.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-4-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 75  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.4  
SEC-C : X2.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
3 D
Actual parameter is also global to procedure.

This is generated when a procedure which uses a global variable x also has x as a formal parameter.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 glob1 = 1;
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 3 D : Actual Parameter is also global to procedure
 *************************************************************/ 
 
static void fn( UINT_32 *par_1 )
{
   *par_1 = *par_1 + glob1++;
}
 
static void SDA_003(void)
{
   fn(&glob1);  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 148  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
4 D
Variables declared but not used in code analysed.

Variables have not been used and hence can be removed.

This standard is superseded by 94 D which provides a more detailed report.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 4 D : Variables declared but not used in code analysed.
 ******************************************************************/ 
 
static UINT_32 SDA_004( void )
{
   UINT_32 v_1, v_2;  /* v_2 is not used */
 
   v_1 = 0U;
   return v_1;
 
} /* not compliant */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
5 D
UR data flow anomalies found.

At least one variable is used before it is given a value. This result is generated regardless of whether a compiler claims to initialise all or some of the variables.

This standard is superseded by 69 D which provides a more detailed report.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 SDA_005 ( void) ;
 
/*********************************************
 * Standard 5 D : UR data flow anomalies found.
 *********************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_005 ( void)
{
   UINT_32 v_1 , v_2 ;
 
   v_1 = v_2 ;   /* v_2 is undefined(U), but is then referenced(R) */
   v_2 = v_1 ;
   return v_2 ;
 
} /* not compliant */
6 D
Recursion in procedure calls found.

Recursion is often banned because of the fear of running out of store, but recursive calls can also cause loops when the programmers are unaware of the calling structure.

Example
#include "c_standards.h";
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 6 D : Recursion in procedures calls found.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_006( UINT_32 par_a )  /* not compliant */
{
   UINT_32 result;
   UINT_32 value;
 
   if (par_a != 1 )
   {
      value = par_a;
      value--;
 
      result = SDA_006( value ) * par_a;
   }
   else
   {
      result=1u;
   }
   return (result);
}
 
UINT_32 Test_006(void)  /* not compliant */
{
   UINT_32 result;
   result = SDA_006( 20 );
   return result;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 674  
DERA : 70  
EADS-C : 117  
HIS : 70  
JPL : 1  
JSF++ AV : 119  
LMTCP : 219  
MISRA-AC : 16.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-5-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 70  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.2  
SEC-C : R3.4.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
7 D
DU data flow anomalies found.

DU anomalies are unnecessary and can always be removed with a consequent improvement in the readability and efficiency of the code.

This standard is superseded by 70 D which provides a more detailed report.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 7 D : DU data flow anomalies found.
 **********************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_007( void )
{
   BOOL    flag = FALSE;  /* flag is defined(D), but never used */
   /* ... */ 
 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
8 D
DD data flow anomalies found.

A variable exists that has been defined, and has been redefined without being referenced after the definition. DD anomalies can arise from programming errors. Information about the variables affected are listed in the Data Flow Analysis Report.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************
 * Standard 8 D : DD data flow anomalies found.
 **********************************************/ 
 
static BOOL SDA_008( void )
{
   BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
   flag = TRUE;  /* flag hasn't been referenced after its definition */
 
   return flag;
 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 563  
JPL : 7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.2  
SEC-C : X1.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
9 D
Defined parameter has possible clear path.

In this case a call to the procedure does not necessarily mean that an output variable is given a value. This can lead to serious errors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 9 D : Defined parameter has possible clear path.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_009(UINT_32 p_1, UINT_32* p_2 )
{
   if (p_1 != 5)
   {
      *p_2 = p_1 + 6;
   }
} /* not compliant - p_2 is not given a value in the else branch */
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 151  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , RUNTIME , Standard
10 D
Globals used inside procedure.

Some authorities believe that the use of global variables is bad programming practice. Certainly it is more difficult to reuse procedures that use such variables. Furthermore, the order of initialisation across translation units is unspecified, and so any module which contains the appropriate declaration may access a global variable defined elsewhere before it has received an initial value.

This standard is limited to non-constant variables that have external linkage, since these are the variables that might be altered in other translation units. It will also be generated for procedures that indirectly access global variables through procedure calls. Checks on global function pointers are covered by 95 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 globl = 1U;         /* Global variable  */
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 10 D : Globals used inside procedure
 ************************************************/ 
 
void direct_access1( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
  *par_1 = *par_1 + globl;  /* Global variable accessed */ 
 
} /* not compliant */
 
 
void indirect_access(void)
{
  UINT_32 local_var = 42U;     /* Local variable */
  direct_access1(&local_var);  /* Indirect access: called procedure accesses a global */
 
} /* not compliant */
 
 
static void SDA_010(void)
{
  indirect_access();
             /* Indirect access: called procedure calls a procedure
              * which accesses a global.
              */ 
}  /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 4.6  
HIC++ : 6.6, 8.2.2  
11 D
Parameters do not match expected actions.

This arises if either a purely input variable is given a value or an input/output variable is not given a value.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 11 D : Parameters do not match expected actions
 **********************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_011( UINT_32 par_1, UINT_32 par_2 )
{
   if (par_2 != 1U)
   {
      par_1 = 0U;  /* par_1 is treated as an input only variable */
   }
   else
   {
      par_1= 1U;
   }
 
} /* not compliant */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
12 D
Referenced parameter has possible clear path.

This is similar to standard 9 D but in this case an input value is not used on all paths. Generally it is not dangerous.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 12 D : Referenced parameter has possible clear path.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_012( UINT_32 par_1, UINT_32 par_2 )
{
   UINT_32 var_1;
 
   var_1 = par_2;
 
   if (par_2 != 1)
   {
      var_1 = par_1;
   }
   /* par_1 not used in function is par_2 == 1 */ 
   return (var_1);
 
}  /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard
13 D
Global used in procedure matches local parameter.

This standard checks that whether a global object is accessed in a function that is called with an object which is a function parameter with the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
INT_32 globl = 1;
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 13 D : Global used in procedure matches local parameter.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void fn_13( INT_32 * pVar )
{
   *pVar = *pVar + globl;  /* global accessed in procedure */
}
 
void SDA_013( INT_32 * globl )
{
  fn_13( globl );  /* not compliant - function call with globl which is a function parameter */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard
14 D
Attempt to change parameter passed by value.

C will allow you to assign to call by value parameters which could be an error.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 14 D : Attempt to change parameter passed by value.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_014( UINT_32 par_1, UINT_32 par_2 )
{
   if (par_2 != 1U)
   {
      par_1 = 0U;  /* assignment to call by value parameter */
   }
   else
   {
      par_1= 1U;
   }
 
} /* not compliant */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 152  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.17.8  
SEC-C : X1.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard
15 D
Unused procedural parameter.

Ensure that any procedural parameters left unused have not been done so in error. If a parameter is not required, for readability and easier understanding of the code it should be removed.

This standard covers just procedural parameters, other unused parameters to procedures are covered by 1 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************
 * Standard 15 D : Unused procedural parameter.
 ************************************************/
 
void SDA_015(void (*p_proc_pointer)(void) )
{
   /* ... */ 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.8  
CERT-C : MSC13-C  
CMSE : 1.2.10  
CWE : 398, 747  
GJB : 5.2.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-11, 0-1-12  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.7  
SEC-C : M1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
16 D
Identical actual parameters in call.

If a procedure is called with two identical actual parameters then there is an equivalence between the corresponding formal parameters but the actual form of this equivalence is compiler dependent.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
static void Test_016( UINT_32 *par_1, UINT_32 *par_2 )
{
   if (par_1 == par_2)
   {
      /* ... */ 
   }
}
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 16 D : Identical actual parameters in call.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_016(void)
{
   UINT_32 var = 6;
 
   Test_016( &var , &var );  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 153  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
17 D
Identifier not unique within *** characters.

The maximum sequence for distinction between identifiers is compiler and linker dependent. The user can specify the maximum sequence in the cpen.dat file and this standard will warn if there are any which are identical up to this limit. The *** symbols refer to a user definable number for this standard. The configuration is made in the c/cpppen.dat file.

This standard compares function, variable, component and label identifiers. The checks are extended in 61 X to include other forms of identifiers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 17 D : Identifier not unique within *** characters.
 * Does not compile under VC++ without /H
 **************************************************************/ 
 
static UINT_32 SDA_017(void)
{
   UINT_32 This_identifier_exceeds_thirty_one_characters_in_length;
   UINT_32 This_identifier_exceeds_thirty_one_characters_in_length_also; /* not compliant */
 
   /* ... */ 
   This_identifier_exceeds_thirty_one_characters_in_length       = 1;
   This_identifier_exceeds_thirty_one_characters_in_length_also  = 2;
 
   return (This_identifier_exceeds_thirty_one_characters_in_length);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL32-C  
CWE : 758  
DERA : 11  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
HIS : 11  
JSF++ AV : 46  
LMTCP : 69  
MISRA-AC : 1.4, 5.1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 11  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.4, 5.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.1, R.5.2, R.5.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , UML , VSOS
18 D
Identifier name reused.

This standard also reports when names are duplicated across file boundaries.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 Re_Used;
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 18 D : Identifier name reused.
 * Does not compile with VC++
 ************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_018( void )
{
   UINT_32 Re_Used; /* not compliant */
 
   Re_Used = 1;
   return Re_Used;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 12, 21  
FSB582-C : 3.5.5  
HIS : 21  
MISRA-AC : 5.2, 5.5  
MISRA-C:1998 : 12, 21  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.2, 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.3  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
19 D
Procedure called before being defined.

Some compilers use default values if a use is found before a declaration or definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 19 D : Procedure called before being defined.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_16 SDA_019(void)
{
   UINT_16 retval;
   retval = Test_19d();  /* not compliant */
   return (retval);
}
 
UINT_32 Test_19d( void )
{
   /* ... */ 
   return (1u);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 20, 71  
HIS : 20, 71  
MISRA-C:1998 : 20, 71  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
20 D
No declaration for variable found before use.

Some compilers will assume a default type if a variable is used before a declaration is found.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 20 D : No declaration for variable found before use.
 * Does not compile with VC++
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
static UINT_32 SDA_020(void)
{
   UINT_32 retval;
 
   retval = undeclared;  /* not compliant */
 
   return (retval);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 398  
DERA : 20  
HIS : 20  
LMTCP : 16  
MISRA-C:1998 : 20  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
22 D
Function has global variable side effects.

A function has global side effects if it can return a value through its global variables as well as by means of its parameters (possibly) and its return type. The safest form is one which only returns a value through the return type.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 global = 0U;
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 22 D : Function has global variable side effects.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_022(void)
{
   global++;
