   return global;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
LMTCP : 286  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.2  
23 D
Function has parameter side effects.

A function has parameter side effects if it can return a value through its parameters as well as by means of its globals (possibly) and its return type. The safest form is one which only returns a value through the return type.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 23 D : Function has parameter side effects.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_023( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
   *par_1 = 1;
   return (*par_1);
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
24 D
Procedure definition has no associated prototype.

In general providing prototypes is considered to be good practice and is essential if the uses precede the definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 24 D : Procedure definition has no associated prototype.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_024( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
   *par_1 =  1;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL31-C  
DERA : 71  
EADS-C : 107, 118  
HIS : 71  
LMTCP : 230  
MISRA-AC : 8.1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 71  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.1  
NETRINO : 6.2.d  
SEC-C : M4.4.3, R2.8.3  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
25 D
Scope of variable could be reduced.

Variables should always be declared in the smallest scope consistent with their use. This standard reports the names of variables which could be moved to an inner scope. It does not take account of possible uses of a global variable in other files in a system.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 g_var_1 = 1; /* not compliant */
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 25 D : Scope of variable could be reduced
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_025( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
   *par_1 =  g_var_1;
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 22  
HIC++ : 8.4.4  
HIS : 22  
JPL : 6  
LMTCP : 249  
MISRA-AC : 8.7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-4-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 22  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.9  
NETRINO : 7.2.b  
SEC-C : M2.2.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
26 D
Variable should be defined once in only one file.

This standard reports variables that have more than one definition, either within a file, or across a set of files. Note for that C++, const variable declarations are excluded from this check.

Note: The violation message appears at the start of the file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h" 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 26 D : Variable should be defined once in only one file.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_026;
SINT_32 SDA_026;
 
 
void SDA_026(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 25  
HIS : 25  
JSF++ AV : 139  
LMTCP : 253  
MISRA-AC : 8.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-2, 3-2-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 25  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.6  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
27 D
Variable should be declared static.

A variable that is of file scope and not used in another file should be declared with the static qualifier.

This standard is only enabled when the code is run as a system set.

Example

Sda_027_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 27 D : Variable should be declared static.
 *****************************************************/
 
INT_32 global_1 = 1;     /* not compliant */
INT_32 global_2 = 2;     /* compliant as used in other file */
 
static INT_32 SDA_027( void )
{
  return global_2 - global_1;
}
 
INT_32 main( void )
{
  return  SDA_027() + SDA_027_2();
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Sda_027_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
INT_32 global_2;
 
INT_32 SDA_027_2 ( void )
{
	return global_2;
}
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL15-C  
CWE : 736  
DERA : 23  
EADS-C : 97  
FSB582-C : 3.5.4  
HIS : 23  
LMTCP : 250, 251  
MISRA-AC : 8.10, 8.11  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-3-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 23  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.10, 8.11  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.7, R.8.8  
NETRINO : 1.8.a  
SEC-C : M2.2.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Standard , VSOS
28 D
Potentially infinite loop found.

The value required to exit a looping sequence is not assigned in every path through the sequence.

Further infinite loop detection is performed in by 26 S and 5 C.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 28 D : Potentially Infinite loop found.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_028( void )
{
   INT_32 i = 1;
   BOOL flag = TRUE;
 
   while (flag) /* not compliant */
   {
      if (i==0)
      {
          flag = FALSE;
      }
   }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 835  
DERA : 142  
EADS-C : 133  
JPL : 2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.1  
SEC-C : M1.9.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , TBrun Requires , VSOS
29 D
Partially used structure parameter.

A structure has been used as a parameter to a procedure call, but some parts of it have not been used.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct s29
{
   UINT_32 u1;
   UINT_32 u2;
   UINT_32 u3;
};
 
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 29 D : Partially used structure parameter.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
static UINT_32 SDA_029( struct s29 s )
{
   UINT_32 result;
   result = s.u1 + s.u2;
   return (result);
 
} /* not compliant  - u3 member of s has not been used */
 
static UINT_32 Test_029( void )
{
   UINT_32 a;
   struct s29 s;
 
   s.u1=1U;
   s.u2=2U;
   s.u3=3U;
 
   a = SDA_029( s );
   return (a);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
VSOS
33 D
No real declaration for external variable.

A variable has been declared 'external' in each of the program components. There is no real declaration.

This standard is only enabled when the code is run as a system set with at least 2 files.

Example

Sda_033_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
extern UINT_32 global = 1;   /* not compliant */
 
extern UINT_32 sda_033_2( void );
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 33 D : No real declaration for external variable.
 ************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 sda_033_1( void )
{
  return sda_033_2( );
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Sda_033_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
extern UINT_32 global;
 
UINT_32 sda_033_2(void)
{
  global++;
  return global;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 25  
HIS : 25  
MISRA-AC : 8.9  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-4  
MISRA-C:1998 : 25  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.9  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.6  
SEC-C : M4.4.3, M4.4.4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , Standard , VSOS
34 D
Procedure name re-used in different files.

Two C files can contain procedures with the same name, leading to confusion and errors.

This standard is only enabled when the code is run as a system set with a least two files.

Example

Sda_034_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 34 D : Procedure name re-used in different files
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_034( UINT_32 a1 )
{
  UINT_32 b = a1;
  b--;
  return b;
}
 
static UINT_32 test_034(void)
{
  UINT_32 a = 1U;
  a = SDA_034( a );
  return a;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 * 
 */

Sda_034_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 34 D : Procedure name re-used in different files.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32 SDA_034( SINT_32 a1 ) /* not compliant */
{
  SINT_32 b = a1;
  b--;
  return b;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 25  
HIS : 25  
MISRA-AC : 8.9  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 25  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.9  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.6  
SEC-C : M4.4.3, M4.4.4  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
35 D
Expression has side effects.

This can occur with operators such as ++ used in expressions. For example: x = A[j] + j++; is potentially ambiguous depending on the order of evaluation of the right hand side.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************
 * Standard 35 D : Expression has side effects.
 ************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_035( UINT_32 par_1 )
{
   UINT_32 result;
   UINT_32 var_1 = par_1;
 
   result = var_1++ + var_1;  /* not compliant */
   return (result);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP02-C, EXP10-C, EXP30-C, FIO41-C  
CWE : 737, 758, 768  
DERA : 46  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17, 9.21  
HIC++ : 10.3  
HIS : 46  
JSF++ AV : 157, 204  
LMTCP : 286, 362  
MISRA-AC : 12.2, 12.4, 12.13  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 46  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2, 12.4, 12.13  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.1, R.13.2, R.13.5  
SEC-C : M1.8.1, R3.6.1, R3.6.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
36 D
Prototype and definition name mismatch.

This penalty is flagged if the names of parameters mentioned in a procedure prototype definition do not match the names in the real definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
UINT_32 SDA_036( UINT_32 var_1 );
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 36 D : Prototype and definition name mismatch.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_036( UINT_32 par_1 ) /* not compliant */
{
   UINT_32 result;
   UINT_32 var_1=par_1;
   result = var_1;
   return (result);
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 74  
FSB582-C : 3.7.4  
HIC++ : 11.3  
HIS : 74  
LMTCP : 233  
MISRA-AC : 16.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-4-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 74  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.3, R.8.4  
SEC-C : M4.5.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
37 D
Function has persistent local side effects.

A non-void function has persistent local side effects if it can return a value through its persistent local variables as well as by means of its parameters (possibly) and its return type. The safest form is one which only returns a value through the return type.

Functions with a void return type are covered by standard 68 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 37 D : Function has persistent local side effects.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 SDA_037(void)
{
   static UINT_32 var_1;  /* persistent local variable */
 
   var_1++;
 
   return (var_1);
} /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.13  
38 D
More than one control variable for loop.

Loop iteration shall be controlled by a single variable only. More than one control variable should never be required and only serves to confuse and increase the potential for undesired behaviour, such as an infinite loop.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 38 D : More than one control variable for loop
 **********************************************************/
 
void SDA_038( UCHAR *pArray, UINT_32 ArraySize)
{
  UCHAR   element;
  UINT_32 stepup=0U, stepdn;
 
  stepdn = ArraySize;
  stepdn--;
 
  while( stepdn > stepup ) /* not compliant */
  {
    element = pArray[ stepdn ];
    pArray[ stepdn ] = pArray[ stepup ];
    pArray[ stepup ] = element;
 
    stepup++;
    stepdn--;
  }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 140  
EADS-C : 165  
FSB582-C++ : 9.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-5-1  
Related standards filter models
VSOS
39 D
More than one entry to a loop.

Ensure that a loop has a single entry point, in order to simplify the control graph for the statement and reduce overall complexity.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 39 D : More than one entry to a loop.
 *************************************************/
 
void SDA_039( void )
{
  UINT_32 it;
  for (it = 0; it < 42U; it++) /* not compliant */
  {
lb1:
    it++;
lb2:
    it++;
    if (it == 7U)
    {
      goto lb1;      /*** re-entry ***/
    }
    else
    {
      if (it == 9U)
      {
        goto lb2;    /*** re-entry ***/
      }
	else
      {
        /* do something */
      }
    }
 
  }
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 5.9  
LMTCP : 356  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
40 D
More than one exit from a loop.

Ensure that a loop has a single exit point, in order to simplify the control graph for the statement and reduce overall complexity.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************
 * Standard 40 D : More than one exit from a loop
 *************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_040( void )
{
  UINT_32 it;
  for (it = 0U; it < 42U; it++) /* not compliant */
  {
    /* ... */ 
 
    if (it == 9U)
    {
      break;    /*** provides an additional exit from loop ***/ 
    }
    else
    {
      /* do something */ 
    }
  }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C : 128  
HIC++ : 5.9  
LMTCP : 356  
41 D
Procedure call has no prototype declared.

Procedures shall always have a prototype visible at the point at which they are called. It is good practice to always declare a prototype and essential where a call is not preceded by a definition of the procedure, as the compiler may make assumptions about the types.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
void SDA_041( UINT_32 param );
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 41 D : Procedure call has no prototype declared.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_041( UINT_32 param )
{
  UINT_32 result = foo( param );  /* not compliant */
 
  /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL31-C, EXP37-C  
CWE : 628  
DERA : 71  
EADS-C : 118  
HIS : 71  
MISRA-C:1998 : 71  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
42 D
Local pointer returned in function result.

A function shall not return a pointer to a non-static local object. Following return of control to the calling function the local object will have gone out of scope and no longer exist.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 42 D : Local pointer returned in function result
 *************************************************************/ 
 
static INT_32 * fn_D42( void )
{
  INT_32 local_var = 22;
 
  return &local_var;  /* Not Compliant */
}
 
 
void SDA_042( void )
{
  INT_32 * result = fn_D42();
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.5  
CERT-C : DCL30-C  
CWE : 562, 758, 825  
DERA : 106  
FSB582-C++ : 4.11  
HIC++ : 11.7  
HIS : 106  
JSF++ AV : 111, 112  
LMTCP : 206  
MISRA-AC : 17.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-5-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 106  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.6  
SEC-C : X3.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , UML , VSOS
43 D
Divide by 0 found.

Measures shall be taken to prevent run-time failures caused by divide by zero operations. Either a conditional test or an assertion should be used on the right hand operand being non-zero.

Note: The message is output against the first use of a zero-valued variable in a divide operation. There may also be other uses within the code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************
 * Standard 43 D : Divide by 0 found.
 *************************************/ 
 
void SDA_043( SINT_32 p_denominator )
{
   SINT_32 local_denominator = 0;
   SINT_32 numerator = 9;
 
   SINT_32 result = numerator / local_denominator;  /* not compliant */ 
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FLP03-C, INT33-C  
CWE : 129, 190, 369, 680, 758  
EADS-C : 103  
HIC++ : 10.17  
LMTCP : 311  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-3-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.1  
SEC-C : R3.2.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
45 D
Pointer not checked for null before use.

A pointer shall not be used without a prior check for NULL status. De-referencing a NULL pointer constitutes undefined behaviour.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 45 D : Pointer not checked for null before use.
 **********************************************************/
 
void SDA_045( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
  UINT_32 * lvar_1 = (UINT_32 *)malloc(sizeof(*lvar_1));
 
  *lvar_1 = *par_1;  /* not compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP08-C, EXP34-C, MEM32-C  
CMSE : 4.1.4  
CWE : 476, 690, 758  
EADS-C : 122  
GJB : 5.1.15  
HIS : 107  
JSF++ AV : 174  
LMTCP : 317  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 107  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.1  
SEC-C : R3.2.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME , TBrun Requires , UML
46 D
Member function may be declared const.

Member functions should be declared const by default and only non-const if there is a clear explicit reason for doing so. Declaring a member function const ensures that objects are not modified incorrectly.

This standard works by detecting modification to member variables, including via calls to other functions. If called member functions are not visible to the analysis (for example, they may be in a base class implementation), it is assumed that they do not modify member variables. The standard may therefore be flagged in situations where making the member function const will cause a compilation error because a non-const member function is called. In these situations the user should determine whether the called function can also be made const. If not, the standard violation may be ignored.

A function with no static or const qualifier may flag both a 46 D and a 79 D violation. In this case the function should be declared static, as adding both qualifiers is illegal.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 46 D : Member function may be declared const.
 *********************************************************/
 
class Person
{
  public:
    Person();
    explicit Person(const UINT_32 personNum);
    Person & operator=(const Person &person );
    explicit Person(const Person &person );
    ~Person();
    UINT_32 get_p_num(void);
 
  protected:
  private:
    UINT_32 personalNumber;
};
 
 
UINT_32 Person::get_p_num(void) /* not compliant */
{
  return personalNumber;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
EADS-C++ : 6  
FSB582-C++ : 6.3  
HIC++ : 3.1.8  
JSF++ AV : 69  
LMTCP : 103  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 9-3-3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

47 D
Unused inspect annotation.

A spurious inspect annotation for a particular standard is present in the code. The line should be removed to avoid confusion and aid readability.

Further checks on the INSPECTED annotation are performed by 305 S and 2 J.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/*********************************************
 * Standard 47 D : Unused inspect annotation.
 *********************************************/ 
 
/*LDRA_INSPECTED 46 D*/        /* not compliant */
                               /* Standard 45 D is violated below, not 46 D*/
 
void SDA_047( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
  UINT_32 * lvar_1 = (UINT_32*)malloc(sizeof(lvar_1));
 
  *lvar_1 = *par_1;   /* 45 D violation */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
48 D
Attempt to write to unopened file.

Any attempt to write to a file must be preceded by a successful open of that file. The return value from the open function should be checked for non-NULL. Invalid access to files will likely result in program termination.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
 
void SDA_048( void );
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 48 D : Attempt to write to unopened file.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_048( void )
{
  FILE *inp,
       *outp;
  SINT_32 ch;
 
  inp = fopen("infile.txt", "r");
 
  do
    {
      ch = getc(inp);
      if (ch == (SINT_32)EOF)
      {
        /* do nothing */
      }
      else
      {
        putc( ch, outp );  /* not compliant - code to open output file omitted */
        ch = getc(inp);
      }
    } while (ch != (SINT_32)EOF );
 
  fclose(inp);
  fclose(outp);
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 399, 910  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.6  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
49 D
File pointer not closed on exit.

A file pointer shall be disassociated from the file once access to the file is no longer required. Failure to close a file may result in subsequent access being invalid, and is likely to cause memory leaks.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 49 D : File pointer not closed on exit.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_049( void )
{
  FILE *inp,
       *outp;
  SINT_32 ch;
 
  inp = fopen("infile.txt", "r");
  outp = fopen("outfile.txt", "w");
 
  do
    {
      ch = getc(inp);
      if (ch == (SINT_32)EOF)
      {
        /* do nothing */ 
      }
      else
      {
        putc( ch, outp );
        ch = getc(inp);
      }
    } while (ch != (SINT_32)EOF );
 
  fclose(inp); 
}  /* not compliant -  code to close output file omitted */ 
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO42-C  
CWE : 403, 404, 772, 775  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
50 D
Memory not freed after last reference.

Dynamically allocated memory shall be freed before the last pointer variable that references it is reset to NULL or assigned a new memory address. A memory leak occurs when a block of allocated memory is no longer accessible and unnecessarily consumes system resources.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 50 D : Memory not freed after last reference.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_050( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
  UINT_32 * lvar_1 = (UINT_32 *)malloc(sizeof(lvar_1));
 
  if (lvar_1 != (UINT_32 *)0)
  {
    *lvar_1 = *par_1;
  }
 
  lvar_1 = par_1;  /* memory not freed before pointer assigned a new address */ 
} /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM00-C  
CMSE : 6.1.25  
CWE : 401, 762  
EADS-C : 127  
GJB : 5.1.17  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
51 D
Attempt to read from freed memory.

Dynamically allocated memory that has been freed is no longer accessible even if it has pointers which reference it. A block of memory shall not be freed whilst two or more pointer variables reference it.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/****************************************************
 * Standard 51 D : Attempt to read from freed memory.
 ****************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_051( UINT_32 * par_1 )
{
  UINT_32 * lvar_1 = (UINT_32 *)malloc(sizeof(lvar_1));
  UINT_32 * lvar_2;
 
  if (lvar_1 != (UINT_32 *)0)
  {
    *lvar_1 = *par_1;
 
    /* ... */ 
 
    free(lvar_1);
 
    *lvar_2 = *lvar_1; /* not compliant */
  }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM30-C  
CMSE : 6.1.24  
CWE : 416, 758  
EADS-C : 126  
GJB : 5.1.16  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
52 D
Member(s) not assigned in = operator.

A copy assignment operator shall assign all data members, including those in base classes, which affect the class invariant.

This standard can be further restricted to perform a deeper, more accurate analysis by setting the modifier 262 to 1 in the cppreport.dat file. Instructions for making alterations can be found in the report.dat file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 52 D : Member(s) not assigned in = operator.
 *******************************************************/
 
class base
{
  public:
    base();
    ~base();
    explicit base(const base &base);
    explicit base(const INT_32 x1) : base_member (x1)
    {
    }
 
    base& operator=(const base& rhs)
    {
      if (this != &rhs)
      {
        base_member = rhs.base_member;
      }
      return *this;
    }
 
  private:
    INT_32  base_member;
};
 
 
class derived : public base
{
  public:
    derived();
    ~derived();
    explicit derived(const derived &der1);
    derived (const INT_32  x1, const INT_32  y1) :
               base (x1),
               derived_member_1 (y1)
    {
       derived_member_2 = 1;
    }
 
    derived& operator=(const derived&  rhs)
    {
      if (this != &rhs)
      {
	// all members are not copied
        derived_member_1 = rhs.derived_member_1 + derived_member_2;
      }
      return *this;
    }  /* not compliant */
 
    private:
      INT_32  derived_member_1;
      INT_32  derived_member_2;
 };
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 8.4   Modifiers : 262 = 1
HIC++ : 3.1.5  
JSF++ AV : 83   Modifiers : 262 = 1
LMTCP : 128  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , UML
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

53 D
Attempt to use uninitialised pointer.

Before a pointer may be used, such that the contents of the memory address pointed to are accessed, it shall already be initialised.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 53 D : Attempt to use uninitialised pointer
 ********************************************************/
 
static void SDA_053( void)
{
   CHAR *ptr1, *ptr2;
   ptr1 = ptr2;   /* Not compliant  */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP08-C, EXP33-C  
CWE : 457, 468, 758  
JSF++ AV : 83  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.9.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
54 D
Unsafe use of function pointer variable.

Constructs that involve the unsafe use of a function pointer variable, for a purpose other than as a handle to a function, shall not be permitted. For instance, a function pointer should not be used as an actual parameter for the function to which it points to.

Example
typedef struct struct_fn_t
{
  void (* s_fn)(struct struct_fn_t * s_fn_ptr);
} struct_fn;
 
/***********************************************************
 * Standard 54 D : Unsafe use of function pointer variable.
 ***********************************************************/ 
 
void sda_054 ( void )
{
   struct_fn s_fn_ptrs[10];
   struct_fn * sda_054_p = &s_fn_ptrs[0];
 
   /* ----- */ 
 
   sda_054_p->s_fn (sda_054_p++);      /* Not compliant */ 
 
   /* ----- */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP08-C  
CWE : 457, 468  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
55 D
Modification of loop counter in loop body.

A loop counter used within a for loop for iteration shall not be modified in the body of the loop. Modification of the loop counter makes code difficult to read and maintain.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 55 D : Modification of loop counter in loop body.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_055( UINT_32 max_count )
{
  UINT_32 loop_counter = 0U;
 
  for (loop_counter = 0U; loop_counter < max_count; loop_counter++)
  {
    if (loop_counter == 7U)
    {
      loop_counter++;   /* not compliant */
    }
    else
    {
      /* do nothing  */
    }
  }
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 67  
EADS-C : 130  
FSB582-C++ : 9.3  
HIC++ : 5.5, 5.6  
HIS : 67  
JSF++ AV : 201  
LMTCP : 354  
MISRA-AC : 13.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-5-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 67  
MISRA-C:2004 : 13.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.14.2  
SEC-C : M3.3.2  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , RUNTIME , Standard , UML
56 D
Throw found with no catch in scope.

All exceptions signalled by a throw-expression shall be handled by an appropriate catch-block for the type of object passed from the throw-point. Failure to handle an exception reduces fault-tolerance, and may result in program termination.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/*****************************************************
 * Standard 56 D : Throw found with no catch in scope.
 *****************************************************/
 
void test(UINT_32 val)
{
  if (val < 5U )
  {
    throw val;
  }
  else
  {
    printf("Value not thrown - %d\n", val);
  }
}
 
void SDA_056(void)
{
  test(10U); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 460  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 15-3-4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

57 D
Global not initialised at declaration.

All variables shall be initialised before use. Global variables, in particular, should be initialised at declaration to ensure there can be no access prior to an assignment.

This standard does not apply to variables that are initialised by constructors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const SINT_32 g_var; /* not compliant */
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 57 D : Global not initialised at declaration.
 **********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_057( SINT_32 p_var )
{
   SINT_32 result1 = g_var * p_var;
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.8  
CMSE : 1.2.10  
CWE : 456  
GJB : 5.2.1  
HIC++ : 8.4.3  
JSF++ AV : 142  
NETRINO : 7.2.a  
58 D
Character or string literal re-used.

Use of symbolic names is preferred to literal values in the code. However, character and string literals are permitted as an exception, provided they appear only once.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 58 D : Character or string literal re-used.
 *******************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_058( void )
{
  CHAR str1[] = {'a', 'b', 'c'};
 
  CHAR str2[] = {'d', 'a', 'f'};  /* not compliant - 'a' already present in str1 */ 
 
  CHAR str3[] = {'x', 'y', 'b'};  /* not compliant - 'b' already present in str1 */ 
 
  CHAR * some_string = "Hello World";
 
  CHAR * another_string = "Hello World";  /* not compliant - "Hello World" already assigned to some_string */ 
 
   /* ... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 10.1  
59 D
Parameter should be declared const.

Any non-pointer parameter, whose value is not intended to change, should be protected by the use of const. Making use of the parameter explicit leads to greater precision in the definition of the function interface. Pointer parameters are covered by standard 603 S.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************
 * Standard 59 D : Parameter should be declared const.
 ******************************************************/ 
 
UCHAR glob;
 
static void sda_059( UCHAR par1, /* Not compliant  */
                     UCHAR par2  /* Compliant      */
                    )   
{
    par2 = glob;
    glob = par1;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-1-1  
NETRINO : 1.8.b  
60 D
External object should be declared only once.

An external object shall only be declared once. The preferred approach is to place an extern declaration in a single header file to be shared by those files that provide a definition of, or wish to use, the object.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
extern SINT_32 some_int; /* initial ext. declaration */ 
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 60 D : External object should be declared only once.
 ***************************************************************/ 
 
extern SINT_32 some_int; /* not compliant - multiple ext. declaration */ 
 
SINT_32 some_int = 0;    /* definition */ 
 
void sda_060( void )
{ ; }
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
DERA : 27  
HIS : 27  
MISRA-AC : 8.8  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-3  
MISRA-C:1998 : 27  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.5  
SEC-C : M4.4.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
61 D
Procedure should be declared static.

Procedures shall have internal linkage unless external linkage is required. That is, the static storage-class specifier must be applied to procedures that are only called from within the same file. The visibility of a procedure is therefore limited to the required minimum, thereby reducing the possibility for confusion with another identifier with the same name.

This standard does not apply to member functions, which are covered by standard 79 D.

This standard is only enabled when the code is run as a system set with at least 2 files.

Example

Sda_061_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 61 D : Procedure should be declared static.
 ********************************************************/
 
static void helper_proc1( void ) { ; } /* compliant */
 
 
void helper_proc2( void) { ; }    /* not compliant  - should be static as
                                   * procedure is not called anywhere
                                   * in system outside of this file.
                                   */
 
void sda_061( void )
{
  helper_proc1();
  helper_proc2();
 
}
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Sda_061_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
int main(void)
{
  sda_061();
 
  return 0;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL15-C  
CWE : 736  
FSB582-C : 3.6.3  
MISRA-AC : 8.10, 8.11  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-3-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.10, 8.11  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.7, R.8.8  
NETRINO : 1.8.a, 6.2.e  
SEC-C : M2.2.3  
62 D
Pointer parameter should be declared const.

The const qualifier should be applied to pointer parameters that address data not subject to change. Const-ness of data should be made explicit in all applicable cases to indicate where protection is required.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 62 D : Pointer parameter should be declared const.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
void sda_062( UINT_32 * pptr1,
              const UINT_32 * pptr2,
              UINT_32 * pptr3 )      /* not compliant - should be const */
{
   *pptr1 = *pptr2 + *pptr3;         /* data at address pptr3 not changed */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL13-C  
CWE : 736  
FSB582-C : 3.6.6  
HIC++ : 11.5  
HIS : 81  
MISRA-AC : 16.7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-1-2  
MISRA-C:1998 : 81  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.7  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.13  
NETRINO : 1.8.b  
SEC-C : M1.11.1, M1.11.3  
63 D
No definition in system for prototyped procedure.

Procedures with external linkage shall have a definition provided in at least one of the translation units in the system.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 63 D : No definition in system for prototyped procedure.
 ******************************************************************/
 
void sda_063_1( void );
void sda_063_2( void );  /* Not compliant */
 
void sda_063_1( void )
{
  /***/
}
 
int main(void)
{
  sda_063_1();
  sda_063_2();
  return 0;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 758  
GJB : 5.21  
MISRA-AC : 8.9  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.9  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.6  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
64 D
Local not initialised at declaration.

Local variables shall be initialised at declaration. To adopt a strategy of initialising before the first access, but after declaration, invites the highly likely case that an access will be added prior to the initialisation. Access of a variable which has not been explicitly initialised may lead to unexpected results or even a failure.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 64 D : Local not initialised at declaration.
 *******************************************************************/
 
static UINT_32 sda_064_1( void )
{
  UINT_32 local_int; /* not compliant */
 
  local_int = 0U;
 
  local_int++;
 
  return local_int;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 8.4.3  
NETRINO : 7.2.a  
65 D
Void function has no side effects.

A function with void return type shall have external side effects. Failure to contribute to the generation of any outputs may not be what the developer intended or expects.

This standard does not apply to constructors or destructors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 65 D : void function has no side effects.
 *******************************************************************/
 
static void sda_065_1( void )
{
  UINT_32 local_int = 1U;
 
  local_int++;
 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC12-C  
CWE : 747  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.2  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
66 D
Non boolean control variable modified in loop.

Loop control variables other than the loop counter shall be Boolean in order to make the code easier to understand.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*
 * Standard 66 D : Non boolean control variable modified in loop.
 * A/Ref:
 */ 
 
extern UINT_16 sda_066_2( void );
void sda_066_1( void );
 
 
 
void sda_066_1( void )
{
  SINT_32 loop;
  UINT_16 u8a = 0U;
  BOOL flag = FALSE;
 
  for( loop = 0; (loop < 10 ) && ( u8a != 42U ); ++loop )  /* Not ok */ 
  {
    u8a = sda_066_2();
  }
 
  for( loop = 0; (loop < 10 ) && flag; ++loop )            /* Ok */ 
  {
    u8a = sda_066_2();
    flag = u8a != 42U;
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 9.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-5-6  
67 D
Void function has global variable side effects.

Procedures that have global variable side effects shall be avoided as their invocation may result in unexpected results when the order of evaluation in the calling expression is significant. This standard includes constructors and destructors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/******************************************************************
 * Standard 67 D : Void function has global variable side effects.
 ******************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 global = 0U;
 
void sda_067_1( UINT_32 p1,
                UINT_32 p2 )
{
  global = (global + p1) * p2;
} /* not compliant */
 
 
void SDA_067( UINT_32 p3 )
{
  sda_067_1( p3++, p3++ );  /* 'global' will be evaluated differently
                                depending on which parameter is evaluated first */ 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
LMTCP : 286  
68 D
Void function has persistent local side effects.

Functions with a void return type that have persistent local side effects shall be avoided as their invocation may result in unexpected results when the order of evaluation in the calling expression is significant.

Functions that have a non-void return type are covered by standard 37 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************************
 * Standard 68 D : Void function has persistent local side effects.
 *****************************************************************/
 
void SDA_068_1( UINT_32 p1, UINT_32 p2 )
{
  static UINT_32 var_1;
 
  var_1 = (var_1 + p1) * p2;    /* 'var_1' will be evaluated differently
                                depending on which parameter is evaluated first */ 
} /* not compliant */
 
 
void SDA_068_2( UINT_32 p3 )
{
  SDA_068_1( p3++, p3++ );
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
69 D
UR anomaly, variable used before assignment.

A particular variable is used before it is given a value. This result is generated regardless of whether a compiler claims to initialise all or some of the variables.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 69 D : UR anomaly, variable used before assignment.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
void sda_069 ( void )
{
  UINT_32 var_1;  /* not compliant */
 
  var_1++;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.13.4  
CERT-C : EXP33-C  
CMSE : 13.1.4  
CWE : 457, 665, 758, 824, 908  
DERA : 30  
EADS-C++ : 31  
GJB : 4.13.1.4  
HIC++ : 8.4.3  
HIS : 30  
JPL : 7  
JSF++ AV : 142  
LMTCP : 257  
MISRA-AC : 9.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 8-5-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 30  
MISRA-C:2004 : 9.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.9.1  
SEC-C : R1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , RUNTIME , Standard , UML , VSOS
70 D
DU anomaly, variable value is not used.

DU anomalies are unnecessary and can always be removed with a consequent improvement in the readability and efficiency of the code.

A DU anomaly will occur if a variable is assigned a value that is not used down all branches of a program. In the example below, var_2 is not used in the else branch of the if statement. A violation will occur even if the control flow structure means that only one branch is reached.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/*
 * Standard 70 D : DU anomaly, variable value is not used.
 */ 
 
static void sda_070 ( const UINT_32 p1 )
{
  UINT_32 var_1 = 0U;
  UINT_32 var_2 = p1;  /* not compliant - var_2 not used in one branch */
 
  var_1++;  /* not compliant - var_1 is not used after incrementation */
 
  if ( p1 > 42U )
  {
     printf("%u\n", var_2);
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2008 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
JPL : 7  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-6, 0-1-9  
SEC-C : M1.1.1, X1.x  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
71 D
No matching catch for throw in called function.

All exceptions shall be handled in all paths to that exception with a handler of a compatible type. Termination of an unhandled exception is implementation-defined.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*****************************************************************
 * Standard 71 D : No matching catch for throw in called function.
 *****************************************************************/
 
static void sda_071_1( const UINT_32 p1 )
{
    if ( p1 > 1U )
    {
      throw 10U;
    }
}
 
static void sda_071( void  )
{
  try
  {
    sda_071_1(15U);  /* Throws an unsigned int */
  }
  catch ( char c )   /* but catches a char */
  {
  }
} /* not compliant */
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 460  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 15-3-4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

72 D
Potential side effect problem in expression.

The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation. Function calls can prevent this reliance if they have additional effects, such as modifying global data or a passed parameter. The order in which side effects take place is unspecified and may lead to unexpected results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 72 D : Potential side effect problem in expression.
 *******************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 arr[] = {1U, 2U, 3U};
 
static UINT_32 sda_072_2( UINT_32 * p2 )
{
  (*p2)++;
  return 1U;
}
 
 
static void sda_072_1( UINT_32 idx )
{
  UINT_32 p1;
  p1 = arr[idx] + sda_072_2( &idx ); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP10-C  
CWE : 758  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
MISRA-AC : 12.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.2  
SEC-C : R3.6.1, R3.6.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
73 D
Predicate variable modified in condition.

The loop counter shall only be modified in the expression part of the statement, to attain greater maintainability.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
static void SDA_073( void);
 
/*
 * Standard 73 D : Predicate variable modified in condition.
 */ 
 
SINT_32 ss = 0;
SINT_32 st = 0;
static void SDA_073( void)
{
  while( st > ss  && (ss = 1) < 10 ){} /* Not compliant  */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C++:2008 : 6-5-3  
74 D
Potential side effect from repeated function call.

The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation. Repeated function calls can prevent this reliance if they have additional effects, such as modifying global data or a passed parameter. The order in which side effects take place is unspecified and may lead to unexpected results.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************************
 * Standard 74 D : Potential side effect from repeated function call.
 ********************************************************************/
 
SINT_32 f ( SINT_32 * pp )
{
    *pp = 77;
    return 6;
}
 
SINT_32 x;
SINT_32 y;
 
static void SDA_074 ( void)
{
   x = f(&y) + f(&y);   /* Not compliant  */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : EXP10-C  
CWE : 758  
FSB582-C : 3.10.1, 3.10.2  
FSB582-C++ : 9.17  
MISRA-AC : 12.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 5-0-1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 12.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.13.2  
SEC-C : R3.6.2  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
75 D
Attempt to open file pointer more than once.

A file that is already open shall not be opened again. The practice of multiple simultaneous file opens is implementation-defined behaviour and may lead to race conditions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 75 D : Attempt to open file pointer more than once.
 *******************************************************************/
 
static void SDA_075( void)
{
   UINT_32 xx;
 
   FILE * fptr = fopen("mikes.h","rw");
   fscanf(fptr,"%d",&xx );
 
   if( xx == 0 )
   {
     fptr = fopen("mikes.h","rw"); /* Not compliant  */ 
   }
   else
   {
   }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO31-C  
CWE : 362, 675, 775  
FSB582-C++ : 9.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
76 D
Procedure is not called or referenced in code analysed.

All defined procedures shall be called or referenced within the code. Uncalled procedures indicate a possible defect in the code.

This standard differs from 23 S and 35 S in that it will not give a warning if a procedure is referenced by its address.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************************
 * Standard 76 D : Procedure is not called or referenced in code analysed.
 *************************************************************************/ 
 
static void SDA_076 ( void) /* not complaint */
{
  ;
}
 
SINT_32 main(void)
{
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.18  
CMSE : 1.2.10, 7.1.2  
CWE : 561  
GJB : 4.7.1.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-10  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.1  
SEC-C : M1.1.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
77 D
Local structure returned in function result.

A function shall not return a structure object that contains a pointer to a local object. Following return of control to the calling function the local object will have gone out of scope and no longer exist.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 77 D : Local structure returned in function result.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
struct tag
{
   UCHAR  * uptr;
};
 
static struct tag SDA_077 (void)
{
   UCHAR  loc = 42;
 
   struct tag rtag;
   rtag.uptr = &loc;
 
   return   rtag; /* Not compliant  */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL30-C  
CWE : 562, 758, 825  
FSB582-C++ : 4.11  
MISRA-AC : 17.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 17.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.18.6  
SEC-C : X3.x  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy , RUNTIME
78 D
Global variable should be declared const.

Global variables should be declared constant wherever possible to avoid unintentional modification, thereby helping to ensure the correctness and security of applications.

Local variables are covered by standard 93 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
static void SDA_078( void);
 
/*
 * Standard 78 D : Variable should be declared const.
 */ 
 
UCHAR glob=9; /* Not compliant  */ 
 
static void SDA_078( void )
{
   UCHAR loc;
   loc = glob;
}
 
int main(void)
{
    SDA_078( );
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL00-C  
CWE : 736  
FSB582-C++ : 4.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-1-1  
SEC-C : M1.11.1, M1.11.3  
79 D
Member function may be declared static.

Member functions should be declared static wherever possible to avoid unintentional modification, thereby helping to ensure the correctness and security of applications. Non-member functions are covered by standard 61 D.

A function with no static or const qualifier may flag both a 46 D and a 79 D violation. In this case the function should be declared static, as adding both qualifiers is illegal.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************
 * Standard 79 D : Member function may be declared static.
 *********************************************************/
 
class Student
{
  public:
    Student()
    {
      m_NumStudents++;
    }
 
    static UINT_32 m_NumStudents;
 
    UINT_32 getTotal( void ) /* not compliant */
    {
      return m_NumStudents;
    }
};
 
UINT_32 Student::m_NumStudents = 0U;
 
void SDA_079( void )
{
  UINT_32 total;
 
  Student my_student;
  total = my_student.getTotal();
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C++:2008 : 9-3-3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

80 D
Potentially unused function-modified value.

The value returned by a function should be used or discarded using (void). Simply assigning the value to a variable that is not subsequently used is not sufficient.

In particular, the status returned by input/output functions should be checked and errors handled appropriately. The failure to check file operation errors may lead to unexpected behaviour.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************
 * Standard 80 D : Potentially unused function-modified value.
 *************************************************************/ 
 
static SINT_32 func(SINT_32 pp)
{
    return pp;
}
 
static void SDA_080( void)
{
   SINT_32 x;
   x = func(1); /* Not compliant  */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO04-C, FIO33-C  
CWE : 252, 273, 391  
JPL : 7  
SEC-C : R3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
81 D
Attempt to remove an open file.

Removing an open file is implementation defined, and may lead to abnormal termination or a failure to delete files. The latter has security implications as a result of unintended information disclosure. A more strongly defined function should be considered instead of remove().

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/**************************************************
 * Standard 81 D : Attempt to remove an open file.
 **************************************************/ 
 
FILE * fptr;
 
static void SDA_081( void)
{
   fptr = fopen("mikes.h","r");
 
   remove("mikes.h"); /* Not compliant  */ 
   fclose(fptr);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO08-C  
CWE : 775  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
82 D
fsetpos values not generated by fgetpos.

Do not use values for fsetpos() that have not been obtained by a prior successful call to fgetpos(). Any other values for pos result in undefined behaviour, which could provide a user with unauthorised access to data being read from the file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 82 D : fsetpos values not generated by fgetpos.
*******************************************************************/
 
static void SDA_082( void)
{
   FILE * fptr;
   struct {SINT_32 ff;}astr;
 
   fpos_t * anoffset = (fpos_t *)&astr;
   fptr = fopen("afile.h","w");
   fsetpos(fptr,anoffset);  /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO44-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
83 D
Potentially repeated call to ungetc.

Calls to ungetc() should be separated by successful calls to a file positioning function such as fseek(), fsetpos(), or rewind(). Improper use of ungetc may cause data to be truncated or lost.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
static void SDA_083( SINT_32 par );
 
/*
 * Standard 83 D : Potentially repeated call to ungetc.
 */ 
 
 
SINT_32 ch;
FILE * fptr;
 
static void SDA_083( SINT_32 par )
{
   if( par == 341 )
   {
      ungetc(ch,fptr);
   }
   if( par > 0 ) {
      ungetc(ch,fptr); /* Not compliant  */ 
   }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO13-C  
CWE : 675, 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
84 D
No fseek or flush before I/O.

Input and ouptut from a stream shall be separated by successful calls to a fflush() or a file positioning function such as fseek(), fsetpos(), or rewind() to avoid undefined behaviour arising.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <string.h> 
 
static void SDA_084( void);
 
/*
 * Standard 84 D : No fseek or flush before I/O.
 */ 
 
 
static void SDA_084( void)
{
   int c,i;
   char data[256],append_data[256];
   FILE *fp1;
   strcpy(append_data,"Some data to append");
   fp1 = fopen("pf1.txt","a+");
   c = getc(fp1);
   fwrite(append_data,256,1,fp1);
   if (c != 'o')
   {
      /* Not compliant */ 
      fread(data,256,1,fp1);
   }
   fclose (fp1);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO39-C  
CWE : 758  
MISRA-AC : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 1.2  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
85 D
Filename not verified before fopen.

File names originating from untrusted sources should be validated to ensure that the file name refers to an expected and valid file. Typically this will require the file name to be an absolute path name. Validation addresses the exploitable vulnerability whereby access to an unintended file is permitted.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <string.h> 
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 85 D : Filename not verified before fopen.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
static void SDA_085( void)
{
   char ok_file_name[256],bad_file_name1[256],bad_file_name2[256];
   FILE *fp1,*fp2,*fp3;
 
   strcpy(ok_file_name,"/home/ldra.txt");
   fp1 = fopen(ok_file_name,"w");  /* No error here because string is known */
 
   scanf("%s %s",bad_file_name1,bad_file_name2);   
   if (strcmp(bad_file_name2,"bad_file.txt") != 0)
   {
      fp2 = fopen(bad_file_name1,"w"); /* not compliant */
 
      /* No error here because the file name has been mentioned
         in a conditional */ 
      fp3 = fopen(bad_file_name2,"w");
   }
 
   fclose (fp1);
   fclose (fp2);
   fclose (fp3);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO02-C  
CWE : 22, 37, 38, 39, 41, 59  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
86 D
User input not checked before use.

User input shall be checked before it is used. It is particularly dangerous to call I/O functions with a format string containing user input, since malicious users could attack a vulnerable process permitting access to the stack or heap memory.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <string.h> 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 86 D : User input not checked before use.
 *******************************************************************/
 
 
static void SDA_086( void)
{
   char input_string1[256], input_string2[256];
 
   scanf("%s %s",input_string1, input_string2);
   if (input_string2 != NULL)
   {
      /* Not compliant */ 
      fprintf(stderr, input_string1);
   }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : FIO30-C  
CWE : 134  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
87 D
Illegal shared object in signal handler.

Non-volatile shared objects shall not be used in signal handlers. Access to a shared object in signal handlers is viewed as undefined behaviour, and may lead to race conditions.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <signal.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 87 D : Illegal shared object in signal handler.
 **********************************************************/
 
INT_32 glob_var;
volatile sig_atomic_t e_flag = 0;
 
/*
 * This is a non-compliant signal handler because it accesses glob_var
 * which is an ordinary integer
 */ 
void my_handler1(int signum)
{
   glob_var = 99;
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n",signum);
 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * This is a compliant signal handler because it only accesses e_flag
 * which is a volatile type
 */ 
void my_handler2(int signum)
{
   e_flag = 99;
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n",signum);
}
 
void SDA_087(void)
{
   signal(SIGINT, my_handler1);
   signal(SIGTERM,my_handler2);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : SIG31-C  
CWE : 662, 758  
MISRA-AC : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2004 : 21.1  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Legacy
88 D
Illegal use of longjmp in signal handler.

The longjmp() function shall not be invoked in signal handlers. The use of longjmp in signal handlers can lead to undefined behaviour - likely to compromise the integrity of the program - if as a result calling longjmp(), a function with side-effects is invoked.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <signal.h> 
#include <string.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <setjmp.h> 
 
void SDA_088(void);
void my_handler1(int signum);
 
/*
 * Standard 88 D : Illegal use of longjmp in signal handler.
 */ 
 
static jmp_buf env;
 
/*
 * This is a non-compliant signal handler because it uses longjmp
 */ 
void my_handler1(int signum)
{
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n",signum);
   longjmp(env,1);
}
 
void SDA_088(void)
{
   setjmp(env);
   signal(SIGINT,my_handler1);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : SIG32-C  
CWE : 479  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
89 D
Illegal use of raise in signal handler.

The raise() function shall not be invoked by a signal handler. If a signal occurs as a result of calling abort or raise, then a further call to raise gives rise to recursion leading to undefined behaviour.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <signal.h> 
#include <string.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <setjmp.h> 
 
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 89 D : Illegal use of raise in signal handler.
*******************************************************************/
 
static jmp_buf env;
 
void my_handler1(INT_32 signum)
{
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n",signum);
}
 
/*
 * This is a non-compliant signal handler because it uses raise
 */ 
void my_handler2(INT_32 signum)
{
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n",signum);
   raise(SIGUSR1);
}
 
void SDA_089(void)
{
   signal(SIGUSR1, my_handler1);
   signal(SIGINT,  my_handler2);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : SIG33-C  
CWE : 479  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.1.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
90 D
Unguarded global used in threaded function.

For multi-threaded applications, resources that are shared between threads - that is, global objects, shall be guarded to prevent simultaneous use, by means of mutual exclusion (mutex) algorithms.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*
 * Standard 90 D : Unguarded global used in threaded function.
 */ 
 
/*
 * Simple deadlock
 * Threaded functions which lock a mutex.
 * lock/unlock in wrong order in funcB-- another type of race condition.
 */ 
 
#include <stdio.h> 
// #include <unistd.h> 
#include <stdlib.h> 
 
#include <math.h> 
#include <sys/types.h> 
#include <semaphore.h> 
#include <pthread.h> 
 
#define NumOfThreads 2
int ind[] = {0,1};
pthread_mutex_t mutexA;
static pthread_t TheThread[NumOfThreads];
void *funcA( void * arg );
void *funcB( void * arg );
int count = 0;
int main() {
   int i, status;
 
   if ( pthread_mutex_init(&mutexA , NULL) != 0){ printf("Error initialising mutex\n");}
 
   pthread_create( &TheThread[0], NULL, funcA , &ind[0]);
   pthread_create( &TheThread[1], NULL, funcB , &ind[1]);
 
   for(i=0;i <NumOfThreads;i++)
   {
      pthread_join(TheThread[i], (void **)&status );  // Exit the threads 
   }
}
 
void *funcA( void * arg ){
   int *i = (int*)arg;
 
   printf("Thread number %d\n", *i);
   pthread_mutex_lock(&mutexA);
   count++;
   pthread_mutex_unlock(&mutexA);
 
   return 0;
}
 
void *funcB( void * arg ){
   int *i = (int*)arg;
 
   printf("Thread number %d\n", *i);
   pthread_mutex_unlock(&mutexA);   /* not compliant */ 
   count++;
   pthread_mutex_lock(&mutexA);
 
   return 0;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 362  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
91 D
Function return value potentially unused.

The value returned by a function should be used or discarded using (void). Simply assigning the value to a variable that is not subsequently used is not sufficient.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 91 D : Function return value potentially unused.
 *******************************************************************/
 
static UINT_32 return_unsigned ( void )
{
  return 4U;
}
 
static void SDA_091 ( void )
{
   UINT_32 unused1;
   unused1 = return_unsigned ( ); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CWE : 252, 273, 391  
JSF++ AV : 115  
MISRA-AC : 16.10  
MISRA-C:2004 : 16.10  
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.7, R.17.7  
SEC-C : R3.3.1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
92 D
C'tor/d'tor calls virtual function.

A virtual function of a class should not be called from its constructors or destructor. This may lead to unexpected behaviour, as for example when a constructor of a derived class calls the virtual function of the base class instead of the derived class.

A virtual function can be used in a constructor or destructor, if the function can be determined statically using the scope resolution operator (::).

Example
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 92 D : C'tor/d'tor calls virtual function.
 *******************************************************************/
 
class Data
{
   public:
       Data ( )  { virt_fun ( ); }  /* not compliant */
      ~Data ( )  { virt_fun ( ); }  /* not compliant */
      virtual void virt_fun ( ) { ; }
};
 
class Data2
{
   public:
       Data2 ( ) { Data2::virt_fun2 ( ); } /* compliant */
      ~Data2 ( ) { Data2::virt_fun2 ( ); } /* compliant */
      virtual void virt_fun2 ( ) { ; }
};
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 3.3.13  
JSF++ AV : 71.1  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 12-1-1  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

93 D
Local variable should be declared const.

Local variables should be declared constant wherever possible to avoid unintentional modification, thereby helping to ensure the correctness and security of applications.

Global variables are covered by standard 78 D.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 93 D : Local variable should be declared const.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void SDA_093 ( void )
{
  UINT_32 local = 44U;
  use_uint(local);
}
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2010 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : DCL00-C  
CWE : 736  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 7-1-1  
SEC-C : M1.11.1, M1.11.3  
94 D
Named variable declared but not used in code.

This variable has been declared, but not used and hence can be removed.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 94 D : Named variable declared but not used in code.
 *******************************************************************/
 
UINT_32 SDA_094( void )
{
   UINT_32 v_1;
   UINT_32 v_2;  /* Not Compliant */
 
   v_1 = 0;
   return v_1;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2011 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.8, 5.16.18  
CERT-C : MSC13-C  
CMSE : 1.2.10, 1.2.11  
CWE : 563  
DERA : 143  
GJB : 5.2.1, 5.2.2  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-3  
Related standards filter models
Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
95 D
Named global function pointer used in procedure.

Some authorities believe that the use of global function pointers is bad programming practice. Certainly it is more difficult to reuse procedures that use such pointers. Furthermore, the order of initialisation across translation units is unspecified, and so any module which contains the appropriate declaration may access a global function pointer defined elsewhere before it has received an initial value.

This standard will also be generated for procedures that indirectly access global function pointers through procedure calls. Checks on global variables and pointers are covered by 10 D.

Example
extern void gf1(void);
 
void (*gfptr)(void) = &gf1;
 
void SDA_095(void)
{
   gfptr();   /* Not Compliant */
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2011 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 6.6, 8.2.2  
96 D
Variable has repeated initialisation.

A variable exists that has been initialised, and has then been assigned a value without being referenced. Such anomalies can arise from programming errors.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************
 * Standard 96 D : Variable has repeated initialisation.
 *******************************************************/
 
void SDA_096( void )
{
   UINT_32 v_1 = 0U;  /* Not Compliant */
   v_1 = 3U; 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards filter models
Legacy
97 D
Signal called from within signal handler.

The signal() function shall not be invoked by a signal handler. Calling the signal function from within a signal handler may result in a race condition in non-persistent platforms. This may cause the signal's default behaviour despite a handler's attempt to override it.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <signal.h> 
#include <stdio.h> 
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 97 D : Signal called from within signal handler.
*************************************************************/
 
static void my_handler2(INT_32 signum)
{
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n", signum);
}
 
static void my_handler1(INT_32 signum)
{
   fprintf(stderr,"Signal %d encountered\n", signum);
   signal(SIGHUP, my_handler2);              /* Not compliant */
}
 
static void SDA_097(void)
{
   signal(SIGINT,  my_handler1);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : SIG34-C  
CWE : 479  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
98 D
Attempt to write to file opened read only.

The C standard does not specify the behaviour if an attempt is made to write to a file that has been opened as read only.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 98 D : Attempt to write to file opened for read
 ************************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_098(void)
{
  FILE *fp1;
 
  fp1 = fopen("file1.dat", "r");
  fprintf(fp1, "Attempting to write to read-only file\n"); /* Not compliant */
  fclose(fp1);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.4  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
99 D
Named pointer object used in procedure.

Some authorities believe that the use of global pointers is bad programming practice. Certainly it is more difficult to reuse procedures that use such variables. Furthermore, the order of initialisation across translation units is unspecified, and so any module which contains the appropriate declaration may access a global pointer defined elsewhere before it has received an initial value.

Checks on global variables and global function pointers are covered by 10 D and 95 D. This rule covers pointer members of classes.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
int *m_ptr;        /* Global pointer */
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 99 D : Named pointer object used in procedure.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_099(void)
{
  *m_ptr = 98;
}  /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
100 D
Named static member object used in procedure.

Some authorities believe that the use of static members objects is bad programming practice. Certainly it is more difficult to reuse procedures that use such variables.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 100 D : Named static member object used in procedure.
 *****************************************************************/ 
 
class my_class
{
 public:
   my_class ()
   {
   }
 
   void proc1()
   {
      sint = 1;
   }
 
   static INT_32 sint;
 
};
 
INT_32 my_class::sint = 0;
 
void sda_100(void)
{
   my_class m;
   m.proc1();
 
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
HIC++ : 6.6, 8.2.2  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

101 D
Function has static member variable side effects.

A function has static member variable side effects if it can return a value through a static member as well as by means of its parameters (possibly) and its return type. The safest form is one which only returns a value through the return type.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*********************************************************************
 * Standard 101 D : Function has static member variable side effects.
 *********************************************************************/
 
class my_class
{
 public:
   my_class ()
   {
   }
 
   INT_32 proc1()
   {
      sint = 1;
      return sint;
   } /* not compliant */
 
   static INT_32 sint;
};
 
INT_32 my_class::sint = 0;
 
void SDA_101(void)
{
   my_class m;
   m.proc1();
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.13  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

102 D
Void function has static member variable side effects.

Procedures that have static member variable side effects shall be avoided as their invocation may result in unexpected results when the order of evaluation in the calling expression is significant.

Constructors and destructors are excluded from this standard.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*************************************************************************
 * Standard 102 D : Void function has static member variable side effects.
 **************************************************************************/
 
class my_class
{
 public:
   my_class ()
   {
   }
 
   void proc1()
   {
      sint = 1;
   } /* not compliant */
 
   static INT_32 sint;
};
 
INT_32 my_class::sint = 0;
 
void SDA_102(void)
{
   my_class m;
   m.proc1();
} /* not compliant - calls proc1 which alters a static member */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
/
Related standards model rules
FSB582-C++ : 1.13  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c.

103 D
File opened both read and write.

The C standard does not specify the behaviour if a file is both written and read via different FILE pointers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h> 
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 103 D : File opened both read and write.
 **********************************************************/
 
void SDA_103(void)
{
   CHAR ch;
   FILE *fp1,*fp2;
   fp1 = fopen("file1.txt", "r");
 
   ch = getc(fp1);
   if (ch != (INT_32)EOF)
   {
      /* file1.txt opened both read and write on different streams */
      fp2 = fopen("file1.txt","w");  /* not compliant */
   }
   fclose (fp1);
   fclose (fp2);
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2012 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.3  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

104 D
Structure implementation not hidden.

The implementation of the structure is not referenced in this translation unit. The implementation details should be protected from unintentional changes by creating on opaque pointer.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
struct not_opaque
{
   INT_32 a;
   CHAR c;
};
 
typedef struct not_opaque *ptr_not_opaque;
 
 
/* struct opaque declared in another translation unit */
typedef struct opaque *ptr_opaque; 
 
/**********************************************************
 * Standard 104 D : Structure implementation not hidden.
 **********************************************************/
 
void SDA_104(void)
{
   struct opaque opq;
   struct not_opaque nopq;
 
   ptr_opaque p_ok1 = &opq;
   ptr_opaque p_ok2; 
   ptr_not_opaque p_nok1;   /* not compliant */
 
   p_ok2 = p_ok1;
   p_nok1 = &nopq;
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : D.4.8  
105 D
DU anomaly dead code, variable value is unused on all paths.

DU anomalies are unnecessary and can always be removed with a consequent improvement in the readability and efficiency of the code.

A DU anomaly will occur if a variable is assigned a value that is not used in any branches of a program. This is a restricted version of 70 D, which checks whether a variable is assigned a value in all branches of a program.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
 
/*******************************************************************************
 * Standard 105 D : DU anomaly dead code, variable value is unused on all paths.
 ******************************************************************************/ 
 
static void sda_105 ( const UINT_32 p1 )
{
  UINT_32 var_1 = 0U;
  UINT_32 var_2 = p1;  /* Compliant - var_2 is used in one branch */
 
  var_1++;  /* not compliant - var_1 is not used after incrementation */
 
  if ( p1 > 42U )
  {
     printf("%u\n", var_2);
  }
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
