CERT-C : MSC06-C, MSC12-C, MSC13-C  
CWE : 14, 563  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.2.2  
106 D
No prototype for non-static function.

In general providing prototypes is considered to be good practice and is essential if the uses precede the definition.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/************************************************************
 * Standard 106 D : No prototype for non-static function.
 ************************************************************/ 
 
void SDA_106( INT_32 * par_1 )
{
   *par_1 =  1;
} /* not compliant */
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.4  
107 D
Attempt to change system call capture string.

Modifying the data structures or strings returned from getenv, localconv, setlocale, and strerror can lead to undefined behaviour.

Example
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
 
/********************************************************************
 * Standard 107 D : Attempt to change system call capture string.
 ********************************************************************/
 
void SDA_107( void )
{
   char *error_str;
   char *buf = "extra_text";
 
   error_str = getenv ("MY_VAR");
   strcat(error_str, buf);        /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ENV30-C  
CWE : 744  
108 D
Tainted argument to unprototyped func ptr.

Functions may only be designed to work for a subset of the possible values described by their parameter types. An argument to such a function is referred to as tainted if the value is derived from an external input to the program. Values from library calls such as getenv, fscanf, getchar are treated as being tainted.

If a function has no prototype, the likelihood of the problem increases as the compiler places no limits on the types of the arguments. When a prototype is present, it is possible that such a problem would be detected.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
 
extern void (*pfn)( );  /* Unprototyped function pointer */
 
/****************************************************************
 * Standard 108 D : Tainted argument to unprototyped func ptr.
 ****************************************************************/
 
#define GET_TAINTED_INT(val)                         \
        do {const char *taint = getenv("TAINT_I");   \
            if (taint == NULL) {taint = "42";}       \
            val = strtol(taint, 0, 10);              \
           } while (0);
 
 
void SDA_108(void)
{
   INT_32 tainted;
   GET_TAINTED_INT(tainted)
   (*pfn)(tainted); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
109 D
Tainted argument to formatted i/o function.

The C library formatted input and output functions do not check whether the input data is within the range of the array to which it will be written. This can lead to corruption of memory.

An argument to such a function is referred to as tainted if the value is derived from an external input to the program. Values from library calls such as getenv, fscanf, getchar are treated as being tainted.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
 
/***************************************************************
 * Standard 109 D : Tainted argument to formatted i/o function.
 ***************************************************************/
 
#define GET_TAINTED_INT(val)                         \
        do {const char *taint = getenv("TAINT_I");   \
            if (taint == NULL) {taint = "42";}       \
            val = strtol(taint, 0, 10);              \
           } while (0);
 
 
void SDA_109(void)
{
   INT_32 tainted;
   char buff[4];
   GET_TAINTED_INT(tainted)
   (void) sprintf(buff, "%d", tainted); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : STR31-C  
CWE : 119  
110 D
More than one prototype for same function.

A function shall have only one non-defining declaration in a file.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 110 D : More than one prototype for same function.
 *******************************************************************/
 
INT_32 fn(INT_32 a);
INT_32 fn(INT_32 a); /* Not compliant */
 
INT_32 fn(INT_32 a)
{
   return a;
}
 
void sda_110( void )
{
  INT_32 rc;
  rc = fn(0);
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 8.8  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.8  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.5  
NETRINO : 6.2.d  
SEC-C : M4.4.3  
Related standards filter models
Legacy
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

111 D
Errno checked without having been set.

The improper use of errno may result in failing to detect an error condition or in incorrectly identifying an error condition when none exists. When errno is tested after a call to a library function, this standard checks that errno has been assigned a value before the call.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <limits.h>
#include <errno.h>
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 111 D : Errno checked without having been set.
 *******************************************************************/
 
void sda_111(const char *c_str)
{
   char *endpt1 = NULL;
 
   /* errno not set to 0 before call */
   UINT_64 num1 = strtoul(c_str, &endpt1 ,0);
 
   if ( endpt1 == c_str  
       || (num1 == ULONG_MAX && errno == ERANGE)  /* not compliant */
       )
   { ; }
   else
   { ; }
}   
 
int main( int argc, char *argv[] )
{
  sda_111("Hello");
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2014 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ERR30-C  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

112 D
Free called twice on same variable.

It can be dangerous to free memory more than once as this can permit an attacker to execute arbitrary code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 112 D : Free called twice on same variable.
 ********************************************************/
 
void sda_112(void)
{
  INT_32 *x = (INT_32*)malloc(10 * sizeof(INT_32));
 
  if (x == NULL) 
  {
    fprintf(stderr, "malloc failure in %s\n", __func__);
    free(x);
  } 
  else 
  {
    *x[0] = 1;
  }
 
  free(x);  /* not compliant */
}
 
int main( int argc, char *argv[] )
{
  sda_112();
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2014 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MEM31-C  
CWE : 415  
113 D
File closed more than once.

The value of a FILE pointer is indeterminate after a close operation has occurred. Therefore unexpected behaviour may occur if a second close operation occurs.

Example
#include <stdio.h>
 
/***************************************************
 * Standard 113 D : File closed more than once.
 ***************************************************/
 
void SDA_113(int p1)
{
   FILE *fp1;
   fp1 = fopen("data1.txt","r");
   if (p1 == 0)
   {
      fclose(fp1);
   }
   fclose(fp1); /* not compliant */
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2014 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : MSC15-C  
CWE : 399, 910  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.22.6  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , RUNTIME
1 X
Declaration types do not match across a system.

The cross referencer checks that the types of variables used across the system are identical. This standard is only enabled when the code is run as a system set with at least 2 files.

Example

Xref_001_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 1 X : Declaration types don't match across a system.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32  xref_1;
 
static void xref_001 ( void )
{
  ;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Xref_001_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/**************************************************************
 * Standard 1 X : Declaration types don't match across a system.
 **************************************************************/ 
 
SINT_32  xref_1; /* not compliant */
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CERT-C : ARR31-C  
CWE : 129, 758  
DERA : 26  
HIS : 26  
MISRA-AC : 8.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-2-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 26  
MISRA-C:2004 : 8.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.8.4  
Related standards filter models
CONFORM , Customer Sample , Legacy , Standard , VSOS
2 X
Ambiguous declaration of variable.
Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/********************************************************
 * Standard 2 X : Ambiguous declaration of variable.
 ********************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32  xref_1;
SINT_32  xref_1; /* not compliant */
 
 
void xref_002(void)
{
   /* ... */ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2001 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
CAST : 5.16.12  
CERT-C : DCL36-C  
DERA : 25  
HIS : 25  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 3-9-1  
MISRA-C:1998 : 25  
Related standards filter models
Legacy , VSOS
3 X
Variable has only one use.

A variable has been defined but not subsequently referenced. Unused variables are indicative of programming errors and should be checked and, if not required, removed from the code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
const SINT_32 g_var = 1;
 
/*********************************************
 * Standard 3 X : Variable has only one use.
 *********************************************/ 
 
static void XREF_003( SINT_32 p_var )
{
   SINT_32 result1 = g_var * p_var; /* not compliant */
 
   /* Some code which makes no further reference to 'result1'... */ 
}
 
 
/*
 * Copyright (c) 2006 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-C++:2008 : 0-1-4  
4 X
Identifier reuse: struct/union tag repeated.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 4 X : Identifier reuse: struct/union tag repeated
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
void bar(void);
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  struct stag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
  {
    UINT_32 us1;
    UINT_32 us2;
  } sobj1;
  struct stag_name sobj2 = {1, 2}; /* Compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  struct stag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
  {
    SINT_32 ss1;
    CHAR ch1;
  } sobj3;
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4, 3-2-2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
5 X
Identifier reuse: struct vs union.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 5 X : Identifier reuse: struct vs union
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
union utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
    SINT_32 us1;
    CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
union utag_name uobj2 = {'a'}; /* Compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  struct utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
  {
	UINT_32 ss1;
    UINT_32 ss2;
  } sobj1;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
6 X
Identifier reuse: struct/union tag vs enum tag.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 6 X : Identifier reuse: struct/union tag vs enum tag
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
union utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  enum utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
  {
    first,
    second
  } sobj1;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
7 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs procedure.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 7 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs procedure
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void stag_name(void);  /* Not compliant */ 
 
union stag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
void stag_name(void) /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.5, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4, 2-10-5

MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7, R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
8 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs procedure parameter.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 8 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs procedure parameter
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(UINT_32 utag_name);  /* Not compliant */ 
 
union utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 utag_name) /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
9 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs variable.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 9 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs variable
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
union utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  UINT_32 utag_name;  /* Not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4, 2-10-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
10 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs label (MR).

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 10 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs label
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
union utag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
void xref_10(void)
{
  /***/ 
 
utag_name:       /* Not compliant */ 
  uobj1.us1 = 0;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
11 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs typedef.

An identifier should not be used for both the name of a tag and the name of a typedef. This may lead to confusion when maintaining the code.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 11 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs typedef.
 *******************************************************************/
 
typedef double utag_name;
 
union utag_name           /* Not compliant */
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} uobj1;
 
 
static void xref_011 ( void )
{
  /***/
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3, 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4, 2-10-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3, 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6, R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
12 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs macro.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example

Xref_012_1.c

#define s_tag2 sn1
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 12 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs macro
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct s_tag   
{
  UINT_32 comp1;
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_type;
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Xref_012_2.c

#define s_tag sn2  /* not compliant */ 
#define u_tag sn3
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 12 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs macro
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct s_tag2  /* not compliant -  Redefinition of macro in file 1 */ 
{
  UINT_32 comp3;
  UINT_32 comp4;
} s_type2;
 
typedef union u_tag  /* ok, in-file macro substitution renders this 'sn3' prior to check */ 
{
  SINT_32 us1;
  CHAR us2;
} u_type;
 
 
void xref_012 ( void )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
13 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs component.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 13 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs component
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct stag_name  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  UINT_32 comp1;
  UINT_32 comp2;
} stag_type;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  struct sloctag_name
  {
    UINT_32 stag_name;  /* Not compliant */ 
  } sobj1;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
14 X
Identifier reuse: tag vs enum constant.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 14 X : Identifier reuse: tag vs enum constant
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct s_name1_tag  /* Not complaint */ 
{
  UINT_32 comp1;
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_name1_type;
 
typedef enum e_name1_tag
{
  first,
  s_name1_tag   /* Not compliant */ 
} e_name1_type;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
15 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs tag.

Tag names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the type definition, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 15 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs tag
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
static UINT_32 static_var2;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  struct static_var2   /* Not compliant */ 
  {
    UINT_32 xx1;
    UINT_32 yy1;
  } ss1;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.4, 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-4, 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.4, 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.7, R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
16 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs variable.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 16 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs variable
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef char t_name;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  UINT_32 t_name;     /* Not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
17 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs label (MR).

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files. This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 17 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs label
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_17_1(void)
{
  typedef char lab_name;  /* Not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
UINT_32 xref_17(void)
{
  UINT_32 retval = 0;
 
lab_name:               /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return retval;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
18 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs typedef.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file that contains the typedef.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 18 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs typedef.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_018_1(void)
{
  typedef double t_name;   
 
  t_name local_var;
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void xref_018(void)
{
  typedef char t_name;    /* Not compliant */ 
 
  t_name local_var;
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3, 3-2-2  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
19 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs procedure parameter.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 19 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs procedure parameter
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef char t_name;
 
void foo(UINT_32 t_name);  /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 t_name)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
20 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs typedef.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 20 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs typedef
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef double static_var1;    /* Not compliant */ 
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  static UINT_32 static_var1;  /* Not compliant */ 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3, 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3, 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3, 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6, R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
21 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs macro.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
 #include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 21 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs macro
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef int s_tag;   
 
#define s_tag sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
static void xref_021 ( void )
{
  ;
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
22 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs component.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 22 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs component
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
typedef struct my_struct_tag
{
  UINT_32 comp1;
  UINT_32 t_name;      /* Not compliant */ 
} my_struct_type;
 
typedef char t_name;   /* Not compliant */ 
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
23 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs enum constant.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 23 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs enum constant
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
void bar(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  typedef struct s_tag
  {
    UINT_32 comp1;
    UINT_32 comp2;
  } s_type;    /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  typedef enum e_tag
  {
    first,
    s_type     /* Not compliant */ 
  } e_type;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
24 X
Identifier reuse: typedef vs procedure.

Typedef names shall not be reused anywhere within a program, other than through the inclusion of a header file, containing the typedef, in multiple source files.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 24 X : Identifier reuse: typedef vs procedure
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void proc1(void);      /* Not compliant */ 
void proc2(void);
 
 
void proc1(void)       /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void proc2(void)
{
  typedef char proc1;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.3, 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-3, 2-10-5, 2-10-6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.3, 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.6, R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
25 X
Identifier reuse: procedure vs procedure param.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 25 X : Identifier reuse: procedure vs procedure param
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void proc1(UINT_32 param,            /* Not compliant */ 
                  UINT_32 another_param);
static void proc2(UINT_32 proc1);
 
 
static void proc1(UINT_32 param,            /* Not compliant */ 
                  UINT_32 another_param)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
static void proc2(UINT_32 proc1)            /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
26 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs label (MR).

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 26 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs label
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_26_1(void)
{
  static UINT_32 s_var;   /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
UINT_32 xref_26(void)
{
s_var:                    /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return 0;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
27 X
Identifier reuse: persist var vs persist var.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 27 X : Identifier reuse: persist var vs persist var
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
UINT_32 p_var;           /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  static UINT_32 p_var;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1, M4.4.3  
28 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs var.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 28 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs var
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
UINT_32 var1;    /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  UINT_32 var1;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
29 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs procedure.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 29 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs procedure
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);        /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
 
void foo(void)         /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  static UINT_32 foo;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
30 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs proc param.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 30 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs proc param
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 pp);  /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 pp)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  static UINT_32 pp;   /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
31 X
Identifier reuse: procedure vs procedure.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example

Xref_031_1.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 31 X : Identifier reuse: procedure vs procedure
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_031 (UINT_32 pp)  
{
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Xref_031_2.c

#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 31 X : Identifier reuse: procedure vs procedure
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void xref_031 (void)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
Language restrictions

This standard is not applicable to c++.

32 X
Identifier reuse: procedure vs var.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 32 X : Identifier reuse: procedure vs var
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);  /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
 
void foo(void)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
void bar(void)
{
  UINT_32 foo;   /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
33 X
Identifier reuse: procedure vs label (MR).

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 33 X : Identifier reuse: procedure vs label
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
UINT_32 xref_33(void)
{
foo:   /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return 0;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
34 X
Identifier reuse: proc vs macro.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
/* FILE 1 */ 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 34 X : Identifier reuse: proc vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);      /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo()           /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */ 
 
 
 
 
 
 
/* FILE 2 */ 
#define foo sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 34 X : Identifier reuse: proc vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void bar(void);
 
 
void bar()
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
35 X
Identifier reuse: proc vs component.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 35 X : Identifier reuse: proc vs component
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag
{
  UINT_32 comp1;   /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj;
 
void comp1(void);  /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void comp1(void)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
36 X
Identifier reuse: proc vs enum constant.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 36 X : Identifier reuse: proc vs enum constant
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);  /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
void foo(void)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  enum e_tag
  {
    first,
    second,
    foo          /* Not compliant */ 
  } e_obj;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
37 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs macro.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
/* FILE 1 */ 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 37 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo()
{
  static UINT_32 p_var = 0;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
 
 
 
 
 
/* FILE 2 */ 
#define p_var sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 37 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void bar(void);
 
 
void bar()
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
38 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs component.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 38 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs component
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag
{
  UINT_32 comp1;         /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  static UINT_32 comp1;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
39 X
Identifier reuse: persistent var vs enum constant.

The name of an identifier that is persistent, i.e. with static storage duration, should not be reused across any source files in the system. Objects or procedures with external linkage, and objects or procedures with the static storage class specifier, are persistent. Confusion may arise if two identifiers share the same name.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 39 X : Identifier reuse: persistent var vs enum constant
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
enum e_tag
{
  first,                 /* Not compliant */ 
  second
} e_obj;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  static UINT_32 first;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.5  
MISRA-C++:2008 : 2-10-5  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.5  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.8, R.5.9  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
40 X
Identifier reuse: component vs var.

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 40 X : Identifier reuse: component vs var
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag
{
  UINT_32 comp1;         /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  UINT_32 comp1;         /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
41 X
Identifier reuse: label vs variable (MR).

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 41 X : Identifier reuse: label vs var.
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_41_1(void)
{
  UINT_32 u_var;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
UINT_32 xref_41(void)
{
u_var:            /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return 0;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
GJB : 4.1.1.2  
MISRA-AC : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.6  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
42 X
Identifier reuse: component vs procedure param.

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 42 X : Identifier reuse: component vs procedure param
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag
{
  UINT_32 comp1;          /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj;
 
void foo(UINT_32 comp2);  /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 comp2)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}

 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates

MISRA-C:2004 : 5.6

43 X
Identifier reuse: label vs procedure param (MR).

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

#include "c_standards.h"

 * Standard 43 X : Identifier reuse: label vs procedure param
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void xref_43_1(UINT_32 u_var)  /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
UINT_32 xref_43(void)
{
u_var:                   /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return 0;
}

44 X
Identifier reuse: component vs enum constant.

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

 * A/Ref:

  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj;
 
enum e_tag
{
  comp1,           /* Not compliant */ 
  two
} e_obj;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /***/ 
}

Identifier reuse: component vs label (MR).

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.

  UINT_32 comp2;

  return 0;

46 X
Identifier reuse: label vs enum constant (MR).

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.

47 X
Identifier reuse: component vs macro.

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

Example
/* FILE 1 */ 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 47 X : Identifier reuse: component vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag
{
    UINT_32 comp1;
    UINT_32 comp2;   /* Not compliant */ 
} s_obj;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */ 
 
 
 
 
/* FILE 2 */ 
#define comp2 sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 47 X : Identifier reuse: component vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void bar(void);
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
48 X
Identifier reuse: label vs macro (MR).

An identifier name in one name space should not be reused in a different name space, except for structure and union component names. The C language name spaces are:

Members/components of structs and unions; each struct/union as a separate name space.
Struct, union, and enum tags.
Label names.
All other identifiers.

This standard is restricted to LDRA Testbed installations featuring the MISRA component, as indicated by (MR).

Example
/* FILE 1 */ 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 48 X : Identifier reuse: label vs macro
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
UINT_32 xref_48_1(void)
{
lab1:         /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
  return 0;
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */ 
 
 
 
/* FILE 2 */ 
#define lab1 sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 48 X : Identifier reuse: label vs macro
 *******************************************************************/

{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.6  
MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
SEC-C : M1.7.1  
49 X
Identifier reuse: var vs proc param.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 49 X : Identifier reuse: var vs proc param
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 pp);  /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
 
void foo(UINT_32 pp)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  UINT_32 pp;          /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.7  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7  
50 X
Identifier reuse: var vs macro.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

Example
/* FILE 1 */ 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 50 X : Identifier reuse: var vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  UINT_32 loc_var = 0;  /* Not compliant */ 
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */ 
 
 
 
 
/* FILE 2 */ 
#define loc_var sn1   /* Not compliant */ 
 
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 50 X : Identifier reuse: var vs macro
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/

void bar(void)
{
  /***/ 
}

51 X
Identifier reuse: var vs enum constant.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

#include "c_standards.h"

 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.7  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7  
52 X
Identifier reuse: proc param vs proc param.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 52 X : Identifier reuse: proc param vs proc param
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
static void proc1(UINT_32 param);           /* Not compliant */ 
 
static void proc2(UINT_32 param);           /* Not compliant */ 
 
 
static void proc1(UINT_32 param)            /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
static void proc2(UINT_32 param)            /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
Related standards model rules
MISRA-AC : 5.7  
MISRA-C:2004 : 5.7  
53 X

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

MISRA-AC : 5.7

MISRA-C:2012 : R.5.5  
54 X
Identifier reuse: proc param vs enum constant.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 54 X : Identifier reuse: proc param vs enum constant
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
void foo(UINT_32 param);  /* Not compliant */ 
void bar(void);
 
void foo(UINT_32 param)   /* Not compliant */ 
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
void bar(void)
{
  enum e_tag
  {
    first,
    second,
    param                 /* Not compliant */ 
  } e_obj;
 
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

57 X
Identifier reuse: macro vs enum constant.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

58 X
Identifier reuse: component vs component.

Identifier names should not be reused across any files in the system, regardless of scope. This violation captures a specific instance of identifier reuse not explicitly checked under the rules applied by 4 X to 48 X.

Example
#include "c_standards.h"
 
/*******************************************************************
 * Standard 58 X : Identifier reuse: component vs component
 * A/Ref:
 *******************************************************************/ 
 
struct s_tag1
{
  UINT_32 comp1;   /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp2;
} s_obj1;
 
struct s_tag2
{
  UINT_32 comp1;   /* Not compliant */ 
  UINT_32 comp3;
} s_obj2;
 
void foo(void);
 
 
void foo(void)
{
  /***/ 
}
 
 
/*
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2007 Liverpool Data Research Associates
 *
 */
